story:
Help us Launch the San Bernardino Production of RENT! And help us to celebrate and honor the 20th anniversary of the New York Theatre Workshop version that was performed in 1994!

The Project:

I am producing RENT in the spring of 2014 March 29th 2pm and 8pm (and student performance Friday the 28th) at the California Theatre in San Bernardino, California. The Inland Empire of California is one of the most economically challenged areas in the entire country. We are second to on Detroit economically. That said, most in the community can't afford theatre. We do have patrons, they love the theatre,  and still try to come as often as they can. In order to keep tickets cheap,  I need help paying some of the cost of the production. If you folks would hep me pay for the show royalty,  that would be tremendous. I will be trying to get student performances set up that will allow the most needy students in our community to see the show for free.

The style of the production will be true to Jonathan Larsons vision. Jonathan Larson told an interviewer once that, "in the theater, the old thing about how you can make a killing but you can't make a living is absolutely true. I'm living proof of that." .

Rent will play the 1700 seat California Theatre of the Performing Arts May 29, 2014 2pm and 8pm.


The November workshop of RENT in 1994 must have been a magical thing to see. We want to celebrate the way that RENT has grown in the 20 years that has passed since the 1994 workshop. We will be trying to get access to some of the original songs that did not make the show to play in the pre-show, with a narrative of why they did not make the production, as well as a narrative of the time leading up to opening night of the show.

For all its flaws, the November workshop was a tremendous success. It ran two weeks with the audience growing larger and more enthusiastic each night; by the last week it was sold out. Anthony Rapp, a cast member of the


November workshop, remembers the excitement: "I kept telling people it was going to be an event. We knew it needed work. But people I trust and respect - friends and collaborators - would come down and be knocked out by it."


Why this production is important:

As a straight man producing live theatre,  I am often surprised at how my fellow GLBT, actors, producers, make-up artists, stagehands and in general... FRIENDS are still treated in this time and age we live in.  Why do we still judge people based on how they live their lives, as opposed to the quality of human that they have become? Until there is equality for all in this nation of FREEDOM, we must continue to show RENT. This production shows us that no matter who or what we are, death takes us all. We have to address homophobia full force,  and one of the best ways to do that is to keep presenting material like RENT that shows us, we are all simply humans,  trying to get by in a world that will keep spinning long after we are gone. And we all need love.

COLLINS You all said you'd be cool today So please -- for my sake... I can't believe he's gone (to ROGER) I can't believe you're going I can't believe this family must die Angel helped us believe in love I can't believe you disagree!

The night of the final dress rehearsal, Jonathan was sick with a sore chest and a fever. But he took a taxi to Fourth Street, watched the show, and sat for his interview with the Times. The last thing Michael and Jim remember saying to him was to take it easy and sleep well; they'd see him and Lynn in the morning. Jonathan died an hour later.

The day of Jon's death, no one at the Workshop was quite sure what to do. The first performance was scheduled for that evening. Jim Nicola's first inclination was to cancel, but he knew they needed to do something for Jonathan's memory. Jim was uneasy. The first act, in particular, involved a lot of tricky dancing and jumping on tables. It hadn't been completely rehearsed, and he was afraid there would be injuries. Eddie Rosenstein urged him to run the whole show full out. By the evening, Jonathan's friends were streaming into the theatre, his parents were there, New York Theatre workshop was filled to capacity with people Jon loved - friends, family and colleagues. Jim decided on a sing-through - no movement, just songs. Throughout the first act, the cast was able to hold their seats. But very slowly, they began to rise. They acted, they danced. "It was incredible and terrible," Anthony remembers. "It was like we had to do it. We were all sobbing and crying." The lighting people made their way to the lighting booth; the sound manager began to pick up his cues. "They couldn't contain themselves," Eddie remembers. "The audience was reaching out to the cast. They were crying and cheering. By the second act, it was no longer contained. It was the full show run full-out, with every line hit for greater and greater meaning. If emotion could have become a physical force, the roof would have blown off, the weather would have changed." The second act ended. There was a huge ovation, the cast slowly left the stage, and the audience stayed in the theater. No one was sure what to do. The cast returned and sat down in the front row. Finally, a single voice called from the audience, "Thank you, Jonathan Larson," which brought the evening's loudest, final burst of applause.

Where You Come In:

Any donations beyond those that pay for the Royalties, will go into renting the theater space, costumes, set design, rehearsal space, and most importantly, pay for needy students in one of the poorest cities in America to see this production for free. 

About The Theatre:

The California Theatre of the Performing Arts was:


Originally a part of the Fox Theatre chain, it opened in 1928 and still houses its original Wurlitzer Style 216 pipe organ. It was also the last performance venue of humorist Will Rogers prior to his death in a 1935 plane crash. One of Will Rogers show curtains still hangs in the theatre fly loft. In the early years of Hollywood, filmmakers would test-screen their movies at the California Theatre. Classic films such as "King Kong" and "The Wizard of Oz" were first seen by audiences at the theatre in the 1930s.


The first version of King Kong was test screened to an audience at the California Theatre, in January 1933, before the official release. At that time the film contained a scene showing what happened to the sailors who were shaken from the log by Kong, showing that they were eaten alive at the bottom of the ravine by a giant spider, giant crab, giant lizard and an octopoid. The spider-pit scene provoked many members of the audience to scream, leave the theatre and even faint. After the preview, Merian C. Cooper cut the scene.


The fate of the song "Somewhere Over the Rainbow" from the Wizard of Oz was determined in 1939 in the lobby of the California Theatre as well. Producers and executives for "The Wizard of Oz" stood in the lobby and discussed keeping or cutting the song. MGM executives kept insisting that the song was a loser and destined to hurt the movie. It was only at the insistence of producer Arthur Freed, who went so far as to threaten that if "Over the Rainbow" was excised from The Wizard of Oz, MGM could count on excising him from the company, that the song made it into the final cut.

Many famous stars have performed at the California Theatre including Buster Keaton, Carol Burnett, The Three Stooges, George Carlin, Sophia Loren, David Niven, Rock Hudson, Yul Brenner, Jerry Seinfield and more!


Viva La Vie Bohème!

Jesse and the Cast & Crew of RENT

story:
The Project:

Hello!! I'm Mandy Greenle, a graduate student at the University of Colorado in Boulder. I am pursuing my Masters of Fine Arts in dance and focusing on community engagement and participatory performance. I utilize performance as a way to engage and include communities in imagining and energizing social change.

I have been invited with my Professor Beth Osnes to Nicaragua to work with the community at The Solar Center in Sabana Grande. This Solar Center was created by a group of women, Las Mujeres Solares de Totogalpa, who saved their community from deforestation by working with renewable energy. They built a solar powered restaurant, use solar cookers, bio-gas, compostable toilets, and sustainable irrigation practices. They are creating a community that is sustainable and are sharing these practices with other communities. 

We have been invited to work with the youth at The Solar Center in creating a solar powered shadow puppet show that tells the story of these remarkable women.

Objective:

The objective of this project will be for the youth to gain experience, confidence and proficiency in using performance to convey essential messages that they identify about clean energy development within their community.  

The Youth Group will learn how stories can be told through this artistic medium.  We will guide the students themselves to identify what information they want to communicate, how to embed that information in an engaging story, and how to bring that story to life through solar-powered shadow puppet theatre.  We will discuss where and how they could perform this in their own community to raise awareness and to educate others.

Your Support and Impact:

I am asking for your support to help me get down there. $1300 covers my expenses. The cost of a plane ticket is $1000 and food and lodging while I am there from January 1-10th is $300.

Please consider donating. Your money will have a direct positive impact on many people. This is an opportunity for me to engage with a community directly utilizing participatory theatre to educate others and increase awareness about the work of The Solar Women. 

I will be traveling with my Professor Beth Osnes, who has successfully utilized shadow puppetry around the world. She is currently working with the Navajo Nation in participatory theatre to engage the community in issues around renewable energy.

Thank you for your support with this project. These truly are incredible women and the opportunity to engage the youth in this creative process will continue to help the growth and success of The Solar Center.

If this project resonates with you please donate, spread the word and use the Indiegogo share tools!

THANK YOU!!!!!!!!

For more information about The Solar Center and Las Mujeres Solares de Totogalpa go to:

www.grupofenix.org

story:
La Burlesqueria

www.burlesqueria.com

is the baby of a series of burlesque classes by the Dandizette at the dance studio tanzEuphoria*. Three passionate and innovative performers, Carolin Oh là là, Désirée Varieté and Vienna Chaconne, along with well-known entertainer Madame Vagabunda and La Dandizette are launching the first hearty, feeling-good, open-stage burlesque show in Vienna on February 1st in Shelter (Vienna 1200): La Burlesqueria Vol. I!

Like every baby, La Burlesqueria needs nutrition and care. And despite the passionate efforts of the organising team some cash is still needed for La Burlesqueria to go live!

La Burlesqueria needs money

for the location, the flyers, the technicians, the costumes and for a part of the flight tickets of La Dandizette.

In return it will give you a magnificent and highly entertaining show, as well as surprises for sponsors donating more than 20 Euros!!

The Impact: The first show everybody can participate in

La Burlesqueria team sees the need of a friendly show, where the performers are close to the audience, where energy is exchanged and where what matters the most is not the glamour, the earnings and fame, but passion and love for whichever role!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Get the word out and make some noise about La Burlesqueria! Social media, Indiegogo share tools, friends and family promotion!


DANKE SCHÖN ! ! !


*www.tanzeuphoria.at

story:
Introduction - 8bit team

We are a team of 5 young people, that are interested in website development, video, photography and android applications. We are searching for young creative and talented people and help them make their dreams come true (dancers, singers, photographers, actors). We are not making anyone rich, just help them with promotional stuff. Our projects haven't made much profit yet, therefore we are searching for financial help to buy a proper equipment to support further projects. Also, we would get a excellent result of what we can make if there is a proper budget behind a project.

The beginning: Mission 1 - The Pharaohs. 

We have all seen dozen of choreography videos, which are kind of non-budget and usually quickly made. We find that quite boring therefore we are trying to do some kind of a choreography video with a story. The only problem is that it's quite hard to get budget for this kind of videos, that is why we are asking you to help. 

We are currently working on a nonprofit project called "Time is a Currency" with the Pharaohs. The story is about our lives and how we aren't able to control our time and enjoy it. Dance type is hip hop with some stuns.

We are going to make a 4 up to 5 minutes long "music/dance" video. Just like our previous one.

The Pharaohs represent a group of 8 young dancers, high school students and college students, that began their dancing career in local dance crew in Celje, Slovenia. They were gathered by world champion in hip hop and street dance Miha Poznič. The group is quite unique since it consists out of more boys than girls. The choreographies include hip hop, jazz and break dance. To make it even more interesting they tend to spice up their shows with some astonishing acrobat features.

If you would like to find out more about the Pharaohs, please go on youtube video and read the information or visit their Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/thepharaohs12?fref=ts


What We Need

Basically we will spend all the money for equipment as we seek for a high quality video. 

  • A proper camera (currently interested in BlackMagic Cinema), tripod, some lenses obviously, as we currently have none of the stuff.
  • All the extra money, will be spent for other expenses: travels, rentals, costumes, scenes etc.


 What You Get

  • The ones that contribute will get their names on Youtube and Vimeo as sponsors. If you contribute more, you can send us logo and we will add it in the video.
  • We were also thinking of offering contributors some discount on web development, as we do that too.
  • If you're an song artist/company we are accepting proposals on music and other adverts from you and other ideas of how we can include you in the video.
  • We are also thinking of making our website, though, we haven't decided yet. Website would be only used for our latest video. We would also share all the contributors on that website.
  • For the rest of contributors, for our next projects we are looking forward for your ideas.


Perks and rewards

Basically we didn't think of a proper rewards yet, except including your names in the video. But don't worry... We are going to think of a solution for a proper return of the favor. All the changes in ranks will affect on both, old and new contributors.

One of the possible rewards are wooden chains and t-shirts.


The end

You can also help us by promoting our project or sharing our previous video.

If the project will receive positive feedback, we are going to publish choreography tutorial. 

In case we don't reach the goal, we will just buy cheaper equipment which means that the project will be done either way.

This is more or less everything. We are thanking you for the time you "wasted" by reading this post and for all kinds of support you're giving us. 

If you have any kind of further question, or ability to help us in either way, you can contact us by email/facebook or by our official website.


We are going to update this post during time to provide you with information on what's going on with the project.
info@8bitdesign.si | www.8bitdesign.si

story:
I'm a Theatre teacher at Gateway High School in Kissimmee, Florida. At my school and in this community, kids quite simply don't get opportunities that rich white kids get. Most of my students have never been to New York City, and if they have, seeing a Broadway show is impossible for them. Kids here are taught to settle. The local community college becomes their highest (and sometimes their only) goal. They have dreams but they are never taught to turn those dreams into goals.

Each year I find a few kids who I think can use Theatre as their way out. Do I think every one of them is going to be a Broadway star? Probably not. But I CAN see them getting into good Acting or Musical Theatre programs out of this state, and I can see them getting a fresh start, expanding their horizons, turning dreams into career goals, and seeing that there is a world out there beyond the confines of their community. Through Theatre, these kids find their voices, and they find something to work for.

This year, I have 4 students who would like to audition for college at the Unified auditions in New York City in January. Some obvious costs are their airfare, their hotel room, food while in New York City, and transportation while there. In the past I've been able to help out a lot, but my financial circumstances have changed and I could use some assistance myself with the trip. In a dream world, I would be able to bring these kids and be there when they see their first Broadway musical, an event I got to experience with a student last year. Under the best circumstances I would bring them to multiple shows on Broadway and Off-Broadway and show them the sights of New York City.

I set the goal here low, at $1,000. The actual cost of a trip of a lifetime for these kids would be considerably more. These are kids who, when we take field trips locally, have to share every meal because they cannot afford to eat otherwise. Kids who expect to have 5 or 6 in a hotel room and who expect no amenities. One of my greatest joys as a teacher so far has been reaching a few of them. I hope you will support me in this.
story_txt: I'm a Theatre teacher at Gateway High School in Kissimmee, Florida.  At my school and in this community, kids quite simply don't get opportunities that rich white kids get.  Most of my students have never been to New York City, and if they have, seeing a Broadway show is impossible for them.  Kids here are taught to settle.  The local community college becomes their highest (and sometimes their only) goal.  They have dreams but they are never taught to turn those dreams into goals.Each year I find a few kids who I think can use Theatre as their way out.  Do I think every one of them is going to be a Broadway star?  Probably not.  But I CAN see them getting into good Acting or Musical Theatre programs out of this state, and I can see them getting a fresh start, expanding their horizons, turning dreams into career goals, and seeing that there is a world out there beyond the confines of their community.  Through Theatre, these kids find their voices, and they find something to work for.This year, I have 4 students who would like to audition for college at the Unified auditions in New York City in January.  Some obvious costs are their airfare, their hotel room, food while in New York City, and transportation while there.  In the past I've been able to help out a lot, but my financial circumstances have changed and I could use some assistance myself with the trip.  In a dream world, I would be able to bring these kids and be there when they see their first Broadway musical, an event I got to experience with a student last year.  Under the best circumstances I would bring them to multiple shows on Broadway and Off-Broadway and show them the sights of New York City.I set the goal here low, at $1,000.  The actual cost of a trip of a lifetime for these kids would be considerably more.  These are kids who, when we take field trips locally, have to share every meal because they cannot afford to eat otherwise.  Kids who expect to have 5 or 6 in a hotel room and who expect no amenities.  One of my greatest joys as a teacher so far has been reaching a few of them.  I hope you will support me in this.

story:
What is the Chicago Showcase?

On December 2, 2013 a group of 13 BFA Acting & Musical Theatre students from Ball State University will perform in Chicago for casting directors and agents! This is a huge first step toward launching us into our professional careers... and we need your help! You can help us get there by contributing. 

Where will the funds go?

Eventually, all of these funds will go toward...

  • Headshot/Resume printing... we need a LOT of them
  • Travel costs
  • Any additional materials we will need

THANK YOU!

Even if you cannot contribute... please help by spreading the word about our showcase!

We will continue to update this page with information and updates on the showcase!

Check back for event information & fun teasers!!!

story:
"By helping small companies and solo performers to produce and promote their shows, and by providing a network that puts artists in touch with one another, the Fringe seeks to advance the goals of its website mission statement: See Shows. Make Friends. Have Fun.” 

                                                                    -The Los Angeles Times

What is The Hollywood Fringe?

In four short years, the Hollywood Fringe has become the biggest performing arts festival in Los Angeles. The 2013 Fringe hosted over 200 artistic projects with over 1000 performances in dozens of venues all over Hollywood.  The festival sold over $250,000 in ticket sales and returned every dollar to the artists and venues.  Over 35,000 seats were sold. The 2014 Fringe is already showing more than 30% growth.

The Hollywood Fringe Festival is an annual, open-access, community-derived event celebrating freedom of expression and collaboration in the performing arts community. Each June during the Hollywood Fringe, the arts infiltrate Hollywood: fully equipped theaters, parks, clubs, churches, restaurants and other unexpected places host hundreds of productions by local, national, and international arts companies and independent performers.

Participation in the Hollywood Fringe is completely open and uncensored. This free-for-all approach underlines the festival’s mission to be a platform for artists without the barrier of a curative body. By opening the gates to anyone with a vision, the festival is able to exhibit the most diverse and cutting-edge points-of-view the world has to offer. Additionally, by creating an environment where artists must self-produce their work, the Fringe motivates its participants to cultivate a spirit of entrepreneurialism in the arts.

Where will the money go?

It costs hundreds of thousands of dollars to put up the festival every year. The Fringe is an expensive thing. Every year we are on the preverbal hook for printing, rent, insurance, advertisements, equipment, supplies and the myriad of services and goods required to serve and support this cause. As the Fringe expands year over year, so too does our overhead and we struggle to keep up.

We are specifically seeking money to help us with our marketing and promotion efforts. We always seek to empower our artists by helping them develop their marketing skills so they can efficiently connect with audiences for their individual productions but we also spend tens of thousands of dollars each year on publicity for the festival as a whole. This year, we're going above and beyond the efforts of our first four years: 

  • For the first time, the Hollywood Fringe will have pole banners. These highly visible signs will be all over Hollywood, Silver Lake, and other parts of Los Angeles. This is an expense that will benefit the Fringe for years to come.
  • The Fringe has also purchased a traditional billboard in the heart of Theatre Row on Santa Monica Blvd for the month of June.  This billboard marks the center of the Hollywood Fringe universe and gives a huge visibility push like nothing we've done before.
  • The Hollywood Fringe will once again work with 89.3 KPCC, LA Weekly, and other outlets to not only publicize the festival but to help maximize advertising opportunities for participants. 


The Impact

Take a look at our video above.  The Hollywood Fringe has galvanized the performing arts community in Los Angeles. As our festival continues to attract more artists it's important that we expand our visibility and marketing efforts so that we can reach a larger audience. The $7500 we hope to raise through this campaign is only a small fraction of what we will spend on producing the festival this year so please donate what you can.

story:
New Orleans Fringe Festival Parade -- it's a tradition!

Now in its 6th year, the collaboration between the Fringe Festival and the Goodchildren Social Aid & Pleasure Club is ready to scale new heights! But in these tough times, our regular sources of funding are pretty tapped out -- less money to go around, more requests for it. So we've come to you!

Our mission, unchanged since 2007, is to revitalize St. Claude, through celebration and cultural preservation. We have, over ther years, kept our parades as accessible as possible, while retaining the traditions of the neighborhoods we serve.

After our first parade in 2008, aptly titled "Resurrection" in honor of the changes taking place all over our city after the floods of Katrina, we were invited to produce a parade for the Fringe Festival -- by our very first Easter Bunny, one of the founders of the New Orleans Fringe!

From the first, we took the values of the many diverse neighborhoods surrounding St. Claude very seriously. We meant to be affordable, sustainable, dedicated to reuse and recycle, creative and inclusive.

We called ourselves "Goodchildren" in honor of the original name of St. Claude (Bons Enfants = Good Children). We rescued dolls from dumpsters and thrift stores, decorated them and used them as our signature throw. We pledged ourselves to not leaving a mess, and the Dukes of Debris was born.

We held our meetings and parties at local businesses, to show our gratitude for everyone who came back or stayed after Katrina. In fact, many of our early sponsors were local businesses and organizations. We still hold events and parties at bars and backyards in our neighborhoods.

We also make it a point to honor our elders, at St. Margaret's and Holy Angels, with parade stops and band performances. These are, after all, the very people who made these neighborhoods, and we want them to know how much we love them!

What We Need & What You Get

This pie chart shows how the money we raise will get spent. Much of it is non-negotiable, i.e., police escort and insurance, fees and fulfillment.
 
If we make our goal, we will be able to obtain all the supplies we need for promotion and publicity, and for band expenses and throws.
 
NOPD Escort - 40% ($1600)
   Lead and follow car, motorcylce escorts/traffic control, 6-8 officers
Insurance - 10% ($400)
   We insure for $1M
Pub/Promo - 20% ($800)
    Postcards, flyers, buttons, stickers, etc
Supplies - 20% ($800)
    Office, parade and band supplies
Fees/Fulfillment - 10% ($400)
     Rewards, packaging and postage
 
If we don't reach the full amount, we will still roll. We're committed to that. If there is shortfall, it will come from supplies and promotion.
 
If we go over our goal, we will be able to continue our band outreach to the kids in the neighborhood, and possibly get them some drums and sticks!
 
 
We think we have come up with some tempting rewards (check 'em out!) including our handmade throws, parade buttons and stickers, and a chance to be part of our royalty! We really love that highest level a lot -- and we hope someone takes advantage of it!

Why It Matters

In the 5 years we've been doing this, we have seen remarkable comebacks and new growth along St. Claude. While we can't take ALL the credit, we are proud to have played a small role in bringing people out to see our progress. Like the Fringe Festival, we are deeply committed to our community, and we love the spontaneous combustion of combining neighborhood groups, bands, dance groups, artists, Mardi Gras Indians, buskers, businesses, cheerleaders, bike sculptures and random locals with Fringe performers from all over the county, and indeed the world!
 
 
And we are equally committed to keeping it free and accessible for as long as we can. We absolutely adore the fact that just about everyone can be in our parades -- the spirit of New Orleans abounds and abides.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that everyone can't afford to contribute financially to every good cause. But there are still many ways to help!
 
* Email, tweet, like us on Facebook! We've provided all the links right here.
* Come to one of our throw parties, and help us fulfill our rewards!
* Let us know if you have extra art supplies or dolls you want to give us!
* Be in the parade! (Just email us, and we'll tell you how.)
 
Most of all, tell everyone you know to check us out and come to the parade. That's what this is all about! THANK  YOU!!!

story:
Our Story 

We met dancing for Patricia Rincon Dance Collective in 2010 and created our first site specific collaborative dance work this past summer. Patricia Rincon Dance collective is touring Europe this November. Given this opportunity, we have taken the initiative to prolong our stay and continue our own work. 

The Project

For 17 days, we will travel to 4 countries to bring dance out of the theater and into real life surroundings. The structure of our process will consist of scouting locations, conducting research, and making theatrical choices to create improvisational, site-specific dance works unique and relevant to each location. Inspiration from the location's environment, people, conversations and happenstance occurrences will develop each piece. We will conduct research on the location's environmental, cultural and social significance for further development. We will also collaborate with other artists, dancers and musicians and the general public in order to connect with the pulse of each city.  

This is a collective experience where dance is created to discover individual and communal stories that relate to the textures of our changing environment and society. We want to rediscover everyday life realities, with all of the complexities, madness, and beauty, through the lens of movement. Dance is a universal language that transcends borders, cultures, backgrounds, and stories. There is so much we can learn about ourselves and from each other through this expressive form of communication. We want to reinforce this unique bond that ties us together by creating site specific work that communicates to and connects with human essence. 

The impact

By creating guerrilla performances we will cultivate obtainable improvisational dance, available to anyone who chooses to stop, watch and perhaps interact. Just how architecture, nature, artwork, sounds, smells, conversations, life situations, enrich an environment and our experiences in it, so can live art. We want to alter how people view their everyday surroundings by creating work that leaves these spaces touched by human vibrance. Revealing a new way to discover every day, carving out a reality that opens our eyes to the playground of life. 

We feel this is a platform to perpetuate the development of our artistic capacity, thus we will return better prepared to serve our local community with artistic diversity. 

What we need & What you get 

Based on estimated travel costs in Europe plus equipment expenses we have allocated $3400 as our total budget. We have also taken into consideration the current dollar to Euro exchange rate. 

  • Transportation w/Euro rail pass btwn 4 countries: €1100, equal to $1500
  • Lodging:  €900, equal to $1250
  • Digital camera to document all performances: $250 (we will purchase in US to avoid exchange rates) 
  • Portable sound system: $250 (we will purchase in US to avoid exchange rates) 
  • Costuming/dance gear equipped for unusual performance terrain: €100 equal to $135

Gifts for your thoughtful contribution include shout-outs, handwritten postcards, exclusive clips, collectible t-shirts, dance performance tickets, framed photography, and/or we bring the show to you! 

It takes a village!

The success of this project is born out of the help from many. Please take one minute and share this campaign with your family, friends and colleagues using the Indigogo Share tools. Together we can leave everyday environments touched by human vibrance. Thank you for your time, contribution and/or feedback.

story:
The zany adventures of an actress up for the role of a lifetime!!


ABOUT THE SHOW

Janet Cole Valdez is a Gold Record songwriter and award-winning musical theatre writer.  Deedee O’Malley is a multi-award winning quadruple threat:  singer, songwriter, actress and dancer.  Over the years, we have laughed ourselves silly (and cried ourselves crazy) over the strange adventures we’ve had in the entertainment industry.  We’ve decided to put the laughter and tears into a new musical, starring Deedee as New York actress Rita Donatella, and her desperate attempts to land a role in a Johnny Depp film! 


After finishing the script and songs, we brought in world class arranger and composer Bettie Ross to join our creative team!  Click on “GALLERY” above, to view creative team bios!


LOS ANGELES PREMIERE

We are absolutely thrilled to announce the birth of WAITING FOR JOHNNY DEPP at the Secret Rose Theatre in North Hollywood, in January, 2014!!!  Show dates are Friday through Sunday, January 10,11,12, 17,18,19, 24,25,26, with a special Premiere and After-party on Saturday, January 11th!



WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

 Our goal is to raise $12,500 to help with theatre rental, music charts, choreographer, scenic design, lighting design, costumes, set building, marketing/publicity and printing.  Our goal for the L.A. production is to build audience and industry support, and polish up our gem in preparation for Off-Broadway!!  We are offering an array of perks and incentives!!! Everything from show tickets to an Above-the-title Producer credit!!!  


We hope you enjoy browsing the site, and checking out the many ways you can participate in this exciting adventure!

story:
Who We Are

Jessica Blair is a Los Angeles based actor, with an unquenchable passion for theatre. She has received excellent reviews for her many appearances on LA stages. Jessica has appeared on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno in a number of sketch comedy pieces. She also appeared on Conan earlier this year. For more info visit: www.jessicablair.com

Bert Rotundo is an alumnus of The American Musical and Dramatic Academy in New York. He just finished a long successful run of David Mamet's "American Buffalo" and is very excited to be working with Jessica Blair on Frankie & Johnny.  Yoiu can view Bert's darker funnier side on his comedy troupe Generation Awesome's website.  Thank you to everyone who has helped us make this possible!  www.generation-awesome.com

The roles of Frankie and Johnny in "Frankie and Johnny in the Claire de Lune" are absolute dream roles for both actors. For years, both Jessica and Bert have imagined the day when they would get to play these roles onstage. For months, they have been rehearsing and working on the play. This amazing work is ready to be seen and shared with audiences.

By contributing to this campaign in any amount, you are helping to achieve a life-long dream for both of these fine artists. Any amount is a step in the direction of this goal.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal for this campaign is set at $3,755. With this amount we will achieve the following:

Paying the rights to Dramatists Play Service, Inc.

Paying our lighting and set designers.

Paying our show runner and stage manager.

Paying for our set, props and costume pieces that are needed.

Paying the rent for the theatre space, and therefore contributing to the Sidewalk Studio Theatre and the incomparable Sal Romeo.

Perks!

Hugs from Bert, flirty stares from Jesse.

Signed posters, free tickets and special thanks in the program.

Knowing that you are helping to make ART. 

What more could you ask for?!?

The difference your contribution will make:

Your contribution will allow us to share this incredible piece of theatre, during a time when it is so difficult to make artistic contributions to our community. The artistic community suffers when economic times are hard. But we NEED ART more than ever.

Both Bert and Jessica have produced and acted in numerous LA theatre pieces, performing to sold out houses on many occasions. In short, they are successful producers who know how to use a budget and make it go far, creating a great experience for all involved. They know what must go into an achievement of this size and are ready to BRING IT.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute money at this time, you can help us by spreading the word! Feel free to share our campaign with as many people as possible, or anyone with a passion for theatre and/or this wonderful play.

This link will take them to our Indiegogo Campaign:

 http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/285675/x/1823887

This link will take them to our Facebook page:

http://www.facebook.com/BLTdown?ref=ts&fref=ts

 

THANK YOU!!!!!

Jessica has appeared on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno in a number of sketch comedy pieces. She also appeared on Conan earlier this year. For more info visit: www.jessicablair.com
Bert Rotundo is an alumnus of The American Musical and Dramatic Academy in New York. He just finished a long successful run of David Mamet's "American Buffalo" and is very excited to be working with Jessica Blair on Frankie & Johnny.  Yoiu can view Bert's darker funnier side on his comedy troupe Generation Awesome's website.  Thank you to everyone who has helped us make this possible!  www.generation-awesome.com
The roles of Frankie and Johnny in "Frankie and Johnny in the Claire de Lune" are absolute dream roles for both actors. For years, both Jessica and Bert have imagined the day when they would get to play these roles onstage. For months, they have been rehearsing and working on the play. This amazing work is ready to be seen and shared with audiences.
By contributing to this campaign in any amount, you are helping to achieve a life-long dream for both of these fine artists. Any amount is a step in the direction of this goal.


What We Need & What You Get
Our goal for this campaign is set at $3,755. With this amount we will achieve the following:
Paying the rights to Dramatists Play Service, Inc.
Paying our lighting and set designers.
Paying our show runner and stage manager.
Paying for our set, props and costume pieces that are needed.
Paying the rent for the theatre space, and therefore contributing to the Sidewalk Studio Theatre and the incomparable Sal Romeo.
Perks!
Hugs from Bert, flirty stares from Jesse.
Signed posters, free tickets and special thanks in the program.
Knowing that you are helping to make ART. 
What more could you ask for?!?


The difference your contribution will make:
Your contribution will allow us to share this incredible piece of theatre, during a time when it is so difficult to make artistic contributions to our community. The artistic community suffers when economic times are hard. But we NEED ART more than ever.
Both Bert and Jessica have produced and acted in numerous LA theatre pieces, performing to sold out houses on many occasions. In short, they are successful producers who know how to use a budget and make it go far, creating a great experience for all involved. They know what must go into an achievement of this size and are ready to BRING IT.


Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you cannot contribute money at this time, you can help us by spreading the word! Feel free to share our campaign with as many people as possible, or anyone with a passion for theatre and/or this wonderful play.
This link will take them to our Indiegogo Campaign:
 http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/285675/x/1823887
This link will take them to our Facebook page:
http://www.facebook.com/BLTdown?ref=ts&fref=ts
 
THANK YOU!!!!!

story:
We’ve got three stellar projects on the docket but we need your help to make it happen.

Red Tape has dedicated this season to the idea of Empires Collapsing.  We are proud to present the work of Caryl Churchill, Ruth Margraff, and Young Jean Lee, three playwrights who understand the personal, public, and political effects of effects of a changing world. 

Each season Red Tape employs upwards of thirty artists and technicians to produce its award winning, critically acclaimed productions.  Your gift goes directly towards supporting these artists.  We are a not-for-profit organization and your gift is fully tax-deductible.  Please consider helping us put these plays out into the world. 

Season 9: Empires Collapsing

In December 2009, Greece admits its debts have reached 300 billion Euros- the highest in modern history. As the European Central Bank scrambles to keep Greece afloat, member countries experience crippling debt and the Euro-Zone crisis threatens to destroy the European Union. On December 18, 2010, a Tunisian activist lights himself on fire. This event instigates a wave of intense civil uprisings across the Middle East that comes to be known as The Arab Spring. On September 17, 2011, thousands of protesters descend on Zuccotti Park in New York’s financial district speaking out against wealth inequality and government corruption. The movement sweeps across the U.S. sparking ongoing protests nationwide.

Leaders forced from power. Alliances shaken. Populations that can’t be silenced. The powers, systems and structures that we trust, rely on and perpetuate are failing us. Empires are collapsing. 

The Skriker by Caryl Churchill
September 13 to October 20 
directed by Eric Hoff

An ancient shapeshifter, hell-bent on destroying the lives of two impressionable young mothers, unleashes an army of folklore creatures. THE SKRIKER is Churchill’s visionary exploration of global ecology made through gender, storytelling, distorted language and modern urban life. Red Tape Theatre presents THE SKRIKER, a haunting fairytale by Caryl Churchill, directed by Eric Hoff, director of The Inconvenience’s critically-acclaimed production of Hit the Wall.

Stadium Devildare 
by Ruth Margraff
January 17 to February 24 
directed by Karen Yates

“In ancient gladiator style, and based on polls from viewers like yourselves, we have relocated our most patriotic finale to one of America’s actual war zones. During these events you will witness five of your favorites battle to defeat each other for the highest honor.” Don’t miss the sporting event of the year as Reiko throws down with the boys for the ultimate prize, which has nothing to do with a trophy. Karen Yates directs this Chicago premiere that questions love, power and loyalty against the backdrop of world war.

Lear by Young Jean Lee
May 9 to June 23 
directed by James D Palmer

It’s King Lear. But there’s no King Lear. Experimental playwright and Doris Duke Artist Award winner Young Jean Lee has penned a whimsical and psychologically disturbing look at a world in which the pater familias is noticeably absent. The children are left to run the show but they must first overcome their anxiety and regret. As the story goes off the rails, Big Bird arrives to help us make sense of the madness. This is James D Palmer’s return to Lee’s work after CHURCH/PULLMAN, WA, one of Time Out Chicago’s Top Plays of 2011.

story:
"So... what is CO/LAB," you ask?

CO/LAB Theater Group provides individuals with disabilities a creative and social outlet through theater arts.  

Through weekly classes, CO/LAB works with over 45 individuals with developmental disabilities to create pieces of theater which culminate in a performance two times a year.  These classes are offered FREE to all participants.  Our off-site programming offers both one-time workshops and weekly residencies where CO/LAB teaching artists will travel to day-hab programs, residences, schools and other locations where there is a need for our program. 

The program facilitates a safe and judgment-free environment, encouraging participants to collaborate as an ensemble as well as discover their individual voice.  The organization promotes the building of confidence and self-esteem among participants and teaching artists alike.  CO/LAB seeks to honor and celebrate the individual in order to transcend the label of a disability.

Want to get an inside peek? Check out our video here! 

Send CO/LAB Theater Group to Seattle!!

During the month of January, two fabulous teaching artists are travelling cross-country to bring the magic of CO/LAB Theater Group from New York City to Seattle! Help us keep offer free programming to all participants.

Arielle and Chris (and other Seattle based volunteers) will teach a 4-week class concluding in a performance for family and friends.  There will also be single workshops in many different facilities around Seattle. 

"But where's my money going??"

Your contribution will help us travel to and around Seattle, pay our teaching artists, rent space, buy exciting supplies for class and, most importantly, affect the lives of so many individuals with developmental disabilities.

story:
Our Story

Sanyasi 2011
By Rabindranath Tagore 
Directed by Ameneh Bordi 
Original Music by Keith Adams 
Starring Evan Sanderson, Monica Flanagan, Tobin Mitnick, Yonaton Gebeyehu, Giselle Gastell, Jeremy Goren, Marion LeCoguic


We are bringing this beautiful play to Washington, DC and to New York City as part of the Capital Fringe Festival and FringeNYC. The play was written by artist/scholar/poet/musician Rabindranath Tagore, and we're bringing it back 2011 style with original music and explosive ensemble acting. 


The show is playing in NYC at The Kraine Theater (Venue #11) :
THU Aug 18 @ 5:30-6:15 
SAT Aug 20 @ 9:00-9:45 
FRI Aug 26 2:30-3:15 
SAT Aug 27 12-12:45 
SUN Aug 28 5:00-5:45
Tickets at: http://www.fringenyc.org/basic_page.php?ltr=S 


Some Reviews: 

"Minimal, yet lush. Simple, yet complex. It’s a mesmerizing experience." - DC Theatre Scene
http://dctheatrescene.com/2011/07/14/sanyasi/
"Bordi and her production team have removed any extraneous visual or aural input, creating an atmosphere where the text and talented players are allowed to speak for themselves." - DCist
http://dcist.com/2011/07/capital_fringe_review_sanyasi.php
"Sanyasi’s journey from zealot to skeptic comes off without a glitch" - Washington City Paper
http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/blogs/fringe/2011/07/13/hip-shot-sanyasi/
"The cast of this performance justifies the price of the Fringe ticket, especially Evan Sanderson" - MD Theater Guide
http://mdtheatreguide.com/2011/07/fringe-review-sanyasi/
"Bordi’s production of Sanyasi should certainly be on anyone’s short list of plays to see at this year’s Fringe Festival. Sanyasi is a true, beautiful and complex stand out from the normal offerings" - women around town
http://www.womanaroundtown.com/sections/playing-around/sanyasi-a-quest-for-enlightenment

What We Need & What You Get

We're looking to cover the costs associated with entering two (two!!) festivals - the entrance fees, production costs, and advertising expenses to get the show up and get people to see it. By supporting our show, you make our dreams come true, bring this play to life, and jump-start the careers of some amazing artists. PLUS we're assembling some great perks by the day. With a donation to the show you can get a sitar lesson, a genre-bending performance, and more ... If you can dream it, we can probably make it happen.


The DC Show: 

In DC: also staring Nikki Massoud, Nora Achrati, Amie Cazel, Thony Mena, Betsy Rosen, Vishal Vaidya

The show played in DC at Spooky Action Theater.

story:
What is Tomfoolery?

Tomfoolery Theatre Inc. began as a small group of young people with a passion for the performing arts & a desire to make musical theatre accessible to more people in all walks of life with all levels of experience. By rehearsing just twice a week and keeping costs and resources to a minimum, year after year we manage to create theatre that comes straight from our hearts and touches many others'.

Visit our website to view more.

What We Need & What You Get

Guardian Angel Parish in Allendale, NJ has been kind enough to house Tomfoolery Theatre free of charge since our inception in 2009. However, there are many other costs associated with putting on a musical:
  • Theatrical licensing fees
  • Rental materials
  • Insurance costs
  • Costumes
  • Scenery
  • Props
  • Marketing
  • A million little unforeseen disasters!
Every donation gets us closer to being able to cover one of these areas. Your support is what will make this show a success.
 
Thus, we want to recognize you for your contribution! See "Perks" for an array of ways we'd like to honor you for your generosity.

The Impact

Tomfoolery is not just a theatre group. After the devastating earthquake in 2010, we adopted The Rose Foundation of Haiti as our charity of choice. Since then, proceeds from each Tomfoolery production have gone toward aiding the impoverished people of Haiti. The more costs we can cover up front, the more we can ultimately give The Rose Foundation. Learn more about The Rose Foundation at rosefoundationofhaiti.org.

Other Ways You Can Help

Use the share buttons to tell your friends and family about us, pass around the link to your email contacts, or just talk about us! Spreading the word helps turn $1 into $1000 and we will be endlessly grateful for that.

You can also support us by coming out to our ZOMBIE PROM NIGHT FUNDRAISER DANCE, July 20th from 8-11 PM in the Guardian Angel Church Auditorium. Don your finest dresses, suits, and bloody green zombie goo! It’s prom night...ZOMBIE style. Enjoy an evening of music (“Thriller”, anyone?) dancing (Can you say “Monster Mash"?) refreshments (Don’t worry—it’s not brains) BYO-merriment, and priceless photo ops. You may even be named zombie-prom queen or king! Admission: $10 at the door.

You can also support us by coming to see "ZOMBIE PROM" August 3-5 at the Guardian Angel Church Auditiorium, 320 Franklin Turnpike in Allendale, NJ. Admission is free, but donations will be accepted at the door. Hope to see you at "the prom!"

story:
Who We Are

Artist Magnet was conceived by Founder & CEO David Mack.  A graduate of California Institute of the Arts and Cornell University, David has been active in theatre for over 15 years in Los Angeles, New York, Europe and the Caribbean as a performer, director, and producer.  He recently produced "Chocolate City," an intercultural showcase connecting Southern California artists of color to the Industry.  David is Chairman of LA County Supervisor Mark Ridley-Thomas' Empowerment Congress Arts & Culture Committee, Managing Director of Watts Village Theater Company, and serves on the Board of Directors of the Mutineer Theatre Company.

 

Artist Magnet's Board of Directors includes:

* Colin Chaston - Executive Director, Janski Productions Limited - http://www.facebook.com/colin.chaston

* Christopher Lackert (Chairman) - Attorney - http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=32506530

* Priscilla Kamahoro Nzabanita - School of Law, London - http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=617950590

* Stephanie Simon - Producer, Recording Artist, Editor - http://www.facebook.com/stephanie.simon.7524

* Emmitt Thrower - Producer/Founder, Wabi Sabi Productions, Inc. - http://www.facebook.com/emmitt.thrower

* Dio Tsitouras - Attorney - http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=404954

 

What Is Artist Magnet?

* Artist Magnet is the theatre revolution, connecting Artists through Productions and Venues Everywhere.

* Through Artist Magnet, Artists will be able to build as many customized hyperlinking theatre resumes as they like to save, print, and share with their co-workers, family and friends.

* Through Artists' hyperlinking resumes, users will have the ability to (1) connect to the resumes of Directors those Artists have worked with (2) connect to the pages of their past, current and upcoming Productions (which will link to the hyperlinking resumes of all the Artists who worked in those Productions) and (3) connect to Venues they've worked in (which will link to the pages of all past, current and upcoming Productions in those Venues) - it's like a 6 (or 3.74) degrees of separation for the theatre community.

 

Why Artist Magnet?

* The difference between Artist Magnet and other sites is here Artists will generate and control the content and flow of their information - wiki style.  No more waiting for approval from web developers or production companies.

* Most importantly, the site is FREE for the Artists.  Instead of paying tons of money (which most Artists can't afford) to huge production companies for the opportunity to be seen (much less to get a job), those same corporate interests will now invest in gaining access to Artists' information.

* By connecting Artists, Directors, Productions and Venues on one network, Artist Magnet will help build connections and strengthen relationships among Artists, their audiences and their communities.

 

 

When Is Artist Magnet Coming?

* It's already here (well, part of it) - go to www.artistmagnet.com to see what we've done so far; you can make a profile, share it with your friends, build, print and share your customized resumes.

* We need your help in taking Artist Magnet to the next level (including building the hyperlinking technology and connecting Artists through Productions and Venues everywhere).

* We need $5,000 in funding for our web development team to build the next phase of the site and keep our servers from crashing (due to the site's popularity) - if we don't reach our total goal, funds will be allocated to add the hyperlinking technology feature to resumes.

* Join the theatre revolution by contributing to Artist Magnet and you will get recognition on our Facebook page, shout-outs on the ArtMag radio show, Artist Magnet swag and more.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

* Go to www.artistmagnet.com make a profile and share with all your family, co-workers and friends via Facebook and email.

* Join the theatre revolution on our Facebook page ("like" Artist Magnet) - http://www.facebook.com/fansofartistmagnet

* Follow the theatre revolution on Twitter - http://twitter.com/artistmagnet

* Check out the site www.artistmagnet.com so far and give us your feedback, and use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word

 

Questions? email David Mack at david@artistmagnet.com

 

Thank you for your support for Artist Magnet...

story:
Everyone has a story from that day.  

 

Hope in Chaos is the extraordinary true story of one average New Yorker who found herself amongst the chaos of Ground Zero in the days immediately following September 11th.  Directed by Broadway's Holly-Anne Ruggiero, it will be performed in a special one-week run to coincide with the 10-year Memorial -  and will benefit the WTC Tribute and Visitor Center (www.tributeWTC.org).  The more we raise, the more we can give back. 


The "Power of Ten" Campaign:

 

Hope in Chaos is about action. It's about how each of us holds the potential for greatness through our choices, and - perhaps most importantly - it's about how many small acts of kindness add up to something both enormous and extraordinary.  From it's very beginnings this play was a journey that depended not just on a playwright, but on a team of peers, mentors, actors...dozens of people.  People who helped and worked and supported the project - for free - because it was something they believed in.  That journey so far has reinforced that message of the play - that little things add up.  That greatness is many people, not just one.


So here is the challenge.  As we secure our corporate sponsors for the New York benefit production, the success of the show - once again - depends on many.  While some of our resources will be donated, some we can only secure at discounted rates.  And so essentially we are asking you to be one of those many.  And we only want $10.  That's it.  The cost of your lunch (or your martini).  Because we know that little things add up, and we want you to help us prove it.

So click the button. 

We thank you. For your $10.  For reading this.  For forwarding this.  For sharing this.  And of course, for helping us prove the power of little things.


About the play:

Based on writer McCuen’s experience as a member of a New York State Senate-sponsored Disaster Task Force deep inside the chaos of Ground Zero, Hope in Chaos recounts her team’s experiences bearing witness to the tragedy, and their efforts to make sense of what has happened to their city. Then, ten years later, Hope is tracked down by a New York Times reporter who had interviewed her during her relief work. Hope reluctantly speaks about her struggle to reconcile those extraordinary experiences with her return to the ‘regular world’. She reveals why those days have haunted her for a decade, why every person is capable of greatness, and why that chaos is the closest she has ever felt to God.
story_txt:
Everyone has a story from that day.  
 
Hope in Chaos is the extraordinary true story of one average New Yorker who found herself amongst the chaos of Ground Zero in the days immediately following September 11th.  Directed by Broadway's Holly-Anne Ruggiero, it will be performed in a special one-week run to coincide with the 10-year Memorial -  and will benefit the WTC Tribute and Visitor Center (www.tributeWTC.org).  The more we raise, the more we can give back.  The "Power of Ten" Campaign:

Then, ten years later, Hope is tracked down by a New York Times reporter who had interviewed her during her relief work. Hope reluctantly speaks about her struggle to reconcile those extraordinary experiences with her return to the ‘regular world’. She reveals why those days have haunted her for a decade, why every person is capable of greatness, and why that chaos is the closest she has ever felt to God.

story:
Our Story

Two Seul Productions is a Montreal based theatre Company created by Braulio Elicer (Centaur’s Comedy of Errors, Paradise by the River; winner of the CETM’s Le Spotlight 2008, Dome Graduate) David Sklar (Persephone’s Henry V, Concordia Theatre’s Scorched, Assistant Director at the Stratford Shakespeare School) and Nico Racicot(NTS Grad-2012) These actors decided to rejoin forces after their successfully sold-out and 2008 Mecca Nominated Fringe Show, This Hour Has 88 Years.


This year they are presenting "Crazy Love", a one-act play written and directed by David Sklar and winner of the 2010 Kit Brennan Award for Best Play at the Montreal Fringe Festival at MainLine Theatre.  


BASED ON A TRUE STORY   

 A funny, smart and scary play - it's a roller coaster ride about one of those 

relationships you always knew you should get out of, once and for all, but never got around to.  After this, you won't forget” –Kit Brennan 



What is the play about?

Leo has just been freed from a rocky relationship and is set to restart his life with his new love. That is until his ex, Rebecca, shows up unannounced to reveal that she is pregnant with their “love” child. Tension ensues, past grudges are rehashed and both parties stop at nothing to win back their life, even at the expense of their furniture. Both are forced to take a deep and honest look into each other’s hearts. Dead baby jokes included!

  


The Impact

Any generous donation will help cover the costs of our production and expenses.  

We are aiming to break even so we don't have to sell blood once the show is over to pay for rent!


What We Need & What You Get

What We Need:


  • 750$ Fringe Application Fee
  • 100$ Venue 
  • 300$ Graphic designer  
  • 100$ Props, Set and Costumes
  • 250$ New Promotional Materials 


What You Get:

Besides the knowledge that you are helping promote local indie theatre and it's artists, we have a bunch of cool "thank yous" to anyone who donates.  

Other Ways You Can Help


Please help us spread the word about our Indiegogo campaign!

- Come and see Crazy love 

- Invite your friends to see Crazy Love.

- Join the event on Facebook 

- Spread the word!


Venue #6: Mainline Theatre 3997 St-Laurent

Saturday June 11th at 24h00 Volunteer Show

Sunday June 12th at 19h00

Wednesday June 15th at 20h15min

Friday June 17th at 13h30min

Saturday June 18th at 23h45min

Sunday June 19th 13h30min

Tickets: $10 Regular, $8 Students and Baby Mama’s

 

Fringe Box Office and Hotline: 514.849.FEST www.montrealfringe.ca

For more information, contact David Sklar at 514-992-4490 or d.sklar@videotron.ca

story:
The Core Ensemble presents a weekend of two one-act solo performances: Clara Hayes' "Patience is Understanding" and Spencer Funk's "The Egg Show". We go from the twisted trauma-drama of a 14 year old girl to a show about potential from the point of view of a young boy, an egg, and a radio show host. In order to get these shows on their feet, we are looking to raise $500 to supply props, set pieces, costumes, posters and press, as well as provide payment to our technical crew. These shows are about a year in progress, Patience having begun development in a workshop last summer and The Egg Show beginning soon after. This dynamic duo of actor/writer/director/students has been supported by their awesome co-director, Michael Dreger, and a technical team including Huntington Filson and Matt Ray, all students or alum of Cornish College of the Arts. Together we accomplished a successful staged reading this past spring and hope to be able to share this show many times over with your help! Come see us perform for free September 3rd-5th in 102 (the black box space) at Cornish College of the Arts' main campus center! More information will also become available on our facebook page.
Thank you for your support!!

story:
Seventh Land Theatre presents: 

The Master and Margarita - a fairy tale of Dublin


Love, poverty, madness, and magic...


Seventh Land? Master and Margarita? What's that all about?

Seventh Land is a newly-founded theatre company based in Dublin. Our mission and our vision is to create international theatre for a multicultural audience, with casts that reflect the diversity of modern-day Dublin, telling stories that have universal impact. For our first production we're going to bring Mikhail Bulgakov's classic novel The Master and Margarita alive in a new, exciting version devised by Aggie Bryla. Transporting Bulgakov's characters to present-day Dublin, The Master and Margarita: a fairy tale of Dublin weaves its spell through movement and dance, featuring original music by Eamonn Murphy and Gabriel Caetano.

Sounds cool! Why the campaign?

We're new and hungry, and we want our first production to be special. So we're asking for €1000 to make this production happen. This will cover roughly half of our total budget and will help us to pay for props, costumes, insurance, and hire of rehearsal space, as well as making sure that we can get the word out to as many people as possible.

And why should I donate?

In exchange for your donation -- however big, however small -- you get the knowledge that you're contributing towards the début of a new theatre company, and a theatrical experience unlike any other.

And if that's not enough, there are unique perks for those who donate more than certain amounts! For donations above €25, you get a guaranteed pre-sold ticket; for those especially generous donors who give €100, we will reserve a privileged chair in the corner of a rehearsal room so that you can watch the actors and director at work as they bring the show to life.

I'd love to help, but I can't donate...

No problem -- you can still help us by getting the word out! Tell your friends about this show and about this campaign. Talk about it on Twitter or Facebook or Google+, or better yet, face to face. Word of mouth will help us as much as money!

I do want to donate, but I don't like these perks!

That's great too! If you want to give an amount that comes with a perk, but you don't fancy the perk (or can't use it), just let us know. We are grateful for all donations, and (like all donors) you will receive a heartfelt personal thank-you. If you'd like a perk of equal value, we'll discuss it with you and come up with an alternative to suit your needs.

story:
[6/21 IMPORTANT: Update on Glowstick Project]

The glowstick warehouse has pushed up the payment deadline. They originally said that they needed it by the end of July for me to get them by end of September. However, they emailed me on Thursday to say that they needed extra time to get the order gathered and shipped (also to account for customs just in case). Thus, they moved my payment deadline to 6/24.

Now as you know, the goal for 4000 glowsticks is roughly $2600.
As of right now, we have $1125, and I'm not sure how confident I can be in making up that $1500 gap.


So this is what I'm going to do:
-Cut initial glowstick order down to 2000, people get ONE instead of TWO (which leaves no room for screwups so please read the instruction slip on when to crack them)
-The price for 2000 is $1,434.52, which I believe we can gather.
-However, neither the fund goal nor deadline can be changed on Indiegogo, so it'll still show $2633 til July 18.
-In case we exceed $1,434.52, I will use the excess money on more glowsticks (either from wholesellers or in small batches from stores, depending on how much we get)


TLDR:

+4000 glowsticks -> 2000 glowsticks
+All money gathered is still going to the project.


Short Summary

On October 5, 2014,
Morning Musume '14 will grace American fans with a solo concert in New York City's Best Buy Theater!

And unless you can make it to Japan at the end of this year, this will likely be your last chance to experience this iconic stage in Morning Musume's history!

Michishige Sayumi, the current leader of Morning Musume '14, joined the group over a decade ago, in 2003.
Through 11 years of hard work, camaraderie, laughter, pain, and tears, she has contributed an unprecedented amount to the group, sculpting it into what we know and love today.

At the end of this year's Autumn tour, she will be graduating.

To show our gratitude for everything she's gave us, and gave the group,
I want to make the venue glow pink for her.

With 4000 ultra bright pink glowsticks, we can give 2 per person to light up the venue.
In past US Hello! Project concerts, I've noticed that at least half of the crowd has been dark. And even though more people have been investing in personal glowsticks or kingblades recently, this project will ensure one uniform pink glow that EVERYONE will be a part of.

Even just a small donation will really contribute to the project,
so let's show our love in the pinkest, brightest way we can imagine!

What We Need

4000 ultra bright glowsticks + shipping: $2623.00
2000 rubber bands: $10.00

Everything else, including Indiegogo fees, instruction papers/slips, transport, and manual labor, I, along with volunteers, will be taking care of.

The Impact

A great big heartfelt smile? Some tears?
I don't know what her reaction will be but, we just want to show Sayumi how much we appreciate and love her, right? :)

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word.
Forums, twitter, tumblr, facebook, whatever social media sites you use.
Some people may not be able to make the concert, but might still want to donate to this project.

So please, share this page wherever you can.

story:
The Gaiety School of Acting class of 2014 need your help, we are fundraising for our final graduation play running June 23rd - 28th in Smock Alley Theatre, written and directed by Chris Edmund. 

Chris commenced his career in London where he directed for the Gate Theatre Notting Hill, the Riverside Studios, the Kings Head and New End Theatres. He also directed for regional companies including the Crucible, Sheffield. He has also worked in the United States as Director and Teacher. In his Directing career he has directed over 150 productions from new writing to the classical repertoire. 


In 1985 he moved to Australia to join the Western Australian Academy of Performing Arts (WAAPA), which has produced many of the dynamic Australian actors who have established high profile careers, here and overseas. Actors trained with Chris include Hugh Jackman, Jai Courtney and Frances O’Connor.  He has been both Dramaturg and Director for the Australian National Playwrights Conference

Previous reviews for his work "Stalin's Orchard" include - 

"Yet again, Chris Edmund has demonstrated impressively and unambiguously that, in theatrical terms, he is a master when it comes to the evocation of political terror. The prime focus here is two men with almost limitless political power and who, in different ways, have callously misruled over a great people. " 


"Stalin’s Orchard deserves an international audience."


"...Taut, witty, intelligent, and emotionally compelling with complex and fascinating characters."
--Hugh Jackman.

http://www.chrisedmund.net


Chris has been workshopping and devising with class of 2014 on an new exciting production, however, in order to fund the following requirements expected when producing a play,

we need your help - 

Production team: we need a lighting designer, sound designer, director, writer, stage manager and various other important people to get our production looking and sounding the best it can, we also need set, costume, venue hire, PR and more - this all doesn't come cheap, and as we are relying on ourselves to fundraise it means we have no government help, no grants, just us and our determination to deliver a professional production of the highest standard. 


Over the past year and a half we have had pub quizzes, sponsored cycle, fun days with kids, cinema nights for adults, baking, selling various prizes we had donated, improv comedy night, live shows of poetry and singing, halloween events, christmas events now we need a final push with your help


WHY? 


With funding at an all time low for the arts, its imperative that we actors, writers, producers and anyone with a passion for the arts are able and willing to give time and dedication not just to finding work, but creating their own work when there's nothing else. We need your support, by sticking together and supporting each other we can make amazing new work. This is our push out to the real world. We want to show what we've been doing for two years and we want you to be proud to have donated to us. 

Other Ways You Can Help


If you haven't got the funds to help but still want to donate, we are always welcoming spot prizes we can raffle off, and we are looking for advertising in our programme.

Please feel free to ring the Gaiety School of Acting  on - (01) 6799277
http://gaietyschool.com

story:
Aulò teatro goes to Serbia!

Charivari è uno spettacolo della piccola compagnia teatrale indipendente padovana Aulò teatro.
Charivari è stato selezionato per partecipare al festival internazionale di arte OFF PatosOFFiranje (www.patos.org.rs).
La produzione di Charivari è stata totalmente autofinanziata.
Charivari occupa un furgone a 9 posti, inclusi 5 attori, una regista, e tutto il materiale di scena.
Padova dista 843 km da Smederevo, Serbia.

Come puoi aiutarci

Ci serve una mano per arrivare in Serbia!
Il festival è ad entrata libera e può solo farsi carico del vitto e alloggio per due giorni.
Dobbiamo affittare un furgone 9 posti e pagarci benzina e pedaggi.
Nel caso non si raggiungesse il budget previsto, quanto raccolto andrebbe comunque a tamponare la nostra spesa, perché noi in Serbia vogliamo andarci! Si tratta di una ottima occasione per farci apprezzare in un contesto internazionale e tessere importanti collaborazioni.

Perché aiutarci

Perché c'è uno spettacolo pronto che deve solo arrivare in scena!

Perché abbiamo una lettera ufficiale di invito a disposizione!

Perché è una occasione importante!

Perché per potere fare arte in Italia c'è bisogno dell'appoggio concreto di tutti!

Come aiutarci


Il contributo spese, anche minimo, è la via più semplice, ma anche qualche consiglio su furgoni economici in affitto può essere importante.

Sicuramente il passaparola è un segno che apprezziamo molto.

Charivari è stato selezionato per partecipare al festival internazionale di arte OFF PatosOFFiranje (www.patos.org.rs).La produzione di Charivari è stata totalmente autofinanziata.Charivari occupa un furgone a 9 posti, inclusi 5 attori, una regista, e tutto il materiale di scena.Padova dista 843 km da Smederevo, Serbia.  Come puoi aiutarci
Ci serve una mano per arrivare in Serbia! Il festival è ad entrata libera e può solo farsi carico del vitto e alloggio per due giorni.Dobbiamo affittare un furgone 9 posti e pagarci benzina e pedaggi. Nel caso non si raggiungesse il budget previsto, quanto raccolto andrebbe comunque a tamponare la nostra spesa, perché noi in Serbia vogliamo andarci! Si tratta di una ottima occasione per farci apprezzare in un contesto internazionale e tessere importanti collaborazioni.  Perché aiutarciPerché c'è uno spettacolo pronto che deve solo arrivare in scena!Perché abbiamo una lettera ufficiale di invito a disposizione!Perché è una occasione importante!  Perché per potere fare arte in Italia c'è bisogno dell'appoggio concreto di tutti!Come aiutarci
Il contributo spese, anche minimo, è la via più semplice, ma anche qualche consiglio su furgoni economici in affitto può essere importante.Sicuramente il passaparola è un segno che apprezziamo molto.

story:
OUR STORY

Who gets to be onstage?

Artistic Directors Jenny Reed and Samantha Sheppard met as students in the University of San Francisco’s Performing Arts & Social Justice program. There, they were encouraged to think critically about the creative process, and they took up a regular line of inquiry: Who “gets” to make performance? Where is it made? Who accesses those spaces? Whose stories are being told? Jenny and Sam have been making work independently and collaboratively for nine years, and the foundation of The Pack circles back to those early questions. It is just as important to make a beautiful, transportive show as it is to interrogate why, how, and with whom we choose to make theatre.

The Play

A renowned neuroscientist suffers a stroke.
An old house creaks in the wind.
Something in the universe answers faintly…

False Stars is a darkly humorous modern take on the Southern Gothic drama.When groundbreaking neuroscientist Larry Neils has a stroke, his near-death experience lures an unlikely group of characters to his home in Oxford, Mississippi. Falsely-assumed identities collide with covert queer love triangles; strained family tensions battle grief, love, scientific legacy, and a few old ghosts. With its blend of realism and the supernatural, False Stars unravels a timely tale about six individuals trying to find fulfillment in a society that can’t seem to recognize them.

 

INNOVATING THE PROCESS

The Pack’s formula

  1. Choose a theme: (in this case, our cultural obsession with “genius”)
  2. Commission a playwright: (Nora Sørena Casey)
  3. Cast the show: (performers Felipe Bonilla, Marissa Carpio, Blaze Ferrer, Ian Fields-Stewart, Juliana Forsberg-Lary, Franco Gonzalez)
  4. Assemble a design team: Kate Marvin (sound), Elizabeth Mak (lights), and Chika Shimizu (set, props, and costume)
  5. Workshop ideas: The entire group of collaborators are involved in the development process from the beginning
  6. The playwright writes the script
  7. We stage the play!

 

WHERE YOU COME IN

We are raising $7,500 to pay our artists and cover production costs.

False Stars Budget

Artistic Compensation: $6,000

Sound: $225

Lights: $275

Set/Props: $1000

 

CALL TO ACTION

The Pack has developed a process that creates opportunities for more diversity in storytelling. By investing in making theater with and for new and varied voices, we hope to carve out space for passionate writers, performers, and designers.

While New York City is taking some steps to improve diversity in theater, we recognize that institutional resources are not always (or reliably) available to young artists making new work. Join us in the movement to build a more equitable theater industry!​

Here is what the "Ethnic Representation of New York City Stages" report says about diversity in casting in the 2015–2016 season:

  • 17% of all roles went to black actors
  • 3% of all roles went to Latinx actors
  • 9% of all roles went to Asian American actors
  • 1% of all roles went to all other minorities (including disabled)

According to The Kilroys' List – a gender parity initiative to end the "systematic underrepresentation of female and trans* playwrights" in the American theater industry, in NYC:

  • 2013-2014 there were no new plays by women on Broadway
  • 25% of all plays are by women in NYC
  • Of those plays, 15.7% are by women of color
 
 

Other Ways You Can Help

As working artists with day/night/weekend jobs, we understand that not everyone will be able to offer financial support. Here are some other ways you can help:

  • You can “like” The Pack on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. Engage with us in conversations and news about #FalseStars, #ThePackTheater, #GenderParity, #QueerTheater and #RepresentationMatters

  • Buy tickets to our show HERE!
     

THANK YOU SO MUCH!

 

P.S. A BIG thank you to Adam Glucksman and Giant Spark  for making our beautiful video, graphics, and poster image; to our producer Allie Pinel for your guidance and support; and to Corkscrew Theater Festival for believing in our vision.

story:
Our much anticipated Spring Concert is right around the corner! The concert will showcase the great work and dedication of our students, and will be a fantastic show that sells out weeks in advance. However, ticket sales and participation fees only cover 50% of the many costs associated with making the Spring Concert a reality.

We need your support to help make this year's production the best yet! Make a one-time, tax-deductible donation to our Spring Concert Campaign. In return, you'll get some unique benefits and perks!


What We Need & What You Get

This campaign will support all production expenses ranging from costumes, set design, and lighting equipment to everything else that happens behind-the-scenes, including the production crew and music rights.

For as little as $25, you'll be supporting the production AND making your star feel super special with awesome perks like program ads, reserved seats, and more... check on the right for details!

Spread the Word!

If you've already donated (thank you!) or are unable to do so right now, there are still other ways you can pitch in. Click on any of the sharing options at the top of the page and help spread the word to your friends and family!

Questions? Email cathy@americandance.org
