story:
I’m sure like me,  you’ve  been feeling helpless about the way our current administration has been treating immigrants and refugees, in particular the separation of children from their parents at the border.  When I saw a CNN report about a Jewish women helping to hide a Latina mom and her two daughters from ICE after her husband was suddenly deported, it immediately brought me to the play “The Diary of Anne Frank”.  Then I thought, what if I directed the play word-for-word, but cast everyone in the attic with LatinX actors.  So along with Producers Anne Kathryn Parma and Tracey Rooney and our genius casting director Julie Gale, we embarked on putting this big production together.  Little did we realize that our 50 seat show would cause such a world wide commotion. Once people saw that we were NOT changing the Nazis to ICE agents and that we were honoring the story of Anne Frank, just told through different eyes, the tide turned and we ended up with two successful runs in Fall 2018 and Jan/Feb 2019.  We then were invited to bring our show to a 250 seat theatre in Beverly Hills, CA for 2 special performances in Oct 2019 and 5 in Vancouver at the Chutzpah Festival in Nov 2019. With the recent death of the teen boy in a detention center, we know that we have to keep this production, with this cast alive.  

What We Need & What You Get

With the financial help we receive, we'd be able to lower ticket prices to student groups. School groups have been a priority for us after learning that “The Diary of Anne Frank”is no longer required reading in California Public Schools. We would like to keep the show going around the United States, reaching out to communities and school groups for performances. Our goal is to spark discussion and change where we can. 

If you care about this issue, please share our campaign and help us heal as a nation.  Together we can truly embrace the iconic saying – NEVER AGAIN!

story:
The Unknown Artists Present...
Gearhead and the Realbot

A Space Odyssey Hoedown by BOB SIMPSON
Directed by MATT RITCHEY

The Unknown Artists are proud to present a brand new play written by our very own Bob Simpson. Over the past year and a half, we have produced four fully staged productions: Edgar, the West Coast Premiere of the original musical Right Together, Left Together, our 3.2.1. Festival consisting of original and established one-act plays, and Lysistrata, A Re-Imagining. The Unknown Artists’ mission is to provide opportunities for talented, unknown individuals to thrive on a stage, enabling them to show off their gifts of music, acting, dance, comedy, film, and all categories of art. 

After the success of the above mentioned productions, we know how instrumental our supporters are to achieving the highest production level possible. The funds raised during this campaign will go directly to necessities such as theater rental, promotional materials, rehearsal space, costumes, props, and... wait for it... booze for intermission. Yes, booze for intermission. Our new location in Hollywood is pro-booze. Pro. Booze. (Check out our perks in the right sidebar!) Thank you in advance for your donation!

Where can I find out more about the show, you ask? Check out details below!

FEBRUARY 21 - MARCH 8, 2014
Fridays at 8pm
Saturdays at 7pm & 10pm

DORIE THEATRE at THE COMPLEX
6476 Santa Monica Blvd
Los Angeles, CA 90038

TICKETS -$20

About the Show:

Gearhead and the Realbot is a wacky, science fiction comedy and playwright Bob Simpson’s homage to awesome, terrible, and terribly awesome science fiction films and television shows, particularly from the 1950s and 60s.  The play takes us through a day in the lives of the crew of the spaceship, Pomegranate Fizz, as they explore the galaxy and try desperately to not blow themselves up.  The show contains a smorgasbord of goofy characters, from the inept and overly-masculine captain, to the shell-shocked first mate, to the gentle but probably an axe murderer doctor, to her sweet and annoying son…you know, the one the producers put on the show to appeal to kids but actually appeals to your carnal desire to see a child run over by an Abrams tank.  And don’t forget the villain, whose desire to take over the universe is rooted in the fact that…I don’t know…it’s Wednesday?  Lots of laughs, lots of cool special effects, and a sock puppet…Gearhead and the Realbothas it all. 

PRODUCTION TEAM
DIRECTOR- Matt Ritchey
PLAYWRIGHT- Bob Simpson
ASSISTANT DIRECTOR- Travis James Riner
LIGHTING DESIGN- Jeff Brewer
SET DESIGN/PUPPET DESIGN- Cody Clark
GRAPHIC DESIGN- Katrina Rennells
SOUND DESIGN- Martyn Tyler
COSTUME DESIGN- Meghan Allison
STAGE MANAGER- Jim Niedzialkowski 

CAST MEMBERS
HOWARD BATCH, GEARHEAD- Tory N. Thompson
MARIGOLD, THE REALBOT- Amy Bartlett
PROFESSOR ZELLIUS ZEE - Andy Kenareki
LIEUTENANT VARLA SOLIN- Emily Clark
CAPTAIN HAWK MANTHICKET- Schoen Hodges
CORPORAL HOLLY HENDERSON- Tiffany Brain
THE DOC- Sabrina Carmichael
TIMMY- Paul Reese
ENSIGN ANCILLARY KARACTER- Cody Clark
COMMANDER BURT PHILBIN- John Ross Clark*
HONK/FOOD FABRICATOR- Travis James Riner
GOD- Katrina Rennells

*Member of Actors' Equity Association, The Union of Professional Actors and Stage Managers in the United States.

Founded in 2007 by Emily Clark and Pamela Eberhardt, the Unknown Artists search far and wide for an explosive amount of talent that is of a specific, unheard of, untraveled artistry. Our goal: to make Unknown Artists KNOWN.

The Unknown Artists is a bi-coastal company based in both New York City and Los Angeles.

Parent company of PLAY CLUB WEST

http://iamanunknownartist.wordpress.com

story:
Hot Season

 by Evan Mueller

Directed by, Kevin Kittle

In the not too distant future, a small group of friends and family escape the city for the summer, and head to an isolated cabin in the woods.  We soon realize this is no pleasure trip, this is a true escape. And as the summer months crawl by it becomes harder to stay happy and entertained, harder to distract themselves from what they’ve left behind.

Part comedy, part science fiction – and a dash of horror – Hot Season explores the relationships that connect friends and family, and how the power of nature can challenge, strain, and ultimately reaffirm those relationships.

June 13-28, 2014; The Black Box Theatre at The Sheen Center

Hot Season represents the first time Strange Sun has worked with a play from readings, through workshop and then into full production.  This production is the culmination of almost one year of work on this piece with the director, author and even some of the actors.  The play has grown and changed as it journeyed from reading, to table work and finally to full production.  We are thrilled to bring this play to fruition.

The Strange Sun Theater Company 

"In the theater...there is a kind of Strange Sun, a light of abnormal intensity by which it seems that the difficult and even the impossible suddenly become our normal element" -Antonin Artaud

Our Mission is to create theater and tell stories that illuminate our humanity through a shared experience of the magic of theater.

The Vision of Strange Sun Theater:

Theater is magic in its most basic form, with the power to reveal the complex difficulties and unexpected joys of all our lives.

We believe the dialogue among artist, audience and community, shared in the spirit of simplicity and truth, has the power to evoke this magic.

Now more than ever we are compelled to call upon the magic of theater by bringing the finest theater artists together with dynamic audiences to focus this strange sun upon our shared humanity, releasing us from the ordinary, igniting us with the power of possibility.

Strange Sun Co-Founders: Jessica Bashline & Evan Mueller
Board of Directors:
Gary Bernstein
Suzanne Fine
Sotirios Keros
Brie Turoff Mueller
DiAna Pisarri
Marianne Zarcadoolas

The Hot Season Family:
Carlos Aguilar
Travis Boatwright
Kat Gavornik
Kristen Harlow
Kevin Kittle
Ryder McNair
Michael Mihm
Kenzie Nothnagel
Mitch Ost
Heather Lupton Rasche
Michael Satow
Erica Twiss
Benjamin Williams

story:
Help Us Meet Our Match + Challenge!

Circus Center has received a very special gift this year: a group of anonymous donors has pledged to match 1:1 every dollar we raise -- up to $5,000. Plus, if we make our $5,000 goal with this campaign, our donors will contribute an additional $5,000! Read on to find out why Circus Center needs these funds, and what your gifts mean for our mission.

Spread the Joy of Circus

Circus Center’s mission is to inspire passion for the circus arts, and with the support of donors like you, we bring that mission to people in the San Francisco Bay Area who otherwise wouldn’t know about it or couldn’t afford it. We do this in two main ways:

Scholarships for Children from Underserved Communities. Circus Center offers young people both top-quality, pre-professional-style training in the circus arts and a fun, recreational circus day camp. Each year, we offer thousands of dollars in need-based financial aid, opening the world of circus to low-income kids and their families.

Outreach Performances. We take the joy of circus to the people! Our instructors, students, and youth program trainees perform for free many times a year at local schools, festivals, fairs, and community events. It's our gift to this city that we love.


What Your Donation Means

Your donations make it possible for us to reach thousands of people every year, regardless of their background or financial circumstances. Every dollar counts, and it doesn’t take much to make a big difference:

  • $50 supports the equivalent of a day of small-group training for one of our youth program scholarship recipients

  • $100 pays for a cost like transporting equipment to one of our outreach performances

  • $250 pays for things like lighting equipment needed to put on one of our free shows

  • $500 covers the cost of sending a low-income kid to circus day camp including aftercare (essential for working parents)

Make an Impact with Your Gift

Our unique "match + challenge" grant means that every dollar you give will be AT LEAST doubled, and hopefully tripled! We're raising funds for this campaign in many ways. When we reach our total campaign goal of $25,000, our youth scholarship program will be fully funded, so we won’t have to turn away talented kids for lack of resources. We also will be able to increase the production quality of our current free outreach performances, plus start a new, free circus cabaret series for local audiences. What a return to the local arts community from your investment!

Your gift will also have another impact: generosity is contagious. When you make a tax-deductible gift today, you will encourage others to do the same. The snowball effect can start with you!

Tell Your Friends

Spreading the word is as valuable as donating. Make sure your friends and family know about this campaign by using the IndieGoGo social media tools to share on your networks.

About Circus Center

Circus Center is the oldest and largest circus training and performing arts center on the West Coast. We were originally founded as the training arm of San Francisco’s legendary Pickle Family Circus. Today, the school offers both recreational and professional training with a world-renowned team of instructors and coaches. We are proud to offer training and performance opportunities to hundreds of children, teens, and adults in clowning and physical comedy, acrobatics, aerial performance, flying trapeze and more.

All Because Of YOU

We can't thank you enough for your interest and support. Our community always steps up to support important causes: we just held a benefit performance that raised thousands of dollars for poor kids in post-civil war El Salvador. Plus, last year as part of the Make-a-Wish program, we were the training ground for SFBatKid!

This campaign is a way to provide opportunities for kids in our own backyard. Together, we can bring the joy of the circus arts to a new generation of San Franciscans. Thank you, thank you, thank you!
story_txt:
Help Us Meet Our Match + Challenge!Circus Center has received a very special gift this year: a group of anonymous donors has pledged to match 1:1 every dollar we raise -- up to $5,000. Plus, if we make our $5,000 goal with this campaign, our donors will contribute an additional $5,000! Read on to find out why Circus Center needs these funds, and what your gifts mean for our mission.Spread the Joy of CircusCircus Center’s mission is to inspire passion for the circus arts, and with the support of donors like you, we bring that mission to people in the San Francisco Bay Area who otherwise wouldn’t know about it or couldn’t afford it. We do this in two main ways:Scholarships for Children from Underserved Communities. Circus Center offers young people both top-quality, pre-professional-style training in the circus arts and a fun, recreational circus day camp. Each year, we offer thousands of dollars in need-based financial aid, opening the world of circus to low-income kids and their families.Outreach Performances. We take the joy of circus to the people! Our instructors, students, and youth program trainees perform for free many times a year at local schools, festivals, fairs, and community events. It's our gift to this city that we love.What Your Donation MeansYour donations make it possible for us to reach thousands of people every year, regardless of their background or financial circumstances. Every dollar counts, and it doesn’t take much to make a big difference:
$50 supports the equivalent of a day of small-group training for one of our youth program scholarship recipients
$100 pays for a cost like transporting equipment to one of our outreach performances
$250 pays for things like lighting equipment needed to put on one of our free shows
$500 covers the cost of sending a low-income kid to circus day camp including aftercare (essential for working parents)
Make an Impact with Your GiftOur unique "match + challenge" grant means that every dollar you give will be AT LEAST doubled, and hopefully tripled! We're raising funds for this campaign in many ways. When we reach our total campaign goal of $25,000, our youth scholarship program will be fully funded, so we won’t have to turn away talented kids for lack of resources. We also will be able to increase the production quality of our current free outreach performances, plus start a new, free circus cabaret series for local audiences. What a return to the local arts community from your investment!Your gift will also have another impact: generosity is contagious. When you make a tax-deductible gift today, you will encourage others to do the same. The snowball effect can start with you!Tell Your FriendsSpreading the word is as valuable as donating. Make sure your friends and family know about this campaign by using the IndieGoGo social media tools to share on your networks.About Circus CenterCircus Center is the oldest and largest circus training and performing arts center on the West Coast. We were originally founded as the training arm of San Francisco’s legendary Pickle Family Circus. Today, the school offers both recreational and professional training with a world-renowned team of instructors and coaches. We are proud to offer training and performance opportunities to hundreds of children, teens, and adults in clowning and physical comedy, acrobatics, aerial performance, flying trapeze and more.All Because Of YOUWe can't thank you enough for your interest and support. Our community always steps up to support important causes: we just held a benefit performance that raised thousands of dollars for poor kids in post-civil war El Salvador. Plus, last year as part of the Make-a-Wish program, we were the training ground for SFBatKid!This campaign is a way to provide opportunities for kids in our own backyard. Together, we can bring the joy of the circus arts to a new generation of San Franciscans. Thank you, thank you, thank you!

story:
Overview:

There Is A Field is a play about Aseel Asleh, a 17-year old Palestinian citizen of Israel killed by police in October 2000. Based on interviews and primary sources collected over fourteen years, the play offers a uniquely personal lens for understanding inequality as the root of state violence and impunity. Audiences throughout the United States will find particular resonance with themes raised by Aseel’s life and murder, and post-play discussions and actions will create space to further explore connections and build solidarity across universal struggles for liberation and equality.

LAND DAY TOUR: March-April 2016, in universities across the US.

All funds raised in this campaign will go towards producing There Is A Field.

About the play:

As the Second Intifada erupted in the West Bank and Gaza, demonstrations also began in Palestinian villages and towns inside Israel. In October 2000, Israeli forces killed twelve unarmed Palestinian citizens of Israel in these demonstrations. The youngest of those killed was a 17-year old boy named Aseel Asleh. There Is A Field, written by Jen Marlowe, is a play about Aseel’s life and his killing, through the perspective of his older sister, Nardeen.

Through Nardeen’s struggle to cope with the murder of her brother, the play also addresses the larger struggle facing Palestinians inside Israel.

About the Land Day Tour

The tour coincides with the 40-year anniversary of Land Day, an annual commemoration of land dispossession and the killings of Palestinian citizens of Israel in 1976. There Is A Field will play an important role in exposing and highlighting the issues facing Palestinian citizens of Israel, and connecting the dots between injustices facing Palestinian inside Israel and those facing Palestinians in the West Bank, Jerusalem and Gaza. 

Through post-play discussions and activities, the issues exposed in the play will also be connected to the crisis of state violence and racial injustice experienced by Black Americans in the US. The Land Day Tour will also go to several historically black colleges and universities, and will be a space to build and support Black-Palestinian solidarity, as well as solidarity with other liberation, equality, and human rights struggles.

The team:

The play is being produced in partnership with the following organizations: Adalah, 50 Shades of Black,  donkeysaddle projects, US Campaign to End the Israeli Occupation, Students for Justice in Palestine, Jewish Voice for Peace, Code Pink. 

Playwright/producer: Jen Marlowe

Director/dramaturg: Noelle Ghoussaini

Tour Manager: Amer Shurrab

If our fundraising exceeds our goal, we will expand the tour!

For more information: www.thereisafield.info and www.donkeysaddle.org

story:
Who are we?

Aulos Productions is a multi award-winning Edinburgh theatre group, led by director, writer and youth theatre tutor James Beagon.

We have been operating in Edinburgh since 2014, producing award-winning and award-nominated shows including:

  • Gobland for the Goblins!  (Winner of Best Children's Show, Edinburgh Fringe 2017 - The Derek Awards; ★★★★★ , Families Edinburgh)
  • First Class (Winner of Best New Writing, Buxton Fringe 2014; ★★★★ – Edinburgh Reporter), 
  • Women of the Mourning Fields (★★★★ – Fringe Guru,  ★★★★ - Broadway Baby , ★★★★ - All Edinburgh Theatre; Nominated – Best Production, Buxton Fringe Festival 2015) 
  • Lest We Forget (★★★★ – Broadway Baby; Nominated – Best Production & Best New Writing, Buxton Fringe Festival 2016).

What's the campaign for?

This year, we are producing two brand new shows for the Edinburgh, Buxton & Greater Manchester Fringes, Antigone na h’Éireann and The Shakespeare Catalysts.

Antigone na h’Éireann

Our primary show is Antigone na h’Éireann, a brand new adaptation of the myth set in post-Brexit Northern Ireland. 

Driven by faith to resurrect the IRA, Annie battles to bring her family the honour they deserve. A new Northern Irish adaptation of the myth by multi award-winning writer James Beagon.

In the not too distant future, a hard-border Brexit has severed Ireland in two once and for all. Annie and her siblings will not let this stand. An unshakeable shadow lingers over their journey as faith, family and factions collide: the shadow of their father and the memory of the Disappeared.

A fresh take on the story, inspired by Sophocles and other sources.

Antigone na h’Éireann is being performed at the Edinburgh Fringe from 3rd-26th August, 6pm at Paradise in the Vault. We are also seeking to bring it to the Buxton Fringe and Greater Manchester Fringe in July.

The Shakespeare Catalysts

Our second show is The Shakespeare Catalysts, an exploration of "change" in the modern world through a collection of different Shakespearean scenes.

"Abide the change of time." Cymbeline II.4.

Multi award-winning company (‘Gobland for the Goblins!’ ★★★★★, Families Edinburgh) explores “change” through a timely re-imagining of Shakespeare’s better and lesser known works in the wake of our current social and political upheavals.

Through starkly different scenes from his folios, we challenge audiences to question “change” in our modern world, whether it be something as intimate as the loss of a loved one at old age or the political shake-ups rocking both Europe and the rest of the world.

The Shakespeare Catalysts is being performed at the Edinburgh Fringe as part of the Free Festival from 20th-26th August, 8pm at Espionage (Mata Hari room).

What We Need

We are looking to raise £2000 to help cover the following costs:

  • Venue Fees & Fringe Registration - despite being based in Edinburgh, it is almost prohibitively expensive to put on a show in our home city. We are only able to produce one show at a paid venue (Antigone na h’Éireann) whilst our second (Shakespeare Catalysts) is only possible because of the Free Festival. On top of that, two shows means two Edinburgh registration fees. We are also seeking to take Antigone na h’Éireann to Buxton & Greater Manchester, which means yet more registration & venue fees.
     
  • Travel & Accommodation for Buxton & Greater Manchester - Though we have created award-winning work of a high standard, we operate as an amateur company as we do not have anywhere near the resources to pay any of cast or crew a living wage. That said, we maintain a policy of making sure that we reimburse as many expenses as possible to ensure that nobody loses money by being part of the show. With that in mind, we intend to cover all of our cast & crew travel & accommodation fees for Buxton & Greater Manchester.

What You Get

Our primary perk structure is very simple. For every £30 raised, we pledge to run a free hour of youth theatre workshops for local children in the Edinburgh & Lothians area.

You can either choose to donate this hour (or more!) to a specific Edinburgh local school or community group of your choosing or you can donate the time in general. 

(Although if you would like to buy time for a specific group outside of that area, please get in touch and we'll see what we can do!)

For all hours not donated to a specific school/group, we will split these across a number of completely free youth theatre workshops over the course of 2018 and beginning of 2019. These will be split across the following age groups: 5-7, 8-10, 11-13 and 14-16.

These will be led by professional youth theatre tutor, company founder & award-winning director-playwright James Beagon, who currently works freelance with both Strange Town Theatre Company and East Lothian Youth Theatre.

On top of this, our perks also include the opportunity to get the following:

  • Free Tickets to Antigone na h’Éireann.
  • Aulos Productions mugs and t-shirts.
  • Signed posters of both shows by the cast & crew
  • And more!

Keep an eye out for the appearance of Limited Perks: bonus perks of a fixed number. When they're gone, they're gone!

The Impact

By donating to our campaign, you will be making a real impact for children from families with deprived backgrounds. Youth Theatre tuition can be very expensive and access to drama through the school curriculum is incredibly limited.

Arts funding in Scotland is currently in crisis. Groups like Scottish Youth Theatre, Birds in Paradise and Lung Ha have all recently suffered at the hands of Creative Scotland. When even groups at the top of the Scottish theatre world are in trouble, it means that crowdfunding and regular fundraising events are the only way for groups like Aulos to exist.

By supporting this campaign, you not only make it possible for us to share our work with a wide audience but to produce our work at all.

Risks & Challenges

Every year is a risk for us, but by producing consistently high-quality work, Aulos Productions is able to keep on bringing people the stories and shows that only we can tell.

We put on our first show First Class (2014) on a shoestring budget to the Buxton & Edinburgh Fringe Festivals, where it won the Best New Writing award at the Buxton Fringe on its debut outing.

Since then, every Aulos Productions Fringe show has gone on to be either award-winning or award-nominated and all have received 4 or 5 star reviews.

We don't have the money of professional theatre groups from London or elsewhere. All of our takings from one Fringe go in to financing the next.

We are forced to earn our survival each Fringe and have succeeded every year since we began.

Other Ways You Can Help

We will be hosting at least one fundraising event in Edinburgh per month between April-June, so please try to attend those if you can't donate directly to this campaign!

On top of that, please follow our Facebook page and Twitter account to share updates both about our fundraising campaign and the shows themselves!

You can share this campaign to your personal social media right now by clicking the Share button on this IndieGoGo page.

Word of mouth is always the best form of advertising however. Next time you're in the pub, bring us up in conversation!

Thank-you for reading. If you have any questions, please get in touch with us directly at aulosproductions@gmail.com

story:
Our Fourth Festival happens May 29th - June 2nd, 2019!

We are excited to be presenting the festival again this year. We've had over 250 performers in the last three festivals, presenting both newer and established industry professionals. We have burlesque, sideshow, and the variety arts represented at the festival. This year we are partnering with The Southern Sideshow Hootenanny to bring information about the Carnaval Girls that toured with Girlie Shows in the Carnaval and highlight our variety and sideshow partners.

HI! I'm Lili VonSchtupp, founder of the Hollywood Burlesque Festival in 2013. I've produced over 700 burlesque shows, a gallery photography show, and have toured and headlined festivals throughout the United States. I also run Lili's School for Wayward Girls, a higher education school for burlesque. This year we are growing the festival to include all of southern California. 

Festivals are not a huge money makers. We work within the community to bring a niche art form out from the shadows. It's a community event without major corporate sponsors, that's why we need you. We have a great community in Los Angeles and this event brings producers and performers together in one weekend to educate and entertain the public about that we do.

  • Your contrabutions provide the cash flow before ticket sales to get this event off the ground.

 

We Need To Fund This & You Need Cool Stuff

How are you really helping?

  • Our venue and production costs are about 6k. We bring in lighting and equipment to create a top production event, and we need insurance too. 
  • People love our artwork. Daisy Church created our original Hollywood Showgirls and they are working hard to raise money for us! Take one or all of them home with you, even if you can't attend you can support this event and art locally!
  • All the money raised will go back into the expense of the festival. Venue rental, lighting, sound equipment, media walls, programming, marketing, class room rental, and we provide food to the performers when they perform, you could actually be feeding a hungry artist! 

The Impact

Have you ever wanted to be a part of something bigger than just you?

  • Burlesque is an art form for the people. Shows have cover charges from free to $25. It's a relatively inexpensive art to experience but an expensive art to make happen. It celebrates artists, not limited by their sex, sexual preference, shape, color or disabilty. In fact, I'm 53 and disabled and still perform. 
  • We've made this event happen three times now. For our fourth event we are directly asking for your help!

Risks & Challenges

The festival is three nights in two cities. Weather and art are fickle. We've sold out three times but there is always the chance this weekend night have issues and people stay home. But with your support, the show will go on whether it be sold out or as an intimate event. 

  • We understand we want all the perks and all the bells and whistles! We want our performers to feel loved and valued, yet we know if all the money needed doesn't come in, some things just won't happen. Programs might be smaller, gift bags could be lighter, but we can and have done so much with our  partners working hard to fill them. With your help we can stay on our timeline, cut costs by making early purchases rather than rush orders, and really make this a stellar event. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Share our campaign and our ticket link when it goes live.
  • There are share tools available on this page. And you can donate and give a showgirl to a friend! 

Thank you for sticking with us through this long description and supporting live burlesque in Southern California!

story:
Who We Are

     We are the Happy Accident Theatre (HAT), an Atlanta-based, Atlanta-driven theatre. With a staff comprised of four Atlanta-based artists (Caleigh Derreberry, Esther Lang Reeves, Molly Penny and Zach Stolz) who banded together during their apprenticeship with Horizon Theatre all coming from a range of experience working with theatres all across the country, and even globally. HAT was founded from a love of theatre and frustration with the perceived limitations of the art form. (Want to know more about the founders? Check out the FAQ at the bottom of the page!)

Who Is The Cat?

      Cappy! A lil' rascal dedicated to mischief, curiosity and exploration.

 

What Our Theatre Is

      HAT came together through discussions of weird ideas the founders had, ideas that were too outlandish, too theatrical, too risky, too exciting to ignore. We have compiled these ideas into our first season of theatre to share with the Atlanta community!

 

            IDEAS LIKE:

Abortion Road Trip – September 2019. A staged reading of Rachel Lynett's award-winning play about two sisters who take a taxi from San Antonio to New Mexico to get an abortion. A portion of the proceeds will go to support reproductive justice in Georgia. 8 p.m. Wed., Sept. 4 at The Bakery.

Hold On To Your Hats - November 2019. Ten Atlanta playwrights. Ten plays. Ten minutes long. One prompt: Write an Impossible play. Featuring plays by well-known Atlanta playwrights and performers: Mark Kendall, Suehyla El-Attar, Nick Tecovsky, Jon Carr and Addae Moon, alongside rising writers on the scene: Caleigh Derreberry, Wade Lawrence Hollomon, Slokha Krishnan, Esther Lang Reeves and Bryce Irvin. 8 p.m. Thur.-Sun., Nov. 14-17 at Synchronicity Theatre.

A Hamlet – Spring 2020.  A full production of Hamlet where a different audience member plays the titular character every night. No rehearsal, no prep time, just diving headfirst into Denmark. How universal is the most universal story? Come on down and choose 2 be (or not)!

A World Premiere Play by Anterior Leverett - Summer, 2020. We commissioned Atlanta-playwright Anterior Leverett to write an Atlanta-specific play for our inaugural season.

 

That's the outlook. 13 plays. One big year.

 

What We Need & What You Get: What Your Contributions Cover

Space! The majority of the money from our Indiegogo will help us secure rehearsal and performance space in Atlanta venues both familiar and strange.

Artists! Your contribution will ensure we can pay everyone who works on the production -- designers, writers, stage management, directors, actors -- so no artist has to die the dreaded death of exposure. This covers the entire production team from designers, writers, stage management, directors, and actors. 

Materials! Sets. Costumes. Props. Your donation will help make our shows as accurate and aesthetically rich as each project demands.

Marketing! Help us market our projects so we can build an audience and continue to make affordable, risky theatre again and again and again.

     We will kick-off our season with “Abortion Road Trip” by Rachel Lynett at The Bakery on September 4th, followed by “Hold On To Your Hats” at Synchronicity Theatre November 14th through 17th. We hope to secure our financial support by September in order to recoup personal expenses that have gone into jumpstarting this season and shore up the details of the next two shows.

 

Other Ways You Can Help/How To Reach Us

Want to help but unable to donate? Help us make some noise! Share our campaign, follow us on social media and come see our shows!

Facebook: Happy Accident Theatre

Instagram: @happyaccidenttheatre

You can also email us at happyaccidenttheatre@gmail.com!
story_txt: Who We Are     We are the Happy Accident Theatre (HAT), an Atlanta-based, Atlanta-driven theatre. With a staff comprised of four Atlanta-based artists (Caleigh Derreberry, Esther Lang Reeves, Molly Penny and Zach Stolz) who banded together during their apprenticeship with Horizon Theatre all coming from a range of experience working with theatres all across the country, and even globally. HAT was founded from a love of theatre and frustration with the perceived limitations of the art form. (Want to know more about the founders? Check out the FAQ at the bottom of the page!)Who Is The Cat?      Cappy! A lil' rascal dedicated to mischief, curiosity and exploration. What Our Theatre Is      HAT came together through discussions of weird ideas the founders had, ideas that were too outlandish, too theatrical, too risky, too exciting to ignore. We have compiled these ideas into our first season of theatre to share with the Atlanta community!             IDEAS LIKE:Abortion Road Trip – September 2019. story:
"Invisible?  That's a musical?"

Yup.  Written by David Orris and David Hollingsworth, developed at New Musicals Inc.  It tells the story of two high school nerds who try to develop a serum to make them popular with the Ladies...but instead, it makes one of them invisible.  Invisible was the HIT of the STAGES Musical Theatre Festival last year! 

Now we're taking Invisible to the next level...with a rock band in concert, on June 6th at the Colony Theatre in Burbank. This Indiegogo campaign gives you a chance to buy tickets in advance to the amazing concert, plus show your support for new musicals!




"I'm not rich, but I want to help.  If I donate something, can I at least get a ticket to the concert?"

Sure.  Here's the thing...you could take your chances we haven't sold out, and buy a $22 ticket at the door.  Or for a $30 contribution, you could guarantee yourself a seat PLUS help us recover the $5,500 we will have spent on the concert.


"$5500, for one concert!?"

Actually, it's costing $14,900 for us to put on the concert.  We've already received generous help from 3-D Theatricals and from the National Alliance for Musical Theatre, but that covers only the costs for actors, band, music directors and a very special "invisible" puppet (spoiler alert!).  But we're still out of pocket $5,500 for theatre rental, rehearsal space, director, marketing, programming, insurance, workers' comp, programs, and all that other icky producer-type expense.  We're not complaining -- we love the show; we love what we do...we've just spent every extra dollar we have on this concert, and we're still short.  (Okay, fair enough: SCOTT is short; Elise is tall.)


"I thought Disney was giving you guys some money?"

Nope.  They WERE going to give us some money for a different project -- the New Voices Project, which presented the works of writers under the age of 26 --but we haven't seen a check yet...and in any event, that money's already been spent on the under-26-ers.


"Tell me a little bit more about the show."

Happily; thanks for asking.  Here's how the writers describe the show:

Two nerds, Griff and Kemper, dream of winning the affections of the Lindeborne twins, the most popular girls in school. Despite the objections of their longtime goth friend Hemlock (who has a crush on Griff ), Griff and Kemper hatch a plan to win the twins: Make themselves more popular using science. But when a serum meant to clear Griff's acne turns him invisible, all seems lost. That is, until Griff uses his invisibility to help Kemper beat Chetwick, the school's bully, in a fight, which sends the school abuzz about Kemper.  Kemper goes mad with power and betrays Griff.

See, so it's about betrayal, forgiveness, and trust...and nerds.


"Nerds!?  What do musical theatre writers know about NERDS?"

That's a trick question, and you know it.  Here's who wrote the show....

David Orris (Music and Lyrics) was raised in Twin Peaks (yes, it's a real place) and Chicago and is the gay, Buddhist son of an ordained Protestant minister (who once served as Pat Robertson's chief marketing executive).  Orris studied theater, voice, piano, and composition at the Wheaton Conservatory before heading to Los Angeles where he signed with BMG Chrysalis Music Publishing. His songs and recordings have been heard in a variety of feature films and TV programs, most notably on a number of MTV programs and prominently on JJ Abrams' and Matt Reeves' hit Golden-Globe-winning television series Felicity.

David Hollingsworth (Book) hails from northern California, raised in a family that mounted weekly Gilbert and Sullivan family performances in the living room.  He is the former Editor-in-Chief of UC Berkeley's largest student-run publication, The Heuristic Squelch; and has also collaborated with other writers to create McSweeney’s-- (Onion-like) articles satirizing the news and popular culture.  He also wrote for Rooftop Comedy’s collaboration with MSN, developing written humor pieces based on trending news items as soon as they broke. 

Orris & Hollingsworth ​first met at the Academy for New Musical Theatre while working in the Core Curriculum musical theatre workshop. Orris and Hollingsworth collaborated with many writers to develop short-form musical pieces based on a rigorous curriculum of musical theatre theory created by Lehman Engel. The two David's finally got to collaborate (along with the very-talented lyricist Mara Hitner) on a short one-act musical (with the succinct title of The 'Harmon Galloway Reboot Your Life Total Self-Improvement Method and Enhancement System' Show) which was produced and performed at the Colony Theatre in Burbank, CA in 2012.  Marrying Hollingsworth's sharp humor with Orris's heartfelt pop-infused music, this enthusiastic duo hopes to see Invisible follow in the footsteps of writing heroes such as Gilbert & Sullivan, Stephen Schwartz, Alan Menken and Jonathan Larson.


"Can I hear some music from the show?"

Of course you can.  Here are three demos!

ALL SYSTEMS ARE GO (Randy Guiaya, Christopher Maikish, Dana Shaw)
GIRL IN THE DARK (Amanda Kruger)
ONE SMALL STEP (Randy Guiaya and Christopher Maikish)

Meet Our Amazing Cast!


The cast is set to include Michael Thomas Grant (For the Record: Dear John Hughes, UMPO: Clueless, UMPO: Scream) and Daniel Amerman (Arrested Development, The Office, Glee, CSI:NY, Awkward, and the ABC Family prank show “Freak Out”) as the high school nerds, Griff and Kemper who brew up a potion intended to make them popular (but which accidentally turns Griff invisible). Ashley Argota (The Fosters, Girl Meets World, True Jackson, VP, The Lion King on Broadway) is the goth girl, Hemlock; and Jordan Goodsell (Frozen: Live at the Hyperion) is the jock Chetwick. The cast is rounded out with Christie Brooke and Natalie MacDonald as the twins Melrose and Madison Lindeborne; Jay Cramer as Principal Sherman; Luke Klipp as Mr. Reeves, and Luke Matthew Simon and Daniel Mills as the flunkies Craig and Jackal.

The Invisible ensemble is made up of Melvin Villajin Biteng, Natasha J Gaston, Sara Gonzales, Sarah Kennedy, Christian Sullivan, Dekontee Tucrkile, Collin Tyler, Logan Vamosi; with Ian Wakem Felchlin (Guitar), Randy Fox (Drums), and Kevin Lambertucci (Bass).

The concert reading will be co-directed by 3-D Theatrical’s Artistic Director T.J. Dawson and NMI’s Artistic Director Elise Dewsberry; with music direction by Ron Barnett; sound design by Julie Ferrin; and puppet design by Patricio Wolovich.

"I live in Orange County, and I see you're presenting Invisible in cooperation with 3-D Theatricals.  Is there any chance you'd give a performance down here?"

Yes!  We're also bringing a performance of Invisible to the 3-D Theatricals Rehearsal Hall in Anaheim on Tuesday, June 7 at 8:00pm.  3-D Theatricals is offering it free (suggested donation at the door) at their venue because they are working on developing an audience for new shows.  So if seeing it in Anaheim is easier for you, by all means, sign up for a ticket at 3-D Theatricals - but we wouldn't stop you from donating to our campaign AND seeing the show in Anaheim.  If you do, you might consider donating to 3-D as well.

"So I see perks which give me 1, 2 or 4 tickets.  How do I order three tickets?"

Look at you, all outside the box!  There are several things you might do.  1) Buy both a 1-ticket and a 2-ticket perk in two separate transactions;  2) CONTRIBUTE NOW in the amount of $90...we'll automatically assume you want 3 tickets, and we'll send you confirmation of a reservation; 3) email us at admin@nmi.org and we'll give you some other options, off the grid.


"Oh, it sounds so great.  YES!, I'll be delighted to help by selecting a perk, or making a contribution!"

You're a wonderful person.  Thank you.

story:
About Readymade

Conveying the power of perspective and appreciation, ka·nei·see | collective presents Readymade, an evening-length dance inspired by Marcel Duchamp's art theory by the same title. An hour long, the show involves ten performers, commissioned costume and lighting design, original choreography by Tanya Chianese, and hundreds of rolls of toilet paper.

In 1917 Duchamp turned a porcelain urinal on its side at an esteemed exhibition and titled it Fountain. He did nothing to the object except present it for contemplation. The infuriated art world argued that dignifying commonplace objects did not make them works of art. Duchamp's actions prompted a philosophical movement that challenged society's idea of what art should be and how we view the world.

Now a century later as society becomes reliant on our technological existence, Duchamp's theory of the readymade is relevant today more than ever; it reminds us to acknowledge our surroundings, and in turn our lives, with a positive, open-minded lens. Readymade is not about Duchamp's work, but instead aims to invoke his iconic idea of do-it-yourself power to reshape one's own life by changing how we view things.   

About the Budget

Our budget for Readymade is $15,260.

This includes: Theater Rental $3,500, Personnel $7,300, Costumes and Props $1,400, Marketing & Publicity $1,019, Receptions $181, Rehearsal Space $1,860

This project is supported by the Phyllis C. Wattis Foundation, the Lighting Artists in Dance grant (a program of Dancers’ Group), and individual donors. Additionally, we anticipate selling out and we are factoring ticket sales into our income.

However, we are still $1,500 away from reaching our goal. We hope you will consider supporting contemporary dance and bridging this gap for the present and future.

Thanks so much!

Many thanks for making a huge impact in the future of ka·nei·see | collective!

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Please check out our perks to the right for some added fun and laughter.

See the show

Premiering October 7-9, 2016 at Dance Mission Theater in San Francisco, CA.

Purchase tickets here.

Tour dates...TBA! (We're looking for opportunities, want to partner?)

Other Ways You Can Help

Spreading the word is another valuable way you can help ka·nei·see | collective. Share this campaign and/or the production.

Visit our Facebook and Instagram

About ka·nei·see | collective

ka·nei·see | collective debuted its first home season, Cookie Cutter, to sold-out audiences and a front page cover story of the SF Chronicle's 96 Hours that read “accessible and provocative, as well as unafraid to meld innovation with time-honored dance conventions.” (Nirmala Nataraj, Jan 2015). Launched in 2014, ka·nei·see | collective is a Bay Area performing arts ensemble directed by Tanya Chianese creating vitalizing, accessible contemporary dance that promotes finding humor, appreciation, compassion, awareness, and celebration in our increasingly technological existence. The company has been presented at various venues including ODC Theater, Z Space, Joe Goode Annex, Shawl-Anderson Dance Center, Dance Mission Theater, Fort Mason Center, and Yerba Buena Gardens, as well as toured to Los Angeles. The recipient of two audience choice awards, ka·nei·see | collective has presented in many festivals notably SF International Arts Festival, West Wave Dance Festival, RAWdance’s CONCEPT series, and SPF.

“If you’re in the area, go see it and if you’re not, make a special trip. Tanya Chianese and ka·nei·see | collective are important players in the emerging contemporary dance scene.”  -Heather Desaulniers, Critical Dance, Jan 2015

For more information visit www.kaneisee.org

story:
Short Summary

Melanie Combe graduated with a BA in Theatre from Buffalo State College and an MLitt in Dramaturgy and Playwriting from the University of Glasgow.    This will be her first official production since her move to Glasgow and her way of injecting some fresh humor into the UK theatre scene.

Once Crazy, Twice Removed (directed by Melanie and Assistant Directed by Mary-Jo Hastie) is a farce about a girl who causes chaos in every life she enters, yet people love her despite this.  The cast includes:

Leigha - Cabrina Conaty

Geddy - William Coleman

Max - Jamie Mccafferty

Hermia - Nikoletta Thoma

Katherine - Mary-Jo Hastie


You can see it live at the Govanhill Baths, April 15-18, 2015

What We Need & What You Get

The majority of the funding (roughly £640) is needed to go toward rehearsal space.  (It ain't cheap, folks!)  The rest is allotted toward costumes, props, marketing and tech. 

More importantly, you will get a night of laughter.  We have the funniest cast you've ever seen in Glasgow.

*£10=$15.42


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

Hermia - Nikoletta Thoma
Katherine - Mary-Jo Hastie

You can see it live at the Govanhill Baths, April 15-18, 2015   What We Need & What You Get The majority of the funding (roughly £640) is needed to go toward rehearsal space.  (It ain't cheap, folks!)  The rest is allotted toward costumes, props, marketing and tech. 
More importantly, you will get a night of laughter.  We have the funniest cast you've ever seen in Glasgow.
*£10=$15.42

    
    Other Ways You Can Help  Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

story:
Dear Friends, Family and Fans of new performed art,

For the past four years RECREATIONAL SERVICES have been working to fuse music, physical gesture, objects, words and theory into visceral and mind-expanding performances. If that sounds like opera, that's fine with us! But forget John Adams and Philip Glass (and the older guys). We aim for a 21st-century thinking-artists' opera that is currently hard to find – ambitious multi-arts performance that bursts with complex music and risk-taking theater, that also takes the time to think about cultural questions philosophically. We wish to defend cultivating the life of the mind through art as something that builds a world.


As we gear up for our first festival we are asking for your help! Your donation is important to our ability to continue to present challenging and irreverent work with leading artists from the wide range of contemporary performing arts.


Please read on below for more information about our upcoming London festival, INFANCY, HISTORY & THE AVANT-GARDE. And visit us at recreationalservices.wordpress.com for festival program, artist bios, and tickets.

Sincerely yours,


Steve Potter and Kélina Gotman



INFANCY, HISTORY & THE AVANT-GARDE is our newest project, a two-day festival of imaginative new poetry-music-theater and re-imaginings of 1920s French avant-garde work. Electronics band Schopenhauer and a ‘headless’ Kélina Gotman will give an explosive rendition of Georges Bataille's feisty philosophical text 'Propositions on the Death of God'. Antonin Artaud's 'Jet de Sang' ('Spurt of Blood'), a parody of surrealism from one of 20th century theater's most influential thinkers, has rarely been seen. Adam de la Cour, with Mark Knoop and Carl Rosman, takes Artaud further with L’Exorcisme du Mômo, and Patrick ffrench brings us face to face with Bataille’s cogent yet uncomfortable view of nature as excess and loss in his talk, ‘On (Not) Having Your Feet on the Ground’.



We are proud to host New York's trailblazing Wet Ink Ensemble in their first ever UK appearance, together with a long-germinating work from Steve Potter (with Stephen Upshaw, Rocío Bolaños & Siwan Rhys) on the dark hours of new parenthood. Plus a series of new poetry performances take on extreme sensation, cries, screams and excess, plus the flip-side: discipline, control & security. With theatre-makers Ollie Evans, Matthew Fink & P.A. Skantze, Lisa Jeschke & Lucy Beynon, and Jeremy Hardingham. Finally Greek choreographer Efrosini Protopapa leads a group of participants through the politics of the 18th-century ballroom in a choreographic score especially created for the festival.

story:
SCENES FROM MARS ONE: NOW WITH 68% LESS GRAVITY!  
A ONE-ACT PLAY WITH THIRTEEN INTERMISSIONS

AT LONG LAST, the epic unproduced play by the reclusive Baron Von Krankenstuhl, Mars One, which chronicles, in real time, the colonization and terraforming of Mars (approximate running time 2,327 years, 6 months, 5 days, 17 hours, 31 minutes), has been made available as an easily consumed one-act.  What happens when two untrained astronauts, recently divorced, embark on a one-way mission to Mars, spending 200 days in isolation, in zero-gravity?  Space Fever?  Or will the amateur production collapse under its own weight before the audience finds out?  Please Note:  Hecklers will not be tolerated.

What Enron-Style Accounting Scheme, MARS ONE PRODUCTIONS, Are You Running Here That You Want My Money For Theater, A Dying, if not dead, Art Form?

Thank you for your question.  This isn't a scam, it's a one-act play (with 13 intermissions), debuting at the 2015 San Diego International Fringe Festival.  You can check their Facebook page, we're on the list.  Despite what we thought, producing theater isn't cheap.  Your donation will pay for the following: 

  • The Exorbitant 'Registration' Fee ($563) charged by the San Diego International Fringe Festival.  Admittedly, the fee includes 5 showtimes and a venue, so we've agreed to pay it.
  • Funds For Costumes, Set Design, Special Effects.  After reviews of our Nude Hamlet were tepid at best, we've re-thought the whole clothing-optional approach to theater and decided to dress our cast for Scenes From Mars One: Now With 68% Less Gravity! in actual costumes.  UNFORTUNATELY, this also costs money.  
  • Marketing.  Typically when you produce a play, NO ONE CARES.  So you have to convince them they do care, even though you wouldn't care either, if you were them.  That's where Marketing comes in.  But no, you guessed it, it isn't free.  We anticipate spending a few hundred on flyers, postcards, etc., and we will be giving away a low-quality program to those in attendance.
  • Incidentals.  Several members of our cast are addicted to prescription drugs.  Obviously, none of your money will be going to such things, but we just felt we should make you aware.  Still, it would be nice to give the cast & crew a small stipend, or at least pay for their dinner once during rehearsal.  Speaking of rehearsal, a rehearsal space would be helpful, but is completely dependent upon your generosity. 


Sorry Mars One Productions, but I'd rather flush my money down a space toilet than let you waste it.  Is there anything else (free) I can do to help?

Absolutely!  You're just the type of self-starter this campaign needs, Mr. and/or Ms. Cheapskate.  Even if you want us to fail, but feel guilty for the thoughts you harbor inside of you, give us a hand up, not a hand out, by sharing the link to our campaign on your favorite social media platform.  And tell all your friends, if by some twist of fate a tight-wad like you has any.  Even mentioning to strangers in the street what those Mars One Productions lunatics are up to is greatly appreciated.  And finally, if you live in San Diego, please come out and support the 2015 San Diego International Fringe Festival (July 23 - August 2nd), even if it isn't our play.  We're not the only ones putting together bad theater to escape from our soul-crushing day jobs.

story: ----

Short Summary

Hello All!

This production of The Importance of Being Earnest is a project that is close to my heart. In the Fall of 2017, I began a journey of directing Bye Bye Birdie for Asbury University's annual musical presented by the sophomore class. During this time, I discovered my love of directing and storytelling that gets to the heart of human nature: all of our mistakes, all of our triumphs and joys, and everything in between that makes us relate to and understand one another. Because I found a passion in theatre in a new way, I sought after another project as soon as I possibly could, and The Importance of Being Earnest fell into my open hands as a personal project. Throughout the process of putting this show together in two and a half weeks, I have been grown and stretched as an individual and artist and seen my cast and crew rise to the challenge to assist me and my passion to create a unique version of this classic show. As time draws near to opening our doors, we ask that you consider joining us in our journey and helping us get our feet on the stage, ready to go. 

Theatre is all about community, and I welcome each of you to be a part of ours!

With gratitude, 

Sarah Cole

What We Need & What You Get

We're students! Here's all that we are needy for:

  • Funding! This play is 100% financed by us; we get no financial aid from the university for the performance. Your support allows us to carry out our vision and provide a fun evening of comedic theatre for our school and our local community
  • Choosing to donate to our project will give you: handwritten thanks by our cast and crew, reserved seats, tickets, and more!
  • All of the proceeds go to funding our costumes, lights, props, set, and anything else you may see around our stage!

The Impact

The Importance of Being Earnest is a completely student-run project that gives both our cast and crew opportunities to develop lifelong skills and relationships that will be valuable in the student's future careers in the theatre as well as other professional work environments:

  • We believe that theatre and live storytelling is for everyone, and we want them to know that!
  • Al of our cast and crew have training in both theatre and or film productions and have an interest in dynamic collaboration. Recent project from the Directors include: Bye Bye Birdie (2018).
  • Without your help, we would not be able to follow our dreams and do what we love.

Other Ways You Can Help

This entire show is being put together in two-and-a-half weeks, so your prayers and thoughts are appreciated above all. Here are the way you can be praying for our cast and crew:

  • Health, rest, and energy; even during the long days :)
  • Continued good relationships and community within our ensemble and within the theatre department at Asbury University
  • For our cast and crew to be able to deliver joy, laughter, and a break from the stresses of life for just a few hours.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you all so much!

Love, Sarah Cole and Sarah Nesselroade

story:
HELLO!

I am the creator, founder and visionary of JuxtaPosition Dance Theatre (JPDT). I am also the mother of a happy, energetic, and smart-allec 11 month old baby girl.  Having my own dance company and producing/directing a show of my choreography has been a dream of mine since I began dancing as a child and after our little one was born, I realized that in order to teach her that she can reach her dreams, I needed to have the courage to pursue my own. So I decided to take the plunge and began founding JPDT.  Together with our dancers we are bringing to life "Kinetic Interludes," our first full-length evening dance concert dealing with themes ranging from body image struggles to social greed, but we can't do it alone.

A little bit about me:

I received my B.A. in Theater Arts & Dance, with an emphasis in Dance from CSU, Los Angeles. Upon completion of my collegiate studies, I spent some time in France with the M.A.D.E. in France program where I trained with David Dorfman Dance, Lisa Race, Liz Claire, and Libertivore Dance Theatre. I have also had the opportunity to work with and train with artists such as Hae Lee of Hae Kyung Lee & Dancers, Holly Johnston of Ledges & Bones, Rebeca Hernandez, C. Derrick Jones III  of Catch Me Bird, and many more. In winter of 2010 I choreographed, co-wrote, produced and starred in my first dance for film production entitled "Silenced Dreams," which I created as a social awareness project for the Women of Juarez Femicides; an issue that I am deeply impassioned by. In late 2012 I was given the opportunity to dance under the direction of Rebeca Hernandez for the annual Day of the Dead Celebration at the Los Angeles Hollywood Cemetary.

About our project:

With "Kinetic Interludes," we will present an evening of dynamic, athletic, highly physical and highly emotive choreography that examines our everyday lives, ourselves, the way we love, and the world beyond our front door through the eyes of the femenine perspective.  Our show touches issues ranging from body image and female objectification to social greed and everyday interactions in our humanity. We seek to make dances that create contrast within concepts, music, and movement.  The choreography we are most drawn to is that which pushes limits, derives inspiration from unlikely places, and blooms from confined spaces.

As an emerging dance company we seek to create performance opportunities for dancers of all ages, backgrounds, and abilities. We thrive in the bodies of the unexpected dancer and we desire to depict both the pain & joy in our humanity through our movement.

Furthermore, our mission is to bring modern and contemporary dance to underprivileged youths in low-income neighborhoods. This concert is the first step toward accomplishing our vision and you have the power to make it a reality.

What your donation will contribute:

As a donor, you will ensure that we can meet our production costs and your donation will help procure:

Theater Rental

Lighting Technician

Costumes

Printing Costs

Performance Video & Photography for Dancer Reels & Company Archives

Rehearsal Space

Dancer Stipends

 

Donor Perks:

Check out our perks below! As a donor you have the unique opportunity to receive anywhere from a special thanks dedication in our show's program to a VIP meet & greet with the entire cast after the performance. And for those of you want an even more VIP experience, you also have to opportunity to score a dinner with our artistic director and a photo with the entire cast. Make sure to explore our donor perks, there's so much to choose from!

Help us spread the word and share our campaign!

story:
Our Story

draft89 Theatre Collective has been producing original Canadian interdisciplinary theatre since 2003.  


Islands is a new play by long-time collective member Graham Porter.  Set in the distant future, it looks at the clash between utopia and human nature.  Are people entitled to their bad ideas?  Are people free to relinquish their freedom?  When the mob is at the gate, does it matter if they're right or wrong?  When your opponent plays dirty, when do you climb down into the dirt with them?  All this, plus holograms, radioactive sunflowers, anti-ageing medicine and big hats will be on display in two-hour installments starting May 17, 2012.


The Impact

Original live theatre is hard.  Space is expensive, lots of people are required, and you'd like to pay everyone something for their time, even though there's so little money to go around.  So why do we still do it?


Maybe we're nuts.  Maybe...no, we're nuts.  But if you've got the theatre bug, you just have to do it.  So here we are, after nine years and seven shows, getting ready to do it all over again.


For all that film and television provide, there's still one thing they can't do (yet).  They can't put you in the room.  That's something draft89 tries to do with every show - put the audience right in the action, nose to nose with the performers, and make them feel like they're a part of what's going on.  That's what we did when we turned FOE (2007) into a living art gallery.  That's what we did when we rebuilt John and Yoko's Montreal hotel room for John/Yoko Bed Piece (2009).  And that's what we'll do with Islands, when we treat the audience to front-row seats to the end of the world, and to what came after.


What We Need & What You Get

Right now we're $8000 away from being able to open - our performance space, rehearsal space and insurance all need to be paid for up-front.  Once that's handled, we will use any overflow funds to improve the quality of our sets, costumes and video projection.  The goal is for the show to be debt-free on opening night.  If we can reach that goal, then 100% of the ticket sales can go to paying the cast and crew.  These fine people will have put in months of hard work by the time the show closes, and we want to give them as much financial compensation as we can.


Oh, and don't forget the perks.  Please see the sidebar for all the fabulous prizes you'll win for helping us reach our goal.


Other Ways You Can Help

1. Share this page with anyone you know who loves theatre.

2. Share this page with anyone you know who loves science fiction.

3. Share this page with anyone you know who would laugh if they heard of an operation called "Selective Neural Formatting."

4. Make a donation yourself.

story:
Paperhouse Theatre is a new company in Charlotte, NC dedicated to producing classic and contemporary works with economy of production elements and focus on actors, directors and service to the text.  We are storytellers, lovers of words, fabulists and dreamers who DO.  We are determined to explore all facets of human experience and build them a home that is temporay in time but eternal in spirit. 

Founded in 2012, Paperhouse made its debut in November on the tiny stage of an attic bar, The Wine Up, with "Penny Penniworth - A Story of Great Good Fortune" and left audiences drowning in wine and laughter. 

New opportunities  and partnerships followed that run at rapid-fire pace with plans for comic serials, modern romantic tragedies, forgotten classics and now...LaRonde.

La Ronde is a wry, saucy and very very sexy trip down a circuit of scenes that explore and expose our lives of love and lust.  Ten characters, ten scenes and an endless circle dance with more moves than a Bourbon St go-go girl.

Often reinterpreted and endlessly imitated, we are taking Arthur Schnitzler's text back to it's roots and stripping it down to its bare skin. 

We want it raw and real and in your face with fearless performers and innovative staging. 

We want it on the floor and in the round with everyone watching and close enough to smell the sweat. 

Most of all, we want you.  We need you.  We need you so so bad, baby.    

Your generous contributions will provide us a space in one of the finest intimate professional venues in town - the Duke Energy Theater at Spirit Square-  for a two week run as well as all the associated neccessities such as ticket agents, promotional items and advertising, house staff, ushers, production assitance, set, lighting, sexy, sassy fin de siecle inspired costumes, and not so sexy liabilty insurance.

While the funds we are seeking here are dedicated to production costs, you will also be helping us fulfill to directive at the heart of our company mission.  Paperhouse believes that hard work deserves compensation and is dedicated to paying its artists. The untimate goal is to have that pay be a living wage. But for now box office revenue is dedicated to a reasonable stipend distributed to all actors, directors and technicians who participate once operating cost obligations are met. This allows us to attract the finest talent that the town and region have to offer, secure their ability to do their work and make a real contribution to the economic vitality of the city.   

In addition to the gratification of helping enrich Charlotte's artistic environment -while also tightening its pants -  we also offer a scintillating array of exotic artisan crafted marital aids at ten levels of giving as our way of expressing our deep deep deep satisfaction. 

 Even if you are as poor as we are that doesn't mean you can't make a meaningful contribution to the cause.  We are always looking for partners from all areas of the arts and volunteers are always welcome to lend a hand...or leg...or more. Plus, you can do more than you think right now by helping spread the word.
story_txt:
Paperhouse Theatre is a new company in Charlotte, NC dedicated to producing classic and contemporary works with economy of production elements and focus on actors, directors and service to the text.  We are storytellers, lovers of words, fabulists and dreamers who DO.  We are determined to explore all facets of human experience and build them a home that is temporay in time but eternal in spirit. 
Founded in 2012, Paperhouse made its debut in November on the tiny stage of an attic bar, The Wine Up, with "Penny Penniworth - A Story of Great Good Fortune" and left audiences drowning in wine and laughter. 
New opportunities  and partnerships followed that run at rapid-fire pace with plans for comic serials, modern romantic tragedies, forgotten classics and now...LaRonde.
La Ronde is a wry, saucy and very very sexy trip down a circuit of scenes that explore and expose our lives of love and lust.  Ten characters, ten scenes and an endless circle dance with more moves than a Bourbon St go-go girl.
Often reinterpreted and endlessly imitated, we are taking Arthur Schnitzler's text back to it's roots and stripping it down to its bare skin. 
We want it raw and real and in your face with fearless performers and innovative staging. 
We want it on the floor and in the round with everyone watching and close enough to smell the sweat. 
Most of all, we want you.  We need you.  We need you so so bad, baby.    
Your generous contributions will provide us a space in one of the finest intimate professional venues in town - the Duke Energy Theater at Spirit Square-  for a two week run as well as all the associated neccessities such as ticket agents, promotional items and advertising, house staff, ushers, production assitance, set, lighting, sexy, sassy fin de siecle inspired costumes, and not so sexy liabilty insurance.

Plus, you can do more than you think right now by helping spread the word.

story:
Marilyn Portilla (18) es una estudiante de ballet proveniente de Trujillo, Peru. En la actualidad se encuentra en la ciudad de Philadelphia, Pennsylvania continuando sus estudios en The Rock School for Dance Education. En este website puedes ayudar a Marilyn para que pueda seguir mejorando!

 

 

 Hello my name is Marilyn Portilla.  I am 18 and a ballet student from Trujillo, Peru.  I am currently studying ballet at the Rock School for Dance Education in the city of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.   I am reaching out for financial assistance so I may continue my studies until June of 2013.

If you contribute $10 I'll say you THANKS!

If you contribute $25 I'll send you a picture of me dancing!

 
Thank you for your support in making this happen!

story:
The Show

Hedwig is an East German rock 'n' roll goddess who also happens to be the victim of a botched sex-change operation, leaving her with just an Angry Inch. Now on their “British Tour” Hedwig and her band use music and conversation to tell us of her hilariously tragic life’s search for The Origin of Love, inspiring anyone who has felt life gave them an inch when they deserved a mile. The ground breaking Obie-winning Off-Broadway smash also won multiple awards for its hit film adaptation.


The Theatre

This production of Hedwig and the Angry Inch will take place at New Venture Theatre, a charity theatre based in Brighton, East Sussex and run entirely by volunteers. It has won several local awards for the high quality of its productions. The NVT was founded over fifty years ago to provide education and experience to anyone wanting to get involved in theatre and to bring affordable performing arts to the local community.

The Festival

Brighton Fringe is the largest arts festival in England and one of the largest fringe festivals in the world. It sets out to stimulate, educate and entertain a wide audience by providing a showcase for diverse art forms. Everyone can take part, in fact, whilst enjoying a friendly and supportive environment. And all this in an iconic city with unique cultural heritage.

Why We Need Your Funding

No matter what happens, New Venture Theatre’s Hedwig is going to be a fantastic show. We already have a huge team of talented crew who have fallen in love with it and casting auditions have gone even better than we could have hoped. We now have an experienced cast with just the right mix of charisma, comedy timing and musical talent.

But there are things we would like to add. NVT has excellent lighting facilities for a small theatre, but we would like to add more – the kind of lighting worthy of an ass-kicking band like The Angry Inch. Part of your donation will pay for a high quality strobe light and other equipment to give that extra oomph.

We always enjoy being part of Brighton Fringe Festival. It gets bigger and better every year – but this does make it harder and harder for a modest charity theatre to be noticed amongst the other big shows. Part of your donation will go towards making sure that Hedwig and the Angry Inch get the audience and recognition that they deserve.

There are lots of other things we could bolster too. We have plans for a very stylish set – part of your donation will go towards making it even better. We have a band who will most definitely rock your world – part of your donation will go towards giving them some extra studio rehearsal time.

In order to produce this challenging show, and make it the best we can, we require additional funding to make the show truly outstanding.

We require more funding for the following:

  • A strobe-light
  • Costume for the cast (clothing, makeup and, of course, a wig!)
  • T-Shirts printed for the crew, AKA the band's roadies
  • Set materials
  • Marketing - competition for audience members at the Brighton Festival and Brighton Fringe is fierce, and advertising becomes more expensive. We require funds to enable us to equally promote ourselves alongside the large shows and venues.

The breakdown is as follows:

  • Strobe-light - £110
  • Costume - £90
  • Set materials - £160
  • T-Shirts - £40
  • Marketing - £100+
  • Giving a total of £500

As you can see, our needs are modest, but this additional funding will help make the show the best it can be.

And Beyond

We love this show and we suspect you do too. What happens if we go over our goal? This will go towards extra technical equipment, like in-ear audio monitors for the band, and into making the production the best it can be.

story:
"The germ of Destruction began probably the 2nd or 3rd time I met Darren DeBari.  He asked me what role I wanted to always play... I said there are so many.  He said he wanted to write me a Ricky Roma... and in one way I can say he did, and Willy Loman and Stanley Kowalski too -- what all three of those men do share in common with Jack Gallo is that they will do anything towards achieving the American dream.   Unlike Jack, those great characters before him either destroy or get destroyed... Jack has maybe... just maybe one ounce... possibly an ounce of a chance towards redemption."                     

-- A.J. Ciccotelli, artistic director of LaStrada Ensemble Theater  

Help support... DESTRUCTION!

We'd love for you to support our workshop production of Darren Debari's full-length play DESTRUCTION OF THE AMERICAN MALE which we are producing at Coastal Artists Productions, 66 South Main Street in Ocean Grove, NJ. on Friday, April 11 at 8pm; Saturday, April 12 at 2pm & 8pm; and Sunday, April 13 at 2pm.

LaStrada Ensemble Theater is birthed as Jack Gallo meets his destruction this April.  Founders A.J. Ciccotelli, Darren Debari and Stephen Larsen form a new ensemble theater that focuses on local playwrights and talent.  

Jack Gallo had it all – a promising career as an actor, a trophy wife, and all the booze a young man could drink – then he lost it all. He takes a job as a stockbroker, and starts to claw up the ladder to the American Dream again – only to lose his footing and lose it all, again. Now, he wonders who he is – where will he get his next drink – and what will he leave behind that matters?

Destruction of the American Male was first presented as a reading in April 2013 as a part of the reading series of Black Box of Asbury Park.  After a summer-long dramaturgical reworking, the play is ready for its first workshop production.   The workshop production will help us develop the play into a MainStage production.  We are planning to do two Q&A so audience feedback can help Darren further refine his play.

          

     DESTRUCTION: Budget Needs             

Our budget is $1,500. This includes: set, props, costumes and rehearsal space.

Set, Props, Costumes: $1,000

$1,000 for set, props and costumes for the show.

Rehearsal Space:  $500

We will be renting space for rehearsals and tech week.

Why your funds are important?

                      

Without your funds, we don't have a production.  The play is about a man who is forced to redefine himself in a world that has promised him riches but almost kills him.  It is timely and relevant and has an excellent cast and director.  We'd love to share it with you.

Visit our web page at www.destructionofamericanmale@webs.com

Visit our facebook page at: https://www.facebook.com/lastradaensembletheater 

Helping us with funds makes this great play come alive!

If I can't contribute right now, what can I do?

Share this page with your friends, perhaps they can help.  

And see DESTRUCTION... you will be in for a treat!

 Friday, April 11th at 8pm

Saturday, April 12th at 2pm & 8pm

Sunday, April 13th at 2pm

Go to one of these websites to buy tickets: www.coastalartists.org/theatre or  www.destructionofamericanmale.webs.com.  

For further questions please contact us at lastradaensembletheater@gmail.com or call us at 732-455-2748
