story:
UPDATE!
Dear Friends of Nachmo,

We did it! In fact, thanks to you we more than did it. Your generous donation, combined with that of 54 fellow supporters, raised $3,457 in 31 days. Meaning that together, we surpassed our original goal of $3,000. You’ve helped us grow National Choreography Month into a national organization with over 80 participating choreographers. We are so grateful for your support.

It has been an exciting and eventful month of movement for our Nachmo participants. This year saw the creation of over 80 new dance works, including a piece inspired by The Trojan Women, a movement study of doors in New York, and a ballet to live guitar. We established a rockstar website where Nachmo Artists could share their work. And we brought in an Artists’ Committee to guide our growing organization. Your donations have helped make all of these new undertakings come to life.

For each of the last three years we’ve hosted one evening of work under the guidance of 2 dancers and their friends. You are a major architect of our growth this year in providing funds to shore up our new infrastructure. This year, with the support of your contributions, we and our 15 member Artists’ Committee are thrilled to invite you to seven performances spread across three cities in which our intrepid choreographers present their world premieres to the public. If you received the Two Tickets perk from our campaign, then your name is already on our guest lists in every city. To all others, we invite you to join us at the show nearest you to take in the work you helped us accomplish.

New York City Finale Week
Monday Feb 4th, Tuesday 5th, and Wednesday Feb 6th at 8pm.
$5 cash at the door at Mark Morris Dance Center

New York City Grand Finale
Friday, Feb 8th: 7:30pm &. Saturday, Feb 9th: 7:30pm at Triskelion Arts’ Aldous Theater.
Tickets are $10 in advance here or $15 cash at the door.

Inaugural Nachmo Boston Performance
Saturday, February 16th: 7:30pm at Green Street Studios, Cambridge.
Tickets are $5 cash only at the door. Reservations release to walk-ins 15 minutes prior to curtain. Ticket reservations here.

Inaugural San Francisco Performance
Saturday, March 2nd: 8pm at Aspen Aerial. 81 Langton St. Unit 1 San Francisco (entrance on Filmore).
Cost: $5-10 suggested donation at the door. Email nachmosf@gmail.com for reservations.

We’re psyched to send your perks as a gesture of our appreciation. As you can see above, we’ve got a few things to produce over the next 2 weeks. Expect to hear from us before the end of February with your handwritten notes, haikus, photos, backstage passes, and DVDs. We’re delighted to share with you in thanks for your sharing with us.

With gratitude,
Jaedra, Campaign Manager
Sharyn and Anna, Founders
The Nachmo 4 Artists' Committee: Anjuli Bhattacharyya, Annalisa Ledson, Brighid Greene, Chelsea Koenig, Emily Craver, Erica Frankel, Erin Cairns Cella, Jaedra DiGiammarino, Janet Forward, Jenn Singer, Jun Lee, Karesia Batan, Katie Martin, Lindsay Reuter, Micheline Heal

 
 
 
About Nachmo
Nachmo spurs dancers to choreograph by challenging them with a deadline and supporting them with a community. We invite dancers to forge a new work in one month, from January 1st to 31st. Our framework expands artistic resources through live events, interactive blogging, and a community who expects completion. Many dancers have the inclination and the skills to make their own work, but are limited by the economics of time and funding. Nachmo breaks down that wall with the power of a deadline accompanied by an active community.
 
Who we are
Nachmo was conceived by dancers Sharyn Korey and Anna Brown Massey in 2009, when they felt they both needed a serious nudge to start making work. They admired the model used by National Novel Writing Month, and created a similar format to motivate themselves to put together new work. The event has grown each year, and already we have over 90 Nachmo 4 artists working on creating new pieces this January.


Over our first three years we have been lucky to receive the generous donations of skills, smarts, and energy from fellow choreographers. Nachmo is now in its fourth year and it’s time to generate funds to support the phenomenal work of the Artists Board, the costs of our productions, and the power of publicity. Please join us in our strategic campaign to support us as we spur artists to creation through communal action. Your donation will support us for Nachmo 4 and to help us grow into the coming decade.

What your support provides
Nachmo 4 is supported by a volunteer Artists Committee of 15 dancers who donate services in web design, copy editing, financial development, publicity outreach, graphic design, video editing, email marketing, and event planning. Whew! Their amazing generosity ensures that our costs remain radically low and we need only ask you for the minimum of support. Your donation will support us this January and help us grow into the coming decade.
- Two nights rental of a dance theater with lighting designer: $1270
- Fiscal non-profit sponsorship in 2013: $200
- Rentals for 4 studio performances: $340
- Stipend to members of Artists Committee: $750
- Email marketing: $360
- Studio rental for Choreography Feedback Sessions: $30
- Website domain maintenance: $50

Other Ways You Can Help:
We understand that not everyone is able to make a financial contribution, but you can still help! Post about nachmo on Facebook, Twitter, etc. And come to our shows! Tickets HERE
 
For more information on how you can help, email us at info@nachmo.org.

story:
Escape From Titanic: a new play for young audiences

On April 14, 2013 (the 101st anniversary of Titanic's sinking), PLAY Conservatory will perform Escape From Titanic at Albuquerque’s N4th Theater.

Based on the Senate Hearing transcripts and survivor accounts, Escape From Titanic is a memory play told through the eyes of J. Bruce Ismay, president of the White Star Line at the time of the disaster and himself a survivor of the wreck.  Now at the end of his life, he anguishes over his role in the catastrophe, as voices from the past torment him. 

Nineteen young actors ages 11 to 18, who have been coached in ensemble work and various dialects, will play more than 70 roles.

This original play by Jonathan Dunski made its debut in 2012 with a production directed by Ryan Morris.  It is being developed specifically as a play for young audiences.

As much as $9,000 has already been invested in this play's development by PLAY Conservatory and the Albuquerque community.  We need your help to take it to the next level.

The plan for development includes:

  1. First draft: excerpts staged at a local, indepedent bookstore. April 2012. *COMPLETED*  
  2. Second draft: first performances with student actors at PLAY Conservatory Summer Stock. July 2012. *COMPLETED*
  3. Third draft: revised script staged with student actors.  PLAY Conservatory, special performance on April 14, 2013.
  4. Fourth draft: staged with Theatre for Young Audiences professional companies around the country. 2013 and 2014. 
  5. Submit for publication. 2015.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to contract a team of local Theatre artists, to rent a venue, and to revive and revamp the technical elements from 2012 production.

The budget:

Total cost of the project:

$6,485

Subtotal Space, Marketing & Materials: (venue rental, storage/truck rental, insurance, marketing/advertising, photocopying, stage management supplies, t-shirts, sets, props, costumes, makeup/hair, playbill, ticketing/box office, reception, Indiegogo rewards) $4,397

 

(In Kind: rehearsal space) $0

 

Subtotal Staff: (Director, Stage Mgr., Tech Director, Lighting Designer, Sound Designer, Costume Designer/Costumer, Videographer, Photographer, Box Office Mgr., Bookkeeper, Marketing Mgr., Playbill Ed.) $2,088

 

(In Kind: Producer, Assistant Stage Manager/Crew, Front of House Staff) $0

 

Total revenue, estimated:

$6,710

Subtotal Ticket Sales: $1,260

 

Subtotal Other: (tuition, merchandise, playbill ads, sponsorships, raffle) $1,450

 

Subtotal Indiegogo crowd-funding: $4,000

 

We have devised some cool mementos for our funders: autographed playbills, DVDs of the show, autographed scripts... even your name as producer!

Any funding in excess of our goals will be applied to the next phases of the play's development: pitching it to regional theatre companies and preparing the manuscript for publication.

Impact

PLAY Conservatory brings young people to the Theater.  Last year more than 140 young people trained with us, and some 3,800 people of all ages attended our plays.  Moreover, the five projects we produced contracted 28 teachers, artists and staff.  We play a vital role in the local creative economy.

Escape From Titanic will be published, and made accessible for every Middle School High School, Community Theater, and Regional Theater to produce.  It will be the first original play that has been developed by our company.

In alignment with PLAY Conservatory’s mission, this project fosters the development of confident, cooperative, creative young people.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word!  Please share our indiegogo campaign with your networks.  If you know a “Titaniac” history buff, please tell him or her about this project.  It should also appeal to Drama teachers and producers of Youth Theater.

And, if you are in the Albuquerque area on April 14, please come see the show.  We hope to sell out!

From the Director

The role of the Dramatist has been defined as putting “ordinary people in extraordinary circumstances.”  Even the greatest writer could not have imagined a story like the one that took place 100 years ago, when Titanic, the largest moving object in the world, sank 2.5 miles to the bottom of the sea, leaving 2,223 people to fight for their survival.  Each person’s story is extraordinary.  Perhaps that is why to this day we are still fascinated with the tragedy.  An inspiration for countless films, books, television shows, and Broadway musicals, Titanic has been rigorously studied and represented as both a work of history and numerous works of fiction based on history.

Writers of history have attempted to piece together a timeline of what actually happened that night – cause and effect – using primary documentation, including both written and oral accounts of passengers of the RMS Titanic.  The fictional representations of Titanic have attempted to fill in the gaps of what we don’t know.  What we do know is that there are two questions still debated a century later:  Why did so many people perish that night?  And who should be held accountable for it?

Our play asks these questions of its protagonist J. Bruce Ismay, CEO of the White Star Line, whom history has branded a coward for finding a place for himself in a lifeboat.  In our story Ismay is attempting to pass from his earthly life, but before he can, the spirits and voices of his fellow passengers must haunt him.  He is forced to recount his actions.  We are challenged to see the catastrophe through his eyes.

The passengers of Titanic would like to tell you their extraordinary stories.  As you witness them and consider judgment upon Mr. Ismay, I ask you to, please, “Be Mindful.”

         –Ryan Morris, Director of Escape From Titanic, 2012 production

About PLAY Conservatory

PLAY Conservatory is a 501(c)(3) tax-exempt organization.  Our mission is devoted to serving young people: we offer unique and challenging Theatre experiences for children and youth.  In doing so, we create works that play to every generation.  To learn more about us, go to:  www.playconservatory.org

Escape From Titanic: a new play for young audiences
On April 14, 2013 (the 101st anniversary of Titanic's sinking), PLAY Conservatory will perform Escape From Titanic at Albuquerque’s N4th Theater.
Based on the Senate Hearing transcripts and survivor accounts, Escape From Titanic is a memory play told through the eyes of J. Bruce Ismay, president of the White Star Line at the time of the disaster and himself a survivor of the wreck.  Now at the end of his life, he anguishes over his role in the catastrophe, as voices from the past torment him. 
Nineteen young actors ages 11 to 18, who have been coached in ensemble work and various dialects, will play more than 70 roles.
This original play by Jonathan Dunski made its debut in 2012 with a production directed by Ryan Morris.  It is being developed specifically as a play for young audiences.
As much as $9,000 has already been invested in this play's development by PLAY Conservatory and the Albuquerque community.  We need your help to take it to the next level.

story:
Musa, a new Festival and CLD's June Season in NYC

From June 12th to 22nd, Cherylyn Lavagnino, Zvi Gotheiner and Dusan Tynek, three choreographers whose creative instincts are driven by music, will come together to present a new festival entitled Musa, at the Baruch Performing Arts Center Nagelberg Theatre. 

For this festival, Cherylyn Lavagnino Dance is collaborating with violinist Jane Chung and cellist, Sarah Biber, to create an evocative new 45-minute ballet entitled "Treize en Jeu" for 13 dancers set to 3 movements of Franz Schubert's Piano Trio in E Flat Major for piano, violin, and cello that will be performed live on precious period instruments.

 

Facilitate the Collaboration

Because the heart of a CLD ballet is woven into the music as much as it is woven into the movement, it is imperative to work with the most talented and soulful collaborators in both fields. CLD’s June season at Baruch Performing Arts Center is no different, and so we are looking to you to help us support this collaboration between CLD and American Virtuosi so that we can offer to you, our loyal audience and community, an evening that highlights the powers of music, dance, and the collaborative human spirit.

 

"Treize en Jeu"...The New Ballet by CLD

The collaboration between CLD, Jane Chung, and Sarah Biber in performing "Treize en Jeu" this June will go beyond standard live accompaniment. The musicians will be highlighted in this incomparable Romantic-era work played on period instruments, including a Broadwood 1829 fortepiano. Also on the program is a duet entitled “Compadre” with music by Astor Piazzolla, performed by JP Jofre on an early 20th century bandoneón. It is a rare opportunity to hear these works performed live on period instruments, and these pieces by CLD will be an even more unique experience as dance, live music and period instruments come together.

The complexity of Schubert’s Trio in E Flat Major has lead Lavagnino to create an intricate visual composition responding to the emotional and rhythmic shifts of this rich masterpiece. Although Lavagnino's choreography is typically abstract and emotional, this ballet will explore some of the classical character dance from London's Royal Academy of Dance, placing it more in the pure movement/music genre. This gives Lavagnino an opportunity to employ the engaging medium of classical ballet while remaining within the expressive genre of contemporary dance. 

 

Any amount of support is greatly appreciated and will help us reach our goal of bringing to you engaging works of contemporary ballet with live music. We also hope you will join us at Musa this June at the Baruch Performing Arts Center to see what your support has helped us achieve. Thank you. 

 

Cherylyn Lavagnino Dance Mission Statement

 

Cherylyn Lavagnino’s mission is to create movement that engages an audience by aligning the rigor of ballet with the humanistic performance values of contemporary dance.  Her choreography uses the physically limiting state of dancing “en pointe” as a platform to delve into the range of human interaction and emotion.  The exaggerated classical ballet form is directed to express sensitive and honest portrayals by her dancers.  Music is paramount to Lavagnino’s creative process and its influence pushes and prods her imagery. Live music is a hallmark.

 

Cherylyn Lavagnino Biography

 

Cherylyn Lavagnino (Artistic Director/Choreographer) has an MFA in Dance from NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts, as well as a BA in Philosophy from USC. Lavagnino toured nationally as a soloist with the Pennsylvania Ballet.  She has performed a range of classical repertoire and contemporary work by choreographers including Balanchine, John Butler, Hans Van Manen, and Tere O’Connor, and the diversity of these experiences has informed the dialogue between classical and contemporary in her work with Cherylyn Lavagnino Dance.  Ms. Lavagnino has created over thirty works in the past fifteen years, and since 2000 the platform for her choreography has been Cherylyn Lavagnino Dance. Many of those works were created in collaboration with composers Scott Killian and Jane Chung. She regularly incorporates the performance of live music into her performances. The American Virtuosi, directed by Kenneth Hamrick and Ms. Lavagnino are developing a Dance and Live Music incentive to support their collaborative interests. Lavagnino’s choreography has been presented in New York City by Danspace Project at St. Mark’s Church, Dance Theater Workshop, Symphony Space, DanceNow/NYC, Kaatsban International Dance Center and The Joyce Theatre’s “Evening Stars” series. Ms. Lavagnino is a recipient of the Joyce Dutka Arts Foundation’s award for choreography and of a space grant residency from the Baryshnikov Arts Center and her choreography has been supported by the American Music Center’s Live Music for Dance grant and the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council’s Manhattan Creative Communities Fund.

Lavagnino is currently Chair of the Dance Department at NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts. She has been a full-time member of the NYU faculty since 1987. She teaches professional ballet locally in NYC and internationally; she is developing a creative exchange with the Beijing Dance Academy and Minzu University in Beijing. In recognition of her superior work, Lavagnino won New York University’s prestigious David Payne Carter Award for Excellence in Teaching in 2003.

story:
Who We Are

We envision a community transformed by art with movement, creativity, and performance that effect social change and personal transformation.
Our mission is to expresses the humanity of women and men by reflecting real life experiences through the art of dance. 


What We Need

We need your help!  Donate today!

As a nonprofit organization we need public support to become successful.  Investing in the arts is also investing in your own future.  

Expenses we need help covering:

Dancers $10,000; Choreographers $3,500; Lighting Designer$500; Costume Designer $500; Set Designer $500; Tech crew$1,000; Theater space $5,000; Rehearsal space $3,000; Office Space $3,600; Office expenses $1,500; Advertising $5,000 and more.  

Your help with allow us to transform our community into a better place. 


Our Past Impact 

March 29, 2015 Donation based performance at SafeHouse Arts
August 8-9, 2014  Performance inspired by organization Bay Positives (Free tickets to HIV organizations and members)
July 20, 2014 Became a member and walked in the AIDS Walk San Francisco
April 27, 2014 Free performance at Berkeley Community Center
October 18, 2013 Performed at Bay Positives Gala
August 24, 2013 Donation based Performance inspired by organization Breast Cancer Action (Free tickets to Breast Cancer organization and members)


The Show Must Go On
In the event that we don't raise enough money then many of our artists are generous enough to lower their compensation rate.  We also will have to find a way to cut back on other expenses.  

How You Can Help
If you can not donate then please help us spread the word.  
Share our Indiegogo campaign!
Visit our website: www.emotedancetheater.org
Like us on Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/EmoteDanceTheater
Follow us on Youtube: 
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0qAXBjINPOiv2C60fSgYEw

Sign-Up for our Newsletter:  http://www.emotedancetheater.org/subscribe/

story:
So, who are we and what are we doing?

We are Slick Babble Dance Project, and we need your help!


Slick Babble Dance Project is a small Contemporary Dance company established in 2015 by choreographer Emmeline Gonzalez-Beban. We are launching in December of 2015 with preparations for our premiere performance Feb 24-25th, 2016 at SAFEhouse Arts in San Francisco, CA. This work will be created as part of RAW (resident artist workshop).


This will be Emmeline’s second time producing an evening-length dance work through RAW (resident artist workshop), and the first of many times producing under her newly created company. She has previously created and shown choreographic works through various community outlets, The Garage SF, Shawl-Anderson Dance Center, LEVYdance, the OSU Department of Dance, and the American Dance Festival.


Emmeline Gonzalez-Beban’s choreography aims to enrich the lives of audience members by creating emotionally resonant dance works using psychologically-based choreographic methodology. In building the methodology of her process, she takes inspiration from psychological research on spiritual/religious belief, which explains how people perceive and create profound meaning from chaos.


Her newest evening-length work, "Us, Fumbling", will explore the abstraction of human interaction through this methodology. Using real experiences and emotions as a baseline inspiration, this choreographic offering aims to encapsulate the essence of real-life story in the absence of narrative structure.


Your donations through this campaign will be used towards expenses needed to produce the premiere of "Us, Fumbling" in February 2016.


Slick Babble Dance Project is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Slick Babble Dance Project must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.


What We Need & What You Get

We have 30 days to reach our goal of $954. Your donations will be used towards:

  • costumes

  • publicity materials

  • photography/videography

  • base-level performance/choreography payments

  • other miscellaneous expenses related to the show and company launch


Contributions that help us exceed our goal amount will go directly towards paying the choreographer and performers for their time and artistry! If only some of our goal amount is reached, donations will be used towards necessary materials for producing and publicizing the performance.


We want our supporters to feel like part of the Slick Babble Dance Project community! If you donate, you will receive extra perks to make you feel special!

  • Donate $10 or more and receive our heartfelt thank you and an acknowledgement as a donor on our company website.

  • Donate $20 or more and receive a personalized shout-out on our facebook page so the rest of the community knows how awesome you are.

  • Donate $50 or more and receive a custom sticker with the Slick Babble Dance Project logo.

  • Donate $100 or more and receive exclusive rehearsal footage emailed to you with a chance to reply with your feedback.

  • Donate $300 or more and receive a comp ticket to our premiere performance in February 2016.

  • Donate $500 or more and receive an exclusive invitation to attend a rehearsal for our upcoming performance.


The Impact

As a brand new company, Slick Babble Dance Project needs a little help to launch us into the dance scene. If you support us now, you will play a vital role in creating the company and bringing a fresh voice to Bay Area dance.

As a choreographer, Emmeline values the time and hard work of all her collaborators. In order to pay the dancers what they deserve, we need to start small and work our way up! In 2014, Emmeline successfully funded her first evening-length production as an independent choreographer through Kickstarter.com and was able to pay all the performers a substantial honorarium. Let’s keep this track record going! Help us turn passion into career by making a donation today!


If you're unable to donate at this time, you can still help!

  • If you value our vision and artistry, please share our campaign far and wide through social media or by emailing others who you think may be interested in making a donation.

  • Don’t forget to “like” our company page on facebook to stay connected to us and our artistic process.

  • If you are in or near San Francisco, please come see our premiere on Feb 24-25th, 2016 at SAFEhouse Arts!

The ImpactAs a brand new company, Slick Babble Dance Project needs a little help to launch us into the dance scene. If you support us now, you will play a vital role in creating the company and bringing a fresh voice to Bay Area dance.As a choreographer, Emmeline values the time and hard work of all her collaborators. In order to pay the dancers what they deserve, we need to start small and work our way up! In 2014, Emmeline successfully funded her first evening-length production as an independent choreographer through Kickstarter.com and was able to pay all the performers a substantial honorarium. Let’s keep this track record going! Help us turn passion into career by making a donation today!If you're unable to donate at this time, you can still help!
If you value our vision and artistry, please share our campaign far and wide through social media or by emailing others who you think may be interested in making a donation.
Don’t forget to “like” our company page on facebook to stay connected to us and our artistic process. 
If you are in or near San Francisco, please come see our premiere on Feb 24-25th, 2016 at SAFEhouse Arts!

story:
Steeping Pace cultivates warmth, tenderness, and curiosity. We imagine this dance as an offering - like a quiet moment over a cup of tea. Through inquiring into a series of senses, feelings, and connections that are often lost or overwhelmed by everyday stimuli,  our movement practice is grounded in patience. The continuous faculty of time, varied facets of space, and the many layers of relationships unfold as we learn to be gentle with ourselves and others toward the existence of life. Steeping Pace guides us to reexamine our habitual ways of living and breathing, returning us to the fundamental naturalness that we so desire but fear to engage.

Why am I making this work:

It is important to me that an artistic process coincides with the current life quest of the artist. Therefore, the following wondering inspired me to make this work: how as a (general) culture do people learn/practice to perceive and respond to their daily experiences and how under a larger temporal spectrum that people return to naturalness and find their own reality? I also wondered about within an intercultural contexts (me as a Taiwanese who have been through a diverse cultural exposures and now living and making movement arts in American), how I interact with my surroundings (including people who inhabited in the surroundings) and carry myself through it. The point where in my life the East and the West encountered, greatly shook my preconceived notion of collectiveness and individuality. The deep rooted belief of how I am supposed to walk through life and frame myself over time began to contradict, shatter, and reconstruct yet again with a more embodied integration. With that said, just as life flows on like a river, this work explores via movement and different sensorial experiences (vision, smell, hearing, tactile, taste) the shifting timescales and ongoing relationships people would have with one another. I bring the question of where people place their attention in a fast-paced and demanding world, and wanting to share this work with the audience as an offering - a quality break in our overstimulated daily life.

What have we been working on in the studio?

The studio time has been utilized to work on concept construction, dialogues about individual observations/struggles within a larger social and cultural contexts, movement exploration, and collective building of a certain timescale and feeling during the first phase (April-early July). Starting from the second week of July as movement, relationship, and dynamic for the work began to form, we shifted our focus onto the development of the movement, the cultivation of kinesthetic embodiment and human genuineness with each other that are essential to the core idea of the work. Further into the later half of August, we brought back again the dialogues about the image of tea and the underlying representation of the ritual of tea, the atmosphere derived from brewing and drinking tea, and the connection between the image of tea and the way of life. Through inquiring into a series of senses, feelings, and connections that are often lost by overstimulated daily life, my dancers and I devoted great amount of energy and time on cultivating the tender attention as performers and as humans.

Risks and challenges

I am interested in experiential ways of engaging audiences, and this is always challenging. By focusing on patience, empathy, and human warmth we are inviting audience members into an intimate experience, in which we are all present and vulnerable. I want to develop this project into a series that expands our inquiries and explores new relationships between performers, audience and community.

Other Ways you can Help

Come to the show! Purchase your tickets here: linkshall.ticketfly.com

story:
ABOUT THE ORGANIZATION

Take Wing And Soar Productions, Inc. is a women-led New York State, 501(c)3 Professional Theatre Arts Corporation, dedicated to supporting women, youth, and especially classically trained artists of color.  Take Wing And Soar Productions exists primarily to help classical actors of color to realize their full potential.

The mission of the theatre production company is to support emerging and professional classical artists of color, by fostering their artistic achievement and personal growth, by providing opportunities for career development, and by developing creative programming that fosters diversity in classical theatre.


What We Need & What You Get

JOIN TAKE WING AND SOAR as we celebrate our Tenth Year Anniversary Season.  We will produce four more events by the end of our season, including CLASSICAL CONVERSATIONS WITH ..., Shakespeare's THE WAR OF THE ROSES, Our TENTH ANNIVERSARY GALA CELEBRATION at the World famous COTTON CLUB and THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING EARNEST set in 1920s Harlem.

We are launching THIS CAMPAIGN to help cover the expenses of producing our 24 page GALA JOURNAL.

Join us as an TWAS Artist [$10] You get your name added to the congratulatory booster page of our 10th year Anniversary Journal.

Join us as an TWAS Friend [$25] You get your name added to the congratulatory booster page of our 10th year Anniversary Journal and a copy of the souvenir journal.

Join us as an TWAS Donor [$50] You get your name added to the Donor List of our 10th year Anniversary Journal; a copy of the souvenir journal; and a ticket to see our next mainstage production of The Importance of Being Earnest set in 1920’s Harlem.

Join us as an TWAS Patron [$100]  You get your name added to the Donor List of our 10th year Anniversary Journal; a copy of the souvenir journal; and a ticket to Take Wing And Soar’s 10th Year Anniversary Gala Celebration at the World Famous Cotton Club.

MANY THANKS FOR ALL THAT YOU DO!!

Visit us online at www.takewingandsoar.org

story:
Hi folks! Want to know more about us?

Mo.Re Open Space is a new programme willing to implement the contemporary dance field in Palermo (Sicily, Italy) by giving international artists residency space where to develop their works.

Resident artists will be asked to lead workshops which will be a unique opportunity for local dancers to keep training, exploring, be challenged and develop good networking contacts.

But in this process your help is crucial. As a totally self funded project, we need some support to publish advertising on news papers, dance websites and, yes, also on Facebook.

Unfortunately this is not a cheap mission. By giving even a very small contribution you will help launching a project that aims to promote the growth of art inside and outside our ardours but beloved Palermo by helping artists in their professional development.

 

Advertising costs varies a lot so every single cent can make the difference.

But money is not the only way, you can still contribute and give your support by spreading the word with your friends and on social media!

And don’t forget the Indiegogo  share tools!

 

HELP US GROW          HELP PALERMO           HELP THE ARTS

 

 

 

 

 

Vuoi saperne di più?

Mo.Re Open Space è un programma che punta ad implementare la danza contemporanea a Palermo, offrendo ad artisti internazionali uno spazio di residenza dove sviluppare i propri lavori coreografici.

Agli artisti residenti verrà richiesto di condurre dei workshop; un’opportunità unica per i danzatori locali per continuare ad allenarsi, esplorare, mettersi alla prova e sviluppare una buona rete di contatti internazionali.

Tutto questo sarà realizzabile grazie al tuo contributo.  Essendo un progetto interamente autofinanziato, abbiamo bisogno di supporto per pubblicizzare su giornali, siti di danza e, sì, anche su Facebook.

Dando anche un piccolo contributo puoi aiutare nel lancio di un progetto che ha l’obbiettivo di promuovere l’arte all’interno e all’esterno della nostra ostica ma amata Palermo, aiutando gli artisti nella loro crescita professionale.

Ogni singolo centesimo può fare la differenza.

Ma i soldi non sono l’unica strada, puoi sempre contribuire e dare il tuo supporto spargendo la voce tra tuoi amici e sui social media!

E non dimenticare gli Indiegogo share tools!

AIUTACI A CRESCERE              AIUTA PALERMO        AIUTA L’ARTE

story:
WHO WE ARE

We are dancers, actors, writers, choreographers, videographers, reality tv stars, ukelele players, and much, much more. We are also students at Eugene Lang College, at the New School, in our final semester. 

  • Alexa Andrade: Dance
  • Aliyah Hakim: Theatre
  • Clarke McCrae: Dance
  • Ella Wasserman-Smith: Dance 
  • Genevieve Parkington: Dance
  • Gideon Lazarus: Dance 
  • Justin Calvert: Theatre
  • Sarah Hogan: Theatre

     

    WHAT WE DO

    As students of a liberal arts college in the heart of New York City, we've had the extreme pleasure of participating in theoretical dialogues and embodied practices involving interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary performance. At present, we are each engaged in individual creative processes in a workshop setting facilitated by Neil Greenberg. These processes are the synthesis of our readings and research, our backgrounds and experiences, our influences and interests. We are dealing with a wide range of themes and problems in our works, such as identity, oddness, blackness, isolation, image-dominated culture, family history, pop music, and science fiction. The show we will be presenting, In Real Time, is either the beginning, middle, or end, of our explorations. It is not to be missed, as it is time-based and an will never happen again in quite the same way. 

     

    WHAT WE ARE ASKING

    Bringing our processes and practices from the studio to the greater public is absolutely necessary for their full realization. However, this a costly undertaking since it takes a lot of hands and equipment to produce a live show. Fortunately, we have already raised about half of our production costs through other means, but we need to raise another $1500 dollars to bring this show to life, and to you. This is what your generous contributions will go towards:

    • Paying our (exceptionally talented) lighting designer, stage manager, and crew
    • Lighting equipment (so you can see us)
    • Costumes, sets, props (adds pizzazz) 
    • Promotional materials (so that we can share our work with as many people as possible)
    • Paying the photographer and videographer  (something to remember us by)

    All contributors will have their name in the program surrounded by hearts and smiley faces, and will receive a heartfelt thank you in real life, if at all possible.

    Of course we understand that not everyone is currently in the position to make a donation to this campaign. We deeply value the many ways you support us and our work. The best way to show you care is to come to the show! And bring friends. 

     

    THE MAIN EVENT

    All contributions will go directly towards putting on our show, In Real Time. Here are the details:

    Who: Alexa Andrade, Aliyah Hakim, Clarke McCrae, Ella Wasserman-Smith, Genevieve Parkington, Gideon Lazarus, Justin Calvert, and Sarah Hogan

    What: 8 works in total, each around 12 minutes. 

    Where: Tishman Auditorium, University Center at The New School (65 5th Ave, New York, NY, 1003)

    When: April 7th and 8th @ 8 pm 

    Cost: FREE for New School students, faculty, alumni, $10 suggested donation for General Admission. 

    Lighting designer: Joe Levasseur

    Stage manager: Meredith Belis

     

    A million thanks!

    VIDEO by Mike Robinson

    PHOTOS by Rocco Morabito

story:
About White 

White is a magnificent play for 2-4 year olds, created by Andy Manley from the Scottish theatre company Catherine Wheels. With over 975 performances worldwide, White makes its Latin American debut through Monterrey, Mexico. 

Date:  Saturday November 28 and Saturday November 29, 2015, at 4:30 pm

Location: Pabellón El Universo inside Planetario Alfa, in San Pedro, Monterrey, Mexico.
For every 3 tickets bought through the perks, 1 will be given to a child from a low-income family (La Ciudad de Los Niños). 

'...one of the great experiences of a lifetime... Thank you for the best 40 minutes of my life...' -Sarah-Jessica Parker


'an utter delight no matter your age.' -The Times

COMO COMPRAR TUS BOLETOS: A través de los perks (LADO DERECHO) compra cada boletos individualmente para la función elegida.

_____________________________________________________________________________


White captures the imagination of children like no other theater show. Created by Andy Manley of the award-winning, internationally acclaimed children's theatre company Catherine Wheels, the world of White is full of birdsong and birdhouses. Two friends keep the eggs safe and make sure their world remains ordered, and most importantly, always White. Much to the two friends' shock and denial, color starts to appear... The public accompanies the friends in their initial struggle to reject that which is different and unexpected, until the eventual realization that different colors, just like our differences, enrich our lives.



The critics say:

'a palpable hit.' -Tom Dibdin: The Stage

'an utter delight no matter your age.' -The Times

'Gentle, charming and enchanting, White is a must-see.' -David Owens: Wales Online

'as cleverly executed as a conjuring trick.' -Lyn Gardner

'It was so beautifully constructed- the story, the plot (the moments of suspense!), the characters, and the theme. It amazes me how theatre for young children can take an idea and turn it into this terrific sensory experience.' -Picadilly Arts





The public says:

'The BEST play we have been to, for mummy and kids! So so clever and funny. Thank you so much.' (Adelaide 2011) -Jasper and Sophie

"Delight" is a great word for this show, moving from the ordered and safe world of White to an explosion of color. You've brightened my world today! (Melbourne 2012) -Mary Alice

'To all at WHITE- one of the great experiences of a lifetime. Thank you for the memories and the best 40 minutes of my life. Best of luck and much appreciated. (New York 2011) -Sarah-Jessica Parker


White in Monterrey, Mexico: 

We are looking for funding for two functions in Monterrey, Mexico. For every three tickets purchased, one will be donated to a child from a non profit school called "La Ciudad de Los Niños." La Ciudad de Los Niños (The City of the Children) serves children of very low-income families though a rigorous academic and human education, and is on a mission to keep children off the streets. It is extremely rare that these children have access to any cultural or artistic events of any kind. 

In partnership with the non-profit, LA-based Crayon Collection, we invite all attendees to the show to bring their spare art material that they do not use anymore. These will be re-purposed and distributed to the children of La Ciudad de Los Niños.



About me: 

My name is Susana Odriozola, and I am a social-impact driven, freshly-minted theater promoter who believes in the importance of art, the preciousness of childhood, and the innate goodness of people. 

About the team:

  • Catherine Wheels is an award-winning theater company from Scotland. 
  • Friday SS is a Monterrey-based production company with experience in producing large concerts and corporate events. 


Our Art Sponsors:




In cooperation with:





Our invited guests:






What We Need

We need $12,000 to make this happen. This covers the cost of two functions, one of which YOU will be able to attend! Yes, through the purchase of some of our perks, you can be one of the lucky few to see White in person. 

Here is a breakdown of our costs:


Fees: This includes the fees for two functions in Monterrey and the per diem per actor/manager traveling.

Production: This is for the local production company in Monterrey who works with the local municipality for permits and taxes, coordinates the arrival of the freight, arranges the technical requirements, and serves as a liaison between me and the venue.

Sound, Light, Tech: This is for the rental of the sound and light requirements, as well as the building of the internal structure necessary to create the space where White is produced.

Venue Rental: This is the fee for the rental of the space where White will be produced. Pabellón El Universo is located inside Planetario Alfa. Here is a link to the space: http://www.planetarioalfa.org.mx/renta-de-espacios.htm

Freight: The props and set of White travel all the way from the UK!

Travel & Lodging: This is for travel and lodging costs for the two actors and one stage manager. 



What You Get- 

PHOTOS + VIDEO OF THE EVENT:
 The proof is in the pudding. See for yourself the smiles you helped bring to this world.

TICKETS TO THE SHOW:
YES! YOU can go to see White in Monterrey! Find tickets through our perks. 
Please excuse us as each ticket must be purchased one by one! 

PRIVATE PHOTO SESSIONS:
Purchase a photo session for your family through our perks from these talented local photographers. Know that by buying the session through us, you are helping make White a reality. Ana Elena, Helio Villarreal, and Marcela López Fotografía have all generously donated a session.
Ana Elena: www.anaelena.mx
Helio Villarreal: www.heliophotographer.com
Marcela López: www.marcelalopezfotografia.com

ART FROM MONTERREY ARTISTS: 
The children assisting from La Ciudad de Los Niños will assist in creating a piece of art with Gabriela Rota, a Monterrey-based artist who has experience working with children. In Rota's signature whimsical style, this piece will surely be a hit.
www.gabrielarota.com
Ofrecido a USD $350

Five photograph prints by Mal de Mar, from the ongoing series ANYWHERENESS, are available through our perks. These simple, elegant compositions are the perfect play on light, shadow, movement, and stillness. All editions signed by author. Only 15 editions of each one made.
In perks: ANYWHERENESS 01 (2 available)



In perks: ANYWHERENESS 02 (1 available)


In perks: ANYWHERENESS 03 (2 available)


www.maldemar.com
Unframed photo prints
11" x 14" (28 cm x 35.5 cm)
Valor: USD $120. Ofrecido a USD $110


A mixed media piece by Mache Lopez, titled 'El Astado y su Toroide,' beautifully combines ink and watercolor. The softness of the color contrasts beautifully with the sharp geometries in black and white. At once mathematical and playful, this piece is a signature of Mache's style. UPDATE: This piece has been sold!
www.machelopez.com
Acuarela y tinta sobre papel
23" x 30.5" (59 cm x 77.5 cm)
Valor: MXN $6,500. Ofrecido a USD $375 



The Impact

When you contribute towards White in Monterrey, you are giving children from low-income families the gift of travel, color, and imagination, all without leaving their hometown. You are giving them a rare glimpse into a magical world, a glimpse that will remain ingrained in them and can later serve as the catalyst for change. 

More than a single theater show, White would be the seed for positive growth and appreciation of the arts. A single event that can lead to the ripple effect throughout a community deprived of art and theater.


Risks & Challenges

High quality artistic theater from the UK is probably not on people's list of 'Most Needed' in a city in a developing country. There are bigger fish to fry: crime, food availability, illiteracy... People might first feel obliged to contribute to medicine, education, and pressing environmental issues. Please do! Contribute towards these areas!

But art is important too. Although not a necessary tool for survival, for many art is a necessary tool for finding a purpose in life. For self-expression, for finding joy in the everyday mundane, for an escape from our 9 to 5 routines. 

Art may not be essential for survival, but what's the point of survival without art?


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this link! Help us make quality theater a reality for these impoverished children. Thank you so much for any support you are able to give.


_____________________________________________________________________________


Preguntas Frecuentes acerca de White en Monterrey


¿Para qué edades es la obra?

La obra fue diseñada para niños de 2 a 4 años, pero personas de todas las edades la disfrutarán mucho. Aparte de tener un nivel artístico muy alto, tiene un mensaje que todos podemos entender. 


¿Dónde compro mi boleto?

1. Métete a la página: igg.me/at/whiteenmonterrey (ya estás en la página ;))

2. Del lado derecho bajo “Perks” busca boletos para la función que deseas asistir.

3. Compra cada boleto individualmente.


¿A qué horas debo llegar?

Llega al menos 15 minutos antes de la hora agendada de la función. No hay asientos asignados. La obra dura aproximadamente 40 minutos incluyendo tiempo para fotos después de la función. 


Mis hijos no hablan inglés/Yo no hablo inglés,  ¿vale la pena que asista?

¡Claro! White se ha presentado por todo Asia y países Europeos donde no se habla inglés. El uso del idioma es mínimo, y no es necesario saber nada de inglés para entender o disfrutar de la obra. La comunicación es a través de gestos.


¡Ya compré mi boleto! ¿Dónde lo recojo?

El nombre que usaste para comprar cada boleto estará en la lista de invitados. No es necesario que lleves nada a la obra.


¿Qué es Crayon Collection? ¿Qué tipo de materiales juntan?

Crayon Collection es una asociación sin fines de lucro que busca re-distribuir materiales de arte, en específico crayones, para moverlos de un lugar donde sobran a un lugar donde faltan. Puedes traer crayones, lápices de color, lo que tengas que ya no uses. Vamos a donar el material de arte que se junte al Nuevo Amanecer y a La Ciudad de Los Niños.


¿Qué significa que La Ciudad de Los Niños y el Instituto Nuevo Amanecer sean invitados especiales?

La obra White tiene un mensaje de inclusión y de aceptación de lo diferente. Al apoyar nuestra campaña de crowdfunding a través de Indiegogo, estás haciendo posible que cerca de 90 niños de estas instituciones puedan ir a ver White.


No puedo ir pero quisiera apoyar de alguna forma,  ¿qué puedo hacer?

¡Gracias por tu entusiasmo! Tenemos tres sesiones fotográficas y tres obras de arte donados por fotógrafos y artistas regios. Este equipo está generosamente apoyando a White. Al tu comprar su arte a través de nuestra campaña de Indiegogo, estás ayudando a hacer White una realidad, y a llevar teatro a niños de La Ciudad de Los Niños y del Instituto Nuevo Amanecer. También puedes apoyarnos compartiendo nuestra liga en Facebook y enviando esta página por email a tus amigos.
story_txt:
About White 
White is a magnificent play for 2-4 year olds, created by Andy Manley from the Scottish theatre company Catherine Wheels. With over 975 performances worldwide, White makes its Latin American debut through Monterrey, Mexico. 

Date:  Saturday November 28 and Saturday November 29, 2015, at 4:30 pm


Location: Pabellón El Universo inside Planetario Alfa, in San Pedro, Monterrey, Mexico.


For every 3 tickets bought through the perks, 1 will be given to a child from a low-income family (La Ciudad de Los Niños). 



'...one of the great experiences of a lifetime... Thank you for the best 40 minutes of my life...' -Sarah-Jessica Parker



'an utter delight no matter your age.' -The Times
COMO COMPRAR TUS BOLETOS: A través de los perks (LADO DERECHO) compra cada boletos individualmente para la función elegida.

_____________________________________________________________________________






White captures the imagination of children like no other theater show. Created by Andy Manley of the award-winning, internationally acclaimed children's theatre company Catherine Wheels, the world of White is full of birdsong and birdhouses. Two friends keep the eggs safe and make sure their world remains ordered, and most importantly, always White. Much to the two friends' shock and denial, color starts to appear... The public accompanies the friends in their initial struggle to reject that which is different and unexpected, until the eventual realization that different colors, just like our differences, enrich our lives.







The critics say:
'a palpable hit.' -Tom Dibdin: The Stage
'an utter delight no matter your age.' -The Times
'Gentle, charming and enchanting, White is a must-see.' -David Owens: Wales Online
'as cleverly executed as a conjuring trick.' -Lyn Gardner
'It was so beautifully constructed- the story, the plot (the moments of suspense!), the characters, and the theme. It amazes me how theatre for young children can take an idea and turn it into this terrific sensory experience.' -Picadilly Arts








The public says:
'The BEST play we have been to, for mummy and kids! So so clever and funny. Thank you so much.' (Adelaide 2011) -Jasper and Sophie
"Delight" is a great word for this show, moving from the ordered and safe world of White to an explosion of color. You've brightened my world today! (Melbourne 2012) -Mary Alice
'To all at WHITE- one of the great experiences of a lifetime. Thank you for the memories and the best 40 minutes of my life. Best of luck and much appreciated. (New York 2011) -Sarah-Jessica Parker
White in Monterrey, Mexico: 
We are looking for funding for two functions in Monterrey, Mexico. For every three tickets purchased, one will be donated to a child from a non profit school called "La Ciudad de Los Niños." La Ciudad de Los Niños (The City of the Children) serves children of very low-income families though a rigorous academic and human education, and is on a mission to keep children off the streets. It is extremely rare that these children have access to any cultural or artistic events of any kind. 
In partnership with the non-profit, LA-based Crayon Collection, we invite all attendees to the show to bring their spare art material that they do not use anymore. These will be re-purposed and distributed to the children of La Ciudad de Los Niños.




About me: 
My name is Susana Odriozola, and I am a social-impact driven, freshly-minted theater promoter who believes in the importance of art, the preciousness of childhood, and the innate goodness of people. 
About the team:



Catherine Wheels is an award-winning theater company from Scotland. 


Friday SS is a Monterrey-based production company with experience in producing large concerts and corporate events. 





Our Art Sponsors:












In cooperation with:










Our invited guests:







   What We Need We need $12,000 to make this happen. This covers the cost of two functions, one of which YOU will be able to attend! Yes, through the purchase of some of our perks, you can be one of the lucky few to see White in person. 
Here is a breakdown of our costs:



Fees: This includes the fees for two functions in Monterrey and the per diem per actor/manager traveling.
Production: This is for the local production company in Monterrey who works with the local municipality for permits and taxes, coordinates the arrival of the freight, arranges the technical requirements, and serves as a liaison between me and the venue.
Sound, Light, Tech: This is for the rental of the sound and light requirements, as well as the building of the internal structure necessary to create the space where White is produced.
Venue Rental: This is the fee for the rental of the space where White will be produced. Pabellón El Universo is located inside Planetario Alfa. Here is a link to the space: http://www.planetarioalfa.org.mx/renta-de-espacios.htm

Freight: The props and set of White travel all the way from the UK!
Travel & Lodging: This is for travel and lodging costs for the two actors and one stage manager. 




What You Get- 

PHOTOS + VIDEO OF THE EVENT:
 The proof is in the pudding. See for yourself the smiles you helped bring to this world.TICKETS TO THE SHOW:YES! YOU can go to see White in Monterrey! Find tickets through our perks. Please excuse us as each ticket must be purchased one by one! PRIVATE PHOTO SESSIONS: Purchase a photo session for your family through our perks from these talented local photographers. Know that by buying the session through us, you are helping make White a reality. Ana Elena, Helio Villarreal, and Marcela López Fotografía have all generously donated a session.
Ana Elena: www.anaelena.mx

Helio Villarreal: www.heliophotographer.com

Marcela López: www.marcelalopezfotografia.com
ART FROM MONTERREY ARTISTS: The children assisting from La Ciudad de Los Niños will assist in creating a piece of art with Gabriela Rota, a Monterrey-based artist who has experience working with children. In Rota's signature whimsical style, this piece will surely be a hit.www.gabrielarota.comOfrecido a USD $350Five photograph prints by Mal de Mar, from the ongoing series ANYWHERENESS, are available through our perks. These simple, elegant compositions are the perfect play on light, shadow, movement, and stillness. All editions signed by author. Only 15 editions of each one made.In perks: ANYWHERENESS 01 (2 available)



In perks: ANYWHERENESS 02 (1 available)


In perks: ANYWHERENESS 03 (2 available)


www.maldemar.comUnframed photo prints11" x 14" (28 cm x 35.5 cm)Valor: USD $120. Ofrecido a USD $110

A mixed media piece by Mache Lopez, titled 'El Astado y su Toroide,' beautifully combines ink and watercolor. The softness of the color contrasts beautifully with the sharp geometries in black and white. At once mathematical and playful, this piece is a signature of Mache's style. UPDATE: This piece has been sold!
www.machelopez.comAcuarela y tinta sobre papel23" x 30.5" (59 cm x 77.5 cm)Valor: MXN $6,500. Ofrecido a USD $375 




The Impact
 When you contribute towards White in Monterrey, you are giving children from low-income families the gift of travel, color, and imagination, all without leaving their hometown. You are giving them a rare glimpse into a magical world, a glimpse that will remain ingrained in them and can later serve as the catalyst for change. 
More than a single theater show, White would be the seed for positive growth and appreciation of the arts. A single event that can lead to the ripple effect throughout a community deprived of art and theater.
   Risks & Challenges High quality artistic theater from the UK is probably not on people's list of 'Most Needed' in a city in a developing country. There are bigger fish to fry: crime, food availability, illiteracy... People might first feel obliged to contribute to medicine, education, and pressing environmental issues. Please do! Contribute towards these areas!
But art is important too. Although not a necessary tool for survival, for many art is a necessary tool for finding a purpose in life. For self-expression, for finding joy in the everyday mundane, for an escape from our 9 to 5 routines. 
Art may not be essential for survival, but what's the point of survival without art?




Other Ways You Can Help Please share this link! Help us make quality theater a reality for these impoverished children. Thank you so much for any support you are able to give.

_____________________________________________________________________________


Preguntas Frecuentes acerca de White en Monterrey

¿Para qué edades es la obra?
La obra fue diseñada para niños de 2 a 4 años, pero personas de todas las edades la disfrutarán mucho. Aparte de tener un nivel artístico muy alto, tiene un mensaje que todos podemos entender. 

¿Dónde compro mi boleto?
1. Métete a la página: igg.me/at/whiteenmonterrey (ya estás en la página ;))
2. Del lado derecho bajo “Perks” busca boletos para la función que deseas asistir.
3. Compra cada boleto individualmente.

¿A qué horas debo llegar?
Llega al menos 15 minutos antes de la hora agendada de la función. No hay asientos asignados. La obra dura aproximadamente 40 minutos incluyendo tiempo para fotos después de la función.

¡Ya compré mi boleto! ¿Dónde lo recojo?
El nombre que usaste para comprar cada boleto estará en la lista de invitados. No es necesario que lleves nada a la obra.

¿Qué es Crayon Collection? ¿Qué tipo de materiales juntan?
Crayon Collection es una asociación sin fines de lucro que busca re-distribuir materiales de arte, en específico crayones, para moverlos de un lugar donde sobran a un lugar donde faltan. Puedes traer crayones, lápices de color, lo que tengas que ya no uses. Vamos a donar el material de arte que se junte al Nuevo Amanecer y a La Ciudad de Los Niños.

¿Qué significa que La Ciudad de Los Niños y el Instituto Nuevo Amanecer sean invitados especiales?
La obra White tiene un mensaje de inclusión y de aceptación de lo diferente. Al apoyar nuestra campaña de crowdfunding a través de Indiegogo, estás haciendo posible que cerca de 90 niños de estas instituciones puedan ir a ver White.

No puedo ir pero quisiera apoyar de alguna forma,  ¿qué puedo hacer?
¡Gracias por tu entusiasmo! Tenemos tres sesiones fotográficas y tres obras de arte donados por fotógrafos y artistas regios. Este equipo está generosamente apoyando a White. Al tu comprar su arte a través de nuestra campaña de Indiegogo, estás ayudando a hacer White una realidad, y a llevar teatro a niños de La Ciudad de Los Niños y del Instituto Nuevo Amanecer. También puedes apoyarnos compartiendo nuestra liga en Facebook y enviando esta página por email a tus amigos.

story:
Yesterday, Once More: A Cambodian Musical

THE OPPORTUNITY


This year we have been given a wonderful opportunity - the support of Creative Partnerships Australia to help us raise the seed funds needed to create a new musical in Cambodia. 
The Cambodian Space Project is among just a handful of artists chosen to receive Creative Partnerships Australia’s 2017 MATCH Lab grant. This means that if I reach our fundraising goal of $10,000(AUS) it will be matched, dollar for dollar, by CPA. Your donation will be doubled!!


Yesterday, Once More aka Msel Mehn Mdong Tiet - spans the birth, death and resurrection of South East Asian rock’n’roll and explores the life story of one of its most beguiling and mysterious characters – Poev Vannary.

 

 

 

AN ESSENTIAL STORY TO TELL


Yesterday, Once More (aka Msel Menh Mdong Tiet) tells the story of Cambodia singing sensation Poev Vannary - starting out in 1970, a young, ‘liberated’, Khmer woman, Vannary, picks up a folk guitar plus a repertoire of American radio hits and sets her sights on the city. Arriving in Phnom Penh shortly after a coup d’état ousts Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Vannary’s rise to superstardom is as rapid and bewildering as the demise of Marshal Lon Nol’s corrupt and dysfunctional CIA installed regime and the ideological clashes and social shifts of the early 70’s. Cambodia is engulfed in brutal civil war and the nation’s capital soon becomes surrounded by communist forces. In April 1975, Phnom Penh falls to the Khmer Rouge and within days the regime drives the city’s entire population into forced labor camps in the countryside. Musicians and artists become targets of the genocidal regime as it sets about destroying culture in a perverse attempt to erase the past and install “Year Zero” - an agrarian Marxist utopia. From 1975-1979 Cambodia descends into darkness and Poev Vannary disappears along with and estimated 1.7 million people presumed murdered in the killing fields. The next decade proves almost as tough as the 70s; one long struggle to survive but out of the darkness hope returns. Music, art and culture survive and, while her whereabouts remain unknown, Poev Vannary’s hauntingly beautiful songs are rediscovered. It’s this music that returns to the airwaves, helping to heal and reconcile the tortured memories and broken lives of individuals and whole communities rebuilding a violently shattered past. Vannary’s life, loves, hopes and dreams are reimagined in this extraordinary musical that is as much a testimony to the power of the human spirit to overcome as it is a heartbreaking portrayal honoring a young singer’s life, and an entire generation, lost in one of the most devastating chapters in human history.

WITH YOUR SUPPORT WE ACHIEVE SOMETHING INCREDIBLE!

YOM will be the first musical of it's kind made in Cambodia. The opportunity to create music theatre in Cambodia means that we can make a huge impact on the contemporary arts scene and engage many artists in collaboration as well as reach across to a wide audience within Cambodian and beyond.

AN OVERWHELMING AND HEARTBREAKING STORY!

Yesterday, Once More is an exploration of music by radio stars like Poev Vannary and the little or unknown musicians and entertainers  of the Vietnam War era. In a live show that brings to the stage the “lost sounds” of vintage South East Asian rock’n’roll, it is a vibrant musical extravaganza set against the seismic sociopolitical shifts of the late 60’s through to the dramatic fall of Phnom Penh and Saigon in 1975, and the rediscovery of Cambodian rock - it's reissuing by record labels and filmmakers in the late 80’s and early 90’s and rediscovery by music lovers worldwide.

What We Need & What You Get

Okay let's talk about the money! Our aim is to raise 20k to kickstart the production and cover 12 months of development in Cambodia. We don't expect to create YOM on 20k only but will us the money to create the plays script, live and recorded music, set design, dancer and actor auditions and tests, research historical material, create video design for projections, videography for documentary presentation of the project, marketing and communications material to on sell the show to presenter partners internationally. The seed funding we raise for Yesterday, Once More will allow us to undertake all the development and rehearsal work in Cambodia, culminating with a premiere of the show in Phnom Penh.


Staging a professional musical is expensive!

In Cambodia, where contemporary theatre is virtually non-existent, staging Yesterday, Once More will need all the support we can get but this is a powerful story with fabulous music and a compelling rationale for the creation of such an ambitious work – we believe and will strive to make this incredible independent musical happen it but can only do this with YOUR SUPPORT.

A play requires actors and a director.  A ballet requires dancers and a choreographer.  A concert requires singers and a Musical Director.  A musical requires all 6, plus: assistant directors; repetiteurs; orchestrators; set, costume, lighting and sound designers; costume department; radio mic technicians; scenery builders; follow-spot operators; stage managers; chaperones (if there are children involved); hair and wigs department etc. as well as principal cast, ensemble, swings, orchestra, technical crew, front-of-house team, office staff, company managers and loads more.  All of these need paying, along with the team who wrote the piece in the first place.

Yesterday Once More is our third venture into producing music theatre and will be a work that we will develop entirely in Cambodia.

 

Income $ Expenditure $

Crowd sourcing

$10,000.00

6 months studio rental and staff fees.

$5,000.00

MATCH Lab

$10,000.00

Set building/painting materials

$2,500.00

KAMA contribution

$1,000.00

Additional artist per diems

$4,000.00

Corporate sponsorship

$1,000.00

In Cambodia – artist transport and accomodation

$2,000.00

 

 

Recording studio equipment hire

$3,500.00

 

 

Marketing & communications

$2,000.00

 

 

Video design for stage projection

$3,000.00

 

 

 

 

 

Total: $22,000.00

 

Total: $22,000.00

 

 

 

 

 

Perks! Perks! Over a dozen great Perks!!

  1. "Spaced-Out in Wonderland" CSP T-Shirt $20 
  2. Yesterday, Once More instrumental score "The Space Projectors" digital download - $18
  3. CSP's 5th album "Spaced Out in Wonderland "beautifully packaged on 180gsm vinyl $45
  4. CSP's 4th album "Electric Blue Boogaloo" (produced by Jim Diamond) - dig download $20
  5. Sticky Fingers Art Prints Cambodia limited edition screen print $100
  6. Sticky Fingers Print Art - two pack $180
  7. Superstar pack - 2 x albums, 2 x prints, 2 x t-shirts, $300
  8. An original painting or 10 hours Graphic Design work for your company or product $500
  9. Private concert - The Cambodian Space Project $2,000 (plus travel/accom/stage)
  10. Executive Producer credit 4 available $1500
  11. We will write a song for you - give us 1 word plus a description why this is important to you - it could be your lovers name, a city you love, favorite dish like "Prahok" or the name of your pet, car, or even yourself... we'll write and record and send you your own special Space Project song. 1k

What happens if we don't reach our funding goal?

Should we fall short of our target (let's hope not) we will still use the funds to work on Yesterday Once More but will re-prioritize aspects of the production - e.g. we can do a lot to progress this work by using smaller amounts for producing video documentary and audition and rehearsal sessions and/or writing and recording sessions to create a 'soundtrack' as a stand alone release. The production will continue to raise funds via grants and commissions and we have a proven track record  in self-producing - concept to stage - and achieving our production targets.

Why it's so important to make this a success

  • Yesterday, Once More is such an important historical story and is a ready made musical considering the incredible era of music the narrative covers. This gives us the chance to create meaningful and compelling storytelling that is as haunting and confronting as it is uplifting and inspiring. We believe the process of making YOM will be a success in itself - pioneering contemporary theatre in Cambodia and bringing international opportunities for all the artists involved as well as inspiring others to create new works that will add quality and sustainability to the creative community in Cambodia. 
  • Yesterday, Once More will be the third music theatre work the CSP has staged. If you've followed CSP's development over the last 3 years you'll be aware that we first shape-shifted from  rock'n'roll band to music theatre with Galaxy Khmer - presented in Berlin and Norway in 2014 then in 2015, our psychedelic rock opera Cosmic Cambodia premiered at the Sydney Festival. 
  • The Cambodian Space Project has been a most unexpected and exhilarating experience for all involved. Now in it's 7th year, we are able to consider works like Yesterday, Once More: A Cambodian Musical simply because of all the support and encouragement our wonderful friends, families, fans and supporters have given the project. It's this generosity of spirit that keeps us flying! and allows us the inspiration as well as the resources to create music and art that is so important in showing strength, fortitude and the incredible natural talents of Srey Channthy and chart the incredible distance we've all come. Most of all it's all about bringing communities together and celebrating in a totally cosmic way - vive! Cambodian Rock'n'Roll!

  • As an infant, Cambodian Space Project frontwoman Kak Channthy grew up in war
    and poverty. Here she and her soldier father, are pictured listening to the radio. 


Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk is that one of the key performers or cast members is not available for either a show or part or all of the production. For this reason we plan to create a script and musical that can go ahead with alternating performers and tech team, this includes replacing key performer roles if necessary - THE SHOW MUST GO ON.
Our BIG challenge is to create a professional and popular musical that may be managed and performed by new teams over the coming years. This will create ongoing opportunities for new artists and presenters in Cambodia and abroad to work with the YOM production and concept developed in this important first edition.
An ongoing challenge is "keeping the wheels spinning" especially when it is for a project that will take 1-2 years to fully develop from concept to stage and is being made in Cambodia where funding and resources are little or none. We strive to find a balance between keeping our arts workers employed on the project and finding the resources - time, money, equipment, rehearsal space - to fully trial ideas, test performances and produce a stage ready work. Yesterday, Once More is our most ambitious project to date and therefore challenging but we believe that we are one of the few contemporary arts companies in Cambodia who can achieve the vision of the kind of musical described here

  • With 7 years experience, the CSP team has produced 5 albums, 1 documentary movie, numerous videos, international tours, collaborations and music theatre productions
  • For YOM we intend to fund our own studio/theatre space for use over 12 months as well as cutting back hire fees by purchasing and installing as much of the shows equipment ourselves. This will allow us to build resources for YOM and future theatrical shows. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help: Much of CSP's success over the years has come from inkind support and word-of-mouth promotion of our work and activities. We've very grateful for all the professional pro bono work CSP has attracted from others who are inspired to help us achieve our vision.
For YOM we're calling on we're seeking collaborators who may have skills in media design, theatre production, dance, music, dramaturgical and script writing skills. Workshops will begin in Cambodian early 2018. If this interests you then please email: thecambodianspaceproject@gmail.com
