Total: $22,000.00


 
 
 
 


 
Perks! Perks! Over a dozen great Perks!!

"Spaced-Out in Wonderland" CSP T-Shirt $20 
Yesterday, Once More instrumental score "The Space Projectors" digital download - $18
CSP's 5th album "Spaced Out in Wonderland "beautifully packaged on 180gsm vinyl $45
CSP's 4th album "Electric Blue Boogaloo" (produced by Jim Diamond) - dig download $20
Sticky Fingers Art Prints Cambodia limited edition screen print $100
Sticky Fingers Print Art - two pack $180
Superstar pack - 2 x albums, 2 x prints, 2 x t-shirts, $300
An original painting or 10 hours Graphic Design work for your company or product $500
Private concert - The Cambodian Space Project $2,000 (plus travel/accom/stage)
Executive Producer credit 4 available $1500
We will write a song for you - give us 1 word plus a description why this is important to you - it could be your lovers name, a city you love, favorite dish like "Prahok" or the name of your pet, car, or even yourself... we'll write and record and send you your own special Space Project song. 1k


What happens if we don't reach our funding goal?
Should we fall short of our target (let's hope not) we will still use the funds to work on Yesterday Once More but will re-prioritize aspects of the production - e.g. we can do a lot to progress this work by using smaller amounts for producing video documentary and audition and rehearsal sessions and/or writing and recording sessions to create a 'soundtrack' as a stand alone release. The production will continue to raise funds via grants and commissions and we have a proven track record  in self-producing - concept to stage - and achieving our production targets.
Why it's so important to make this a success

Yesterday, Once More is such an important historical story and is a ready made musical considering the incredible era of music the narrative covers. This gives us the chance to create meaningful and compelling storytelling that is as haunting and confronting as it is uplifting and inspiring. We believe the process of making YOM will be a success in itself - pioneering contemporary theatre in Cambodia and bringing international opportunities for all the artists involved as well as inspiring others to create new works that will add quality and sustainability to the creative community in Cambodia. 
Yesterday, Once More will be the third music theatre work the CSP has staged. If you've followed CSP's development over the last 3 years you'll be aware that we first shape-shifted from  rock'n'roll band to music theatre with Galaxy Khmer - presented in Berlin and Norway in 2014 then in 2015, our psychedelic rock opera Cosmic Cambodia premiered at the Sydney Festival. 
The Cambodian Space Project has been a most unexpected and exhilarating experience for all involved. Now in it's 7th year, we are able to consider works like Yesterday, Once More: A Cambodian Musical simply because of all the support and encouragement our wonderful friends, families, fans and supporters have given the project. It's this generosity of spirit that keeps us flying! and allows us the inspiration as well as the resources to create music and art that is so important in showing strength, fortitude and the incredible natural talents of Srey Channthy and chart the incredible distance we've all come. Most of all it's all about bringing communities together and celebrating in a totally cosmic way - vive! Cambodian Rock'n'Roll!

As an infant, Cambodian Space Project frontwoman Kak Channthy grew up in warand poverty. Here she and her soldier father, are pictured listening to the radio. 


Risks & Challenges
The biggest risk is that one of the key performers or cast members is not available for either a show or part or all of the production. For this reason we plan to create a script and musical that can go ahead with alternating performers and tech team, this includes replacing key performer roles if necessary - THE SHOW MUST GO ON.Our BIG challenge is to create a professional and popular musical that may be managed and performed by new teams over the coming years. This will create ongoing opportunities for new artists and presenters in Cambodia and abroad to work with the YOM production and concept developed in this important first edition.An ongoing challenge is "keeping the wheels spinning" especially when it is for a project that will take 1-2 years to fully develop from concept to stage and is being made in Cambodia where funding and resources are little or none. We strive to find a balance between keeping our arts workers employed on the project and finding the resources - time, money, equipment, rehearsal space - to fully trial ideas, test performances and produce a stage ready work. Yesterday, Once More is our most ambitious project to date and therefore challenging but we believe that we are one of the few contemporary arts companies in Cambodia who can achieve the vision of the kind of musical described here

With 7 years experience, the CSP team has produced 5 albums, 1 documentary movie, numerous videos, international tours, collaborations and music theatre productions
For YOM we intend to fund our own studio/theatre space for use over 12 months as well as cutting back hire fees by purchasing and installing as much of the shows equipment ourselves. This will allow us to build resources for YOM and future theatrical shows. 


Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help: Much of CSP's success over the years has come from inkind support and word-of-mouth promotion of our work and activities. We've very grateful for all the professional pro bono work CSP has attracted from others who are inspired to help us achieve our vision.For YOM we're calling on we're seeking collaborators who may have skills in media design, theatre production, dance, music, dramaturgical and script writing skills. Workshops will begin in Cambodian early 2018. If this interests you then please email: thecambodianspaceproject@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

     PulsePDX began in May of 2011 with the goal of creating a unique dance fitness experience that would combine the fun of a nightclub with the health benefits of a fitness center. Along the way, though, we realized that PulsePDX is so much more than just a place to work out. It is a place where people rediscover the joy of dance and movement, where people reach health goals they didn’t think possible, where new friendships and connections are created daily, where people deal with the stress of their everyday life, and where they celebrate life’s special occasions. It is both nightclub-style fitness and a very special community.

     After renting venues by the hour to hold our nightclub-style fitness classes, we have decided to make the leap and move into our very own building. Taking on this new opportunity will allow us to continue to improve our customer experience, add new and exciting classes, and increase our charitable activities. Luckily, the perfect building was located, but it needs some work! Most notably, it needs a good dance floor that will provide the right amount of spring in order to be easy on people’s joints, and it needs to be impervious to changes in temperature and humidity so students always have just the right amount of traction for the best class experience.

 

What We Are Doing & What You Get

     Moving into a new space and designing it from the ground up to best meet our community's needs and desires is a tremendous undertaking. There are many important elements that we are incorporating to make each PulsePDX class experience the best possible: high-tech lights, an amazing sound system, a stage for easy viewing, a comfortable waiting room, a water fountain for easy sport bottle refills, a fast check-in area, good climate control, and beautiful new bathrooms. While all of these elements are important, none are as important to the quality of our classes as the dance floor! Whether we are dancing around in Zumba®, barefoot in willPower&grace®, or on our mats in Melt® or Burn, a good floor makes all the difference in both the safety and appeal of the class.

     Many of you have asked how you can get involved.  As we complete the build out of the PulsePDX building and further foster the PulsePDX community, we are excited to offer you the chance to be a part of it!  We are not just asking for help in creating the perfect PulsePDX dance floor experience, we have some very unique gifts and perks to offer in exchange for your support that will only be available through this campaign.  From a specially designed t-shirt by Julio Aleman, to an exclusive launch event for contributors only, to an action photo shoot by Megan Henson Photography under the Pulse lights, these are items on which you won’t want to miss out! If you want to join the Pulse team in choosing and creating a class, or always be guaranteed the best cubby or parking spot available, we have something for you, too!

     Any funds raised during this campaign will be applied to the approximate cost to install the new dance floor.  Join us in this campaign with the satisfaction of knowing you helped make it possible for everyone to enjoy the amazing classes and PulsePDX community for many years to come.

 

The Impact

     Since our inception, giving back to our community has been one of our company goals. In our first year of business we helped to raise close to $12,000 for charities such as Passionately Pink for the Cure, the Special Olympics of Oregon, The Autism Society, and the Jefferson Dancers. It is our hope that our new space will give us many more ways we can play an active role in supporting charities and local non-profits. Having a nicely sprung, durable floor will allow us to hold a range of events from Zumbathons to auctions, dinners, fashion shows, and live performances.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

     On behalf of the PulsePDX community, we appreciate any support and hope you will join us in “Raising our Pulse” while getting some fun and unusual gifts in return. You can help us spread the word about this campaign and invite your friends to get in on the perks by sharing on Facebook, sending around the link, or by taking advantage of the “share” tools provided by Indiegogo.

See you on the dance floor soon!

 

With much appreciation,

The Pulse Team

www.pulsepdx.net

www.pulsepdx.net

story:
Short Summary

The BridgePHL was born out of a need to address the devastating racial issues that are challenging our communities today. We need more love! We need more truth! We need to listen and be heard! We need to not be afraid to open the door with compassion, and accept whatever comes of the conversation.

That's what we are doing with our NEW theatre festival: 'Creating Dialogue and Exploring Perspectives about Race, Diversity and Bias'.

Because it's important. Because it's hard to talk about. Because it's the truth. But jumping in together, hand in hand, to face the challenge is what we believe will begin the healing process for everyone.

Theatre is the most effective artistic medium to hold safe space for conversations about race. Theatre holds the mirror up to life and asks the audience to reflect, experience and create an opinion. We hope to do just that with The BridgePHL.

The BridgePHL will debut October 6 -9, 2016.

What We Need & What You Get

The BridgePHL will be needing funding to offset the costs of promotion ( fliers, postcards, posters, possible radio plugs and online advertising) , paying a stage manager and renting the Rotunda

The BridgePHL will also be offering financial assistance to the participating companies/individual artists so they can pay themselves, their actors.and their designers. Any and all funds, whether we make our goal or not, will go to these purposes.

The Impact

We as theatre artists are compelled to voice our thoughts and create art that reflects unity, collaboration, connection and peace between all peoples. There is power in this artistic work and as a contributor, you will be helping to raise awareness and understanding at a time when it is most needed.

Risks & Challenge

We are bringing a difficult subject to the table - the 'race' conversation is riddled with resentment, misunderstandings, regret and hurt. Our challenge is to fearlessly open this dialogue, acknowledging it's difficulty for many, and say 'your feelings are valid; let's find a solution'

Other Ways You Can Help

There are so many ways you can help The BridgePHL! If you cannot donate yourself, you can share this Indiegogo campaign on your facebook page, twitter and instagram - spread the word about what we are trying to do - word of mouth and grassroots growth is always helpful.

You can volunteer to hand out fliers, be a PR person or help backstage during production.

Also - Reflect, take up some brick and mortar and build yourself a bridge to connect with the human family.

story:
A Word on the Let's Go There Collective

"Don't even go there."

Originating in 2009 as a writers/artists group of women of color and their allies, the Let's Go There Collective expanded into the area of theater in 2012. We are women from Palestine, the African Diaspora, Puerto Rico, Cuba, Haiti, Sicily, and Iraq who have decided that telling the stories of our people, of our struggle for liberation and our resistance, is central to our humanity and consequently our art.

We believe that art (in this case theater) belongs to all of us and exists as a means of communicating the beauty and pain of our lives, and at the same time what we need to know and do collectively as we engage in struggle day to day.

We believe that artistic exploration, in the theater, on the written page, in music, or on the canvas, should be accessible to everyone including folks working tough schedules, organizers, moms, teachers, youth, our elders--  folks with big life commitments.

We believe that art, in and of itself, is not an end, but part of the journey of struggle. It is and should be part of our daily lives. It should educate and inspire. Perhaps most importantly, it should be a leaping off point for collective exploration, discussion, and ultimately action.

Our first theatrical production will be the premiere performance of an original play on Palestinian political prisoners written, directed, and acted by members of our collective.

We are fundraising for this production as well as for future theatrical projects this summer.

We are trying to raise $2000 by May 1st. Your contribution will go toward production costs including venue, lighting design, costumes, set, programs, and flyers.

With this in mind, we invite you to join us not only for a "theatrical experience", but to engage/question/discuss/organize(!) after each of our shows.

Let's go there!

 

**Artwork above by Dara Bayer and Laila Murad

story:
BOOTS questions the connection between the female body, the power of nature and sexual abuse trauma. In Liz and Willow’s friendship we dispel the myth of the patriarchal routes to motherhood. How women ‘should’ be. Liz is in her 70s and has a controlling husband. She has never been allowed real freedom. Willow is beginning her journey of choice and true empowerment. They are learning together in their given circumstances.

SO....

Can you make a contribution to our crowdfunder?

If the answer is YES you will be helping to raise awareness for those who have suffered abuse, those who are still suffering and those who have been effected by infertility - you WILL be encouraging those who come to see the play, and who have been affected, to seek help with organisations we will be working with.

If you can, please donate any amount, or buy a perk!

 

 

Who are we?

We are a lovely bunch of very hard working creatives!

Producer: Small Things Theatre Co / Philip Scott-Wallace 

Writer: Jessica Butcher

Co writer: Sacha Voit

Actor: Tanya Loretta Dee

Actor: Illona Linthwaite

Music: Jack Wyllie (Portico Quartet)

 

What We Need & What You will Get!

 

We need to raise £5000 by December.

We need to raise £8,000 overall - the second stage of raising money will be at a charity event on December 17th at the o2 Academy in Islington, London - it is set to be a great event so get involved people! Look out for the launch of the event mid November!

All money will be used for the following:  cover marketing coats, stage craft, creatives payment, hires costs, rehearsal/performance costs, and of course to connect to those who have been effected by the play, to the charities and support groups we will be working with.

PERKS & DONATIONS:

We have some wonderful perks!

We are working very closely with the internationally acclaimed artist Louis Masai; he is a environmental artist known for raising awareness against the extinction of nature and endangered animals - a great link to our show! To all of us on the team, nature is an important part of healing, and so we wanted to work withs someone who was as passionate about connections to nature as we are.

 We are VERY lucky to have some of his art as rewards!

We also have badges, rehearsal experiences and much more! Have a look to the right of the page for full list of perks.

Feel free to buy a perk, or you can make a donation. All that is received is helpful and goes towards making this show happen. YOUR CONTRIBUTION WILL MAKE A DIFFERENCE!

 

The Impact...

Every member of our team is extremely passionate and active in using theatre to try and make the world a better place - sounds cheesy, but it is true! Through our work we all will be raising awareness for sexual abuse, fertility and the positive benefits of nature.

 We believe that theatre has the power to make a difference, to encourage, to empower, to influence and to create change. Wouldn't it be phenomenal if people who came to see this play were able to be inspired, seek help and support? We are want the audience to respond.

 

Risks & Challenges...

Putting on a play with trigger themes is a risk, it carries some responsibility. We hope to raise awareness only, and to share our own stories - a risk in itself! We hope people will come to all our shows in March; we are at a wonderful venue that has faith on our work, our story and our truths - we hope you will have faith in us too! 

Our main challenge is to get this funding - any logistical problems can be easily rectified as we are a well connected team with links to rehearsal spaces and venues etc.

Other Ways You Can Help...

If you cannot contribute, PLEASE do spread the word, on all social media sites, blogs, word of mouth.​ Talk, discuss, share! If you have any questions do get in touch with us!

Our main challenge is to get this funding - any logistical problems can be easily rectified as we are a well connected team with links to rehearsal spaces and venues etc.

story:
STANDBY is about making connections, finding love, and traveling on.

After successful runs in the NYMF 2013 and 2012 Fringe Festival Standby has been given another opportunity. We have been chosen as part of the OVERTURES series in partnership with the Gallery Players. OVERTURES offers staged readings of six new musicals, fostering the creation of new musical theatre and supporting the talented composers and writers as they refine their work.  

We have been writing- and rewriting- and creating a story we are eager for you to see. We are looking to raise $1600 to help us put together a team of directors, musicians, and a fantastic show.

Every little bit helps. Every dollar goes to a creative getting paid for their hard work, or for a copy of their script, or for a musician to play, or for help in getting the word out. Every single dollar helps.

Perhaps you don’t have the money right now. Maybe someone you know does. There are so many ways you can help. Spread the word! From NYCFRINGE to the New York Musical Theatre Festival, Standby has come a very long way. We aren’t done yet.  Help us allow Standby to soar once again.

“STANDBY delivers a first-class experience.” ~Time Out New York

“Best of The Festival [Encore Series 2012]” ~New York International Fringe Festival

“With its brilliant concept and flawless execution, STANDBY is one of the best new shows out this season.” ~Letters From the Mezzanine

“If there is one choice that you have to make today, it should be to buy a one-way ticket to STANDBY at this year’s NYMF. This is a trip you’ll never regret.” ~newyorktheatre.com

STANDBY started as an exploration of karma.The idea that when you do something good, something good will happen to you in return, and when you do something bad, same deal. But what if you did something bad to yourself? Do you get a double dose of bad or do you have to do something good to balance it out?

In 2012 Standby was a success at the New York International Fringe Festival and extended for the ENCORE SERIES. 

In 2013 Standby was  an Official Selection of the New York Musical Theatre Festival 2013 Next Link Project and had a wonderful, nearly sold out run full of laughter, tears, cheers, and standing ovations.  Our lead, Darren Ritchie, won a NYMF Award for excellence in his role of Richard.

Standby

Venue:The Gallery Players 
Schedule: May 2 & 3, 2016

Standby runs 90 minutes with no intermission.

Cast

Seth Blum, Alex Goley*, Jared Joseph*, Michael Liscio*, Elena Ricardo*, Ashley Rose* (*AEA)

Production Credits

Directed by Carlos Armesto

Music by Amy Baer and Keith Robinson

Lyrics by Mark-Eugene Garcia and Alfred Solis

Book by Mark-Eugene Garcia and Alfred Solis

Based on a Concept by Alfred Solis
story_txt: STANDBY is about making connections, finding love, and traveling on.After successful runs in the NYMF 2013 and 2012 Fringe Festival Standby has been given another opportunity. We have been chosen as part of the OVERTURES series in partnership with the Gallery Players. OVERTURES offers staged readings of six new musicals, fostering the creation of new musical theatre and supporting the talented composers and writers as they refine their work.  We have been writing- and rewriting- and creating a story we are eager for you to see. We are looking to raise $1600 to help us put together a team of directors, musicians, and a fantastic show.Every little bit helps. Every dollar goes to a creative getting paid for their hard work, or for a copy of their script, or for a musician to play, or for help in getting the word out. Every single dollar helps.Perhaps you don’t have the money right now. Maybe someone you know does. There are so many ways you can help. Spread the word! From NYCFRINGE to the New York Musical Theatre Festival, Standby has come a very long way. We aren’t done yet.  Help us allow Standby to soar once again.“STANDBY delivers a first-class experience.” ~Time Out New York“Best of The Festival [Encore Series 2012]” ~New York International Fringe Festival“With its brilliant concept and flawless execution, STANDBY is one of the best new shows out this season.” ~Letters From the Mezzanine“If there is one choice that you have to make today, it should be to buy a one-way ticket to STANDBY at this year’s NYMF. This is a trip you’ll never regret.” ~newyorktheatre.comSTANDBY started as an exploration of karma.The idea that when you do something good, something good will happen to you in return, and when you do something bad, same deal. But what if you did something bad to yourself? Do you get a double dose of bad or do you have to do something good to balance it out?In 2012 Standby was a success at the New York International Fringe Festival and extended for the ENCORE SERIES. In 2013 Standby was  an Official Selection of the New York Musical Theatre Festival 2013 Next Link Project and had a wonderful, nearly sold out run full of laughter, tears, cheers, and standing ovations.  Our lead, Darren Ritchie, won a NYMF Award for excellence in his role of Richard.StandbyVenue:The Gallery Players Schedule: May 2 & 3, 2016Standby runs 90 minutes with no intermission.CastSeth Blum, Alex Goley*, Jared Joseph*, Michael Liscio*, Elena Ricardo*, Ashley Rose* (*AEA)Production CreditsDirected by Carlos ArmestoMusic by Amy Baer and Keith RobinsonLyrics by Mark-Eugene Garcia and Alfred SolisBook by Mark-Eugene Garcia and Alfred SolisBased on a Concept by Alfred Solis

story:
Visit our website to learn more about the Artists, the Creative team, proposed venues and to hear sample tracks from Talking To Devon! 


ABOUT THE PROJECT: 

“Talking to DeVon” is a multi-layered, funny, complex yet light-hearted musical that explores the possibilities of trust, openness, respect and generosity between strangers. It is a Multi-Media Musical that features spoken word, song, sound and video installations, dance, fine art, and live percussion all set to an original digital trance-house music soundtrack.

 

“Talking to DeVon” takes you on a journey to explore human connectedness in a place that doesn’t usually promise inspiration: the DMV (Department of Motor Vehicles), anywhere USA. At the DMV, we encounter three women, complete strangers who’ve been patiently standing in the same line for an hour. Thanks to one simple yet unexpected act of kindness, they start to speak candidly with one another and share details of their lives. As fate would have it, all three women have heard of the profound L’il Black Taoist, and their serendipitous meeting at the DMV no longer seems like a simple chance encounter. For these three women, heartfelt conversation with strangers in an ordinary setting becomes a life changing event.


WHO IS DEVON?

Devon was Leisha Lashawn’s younger brother. At the end of 2008, Leisha lost Devon in a devastating car crash. She says that:  "Devon's death, has forever changed me and everyone who knew him. In 2007, I began to experiment with digital music by making loops that I could play alongside my drums. I played those early loops DeVon, He loved the sound and he encouraged me to continue."

 

"In life, DeVon inspired me,  and now even though he has moved on, he continues to do so. This play is more than a simple musical, it is my grieving process made manifest and it is a celebration of Devon’s life. For Devon, there were no strangers, just friends he hadn’t met yet.” 

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU'LL RECEIVE

We need $7000 to pay for:
The Theater Rental and Technical Support
Liability Insurance
Set Production
CD Production (Music Mastering and CD creation)
Supplies: 

 

Your generosity will fund our dreams. In exchange for your pledge, you'll receive the unique gifts outlined to the right.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends about the campaign, Like us our Facebook Page and follow us on Twitter. Spread the word to your friends. The message of Talking to Devon is on of "Trust and Kindness to Others". To spread the word is to spread good cheer!

 

 

ABOUT THE ARTIST:

 Leisha LaShawn has been an active performing artist, and percussionist  for more than twenty years, and a Licensed Massage Therapist and Chi Nei Tsang Practitioner for thirteen of those years. 

 

 THE IMPACT OF THIS PROJECT

"Talking to Devon" will entertain the public, and allow us the access to present fun and dynamic workshops in every city we visit. From "Harnessing the Power of the Breath", to "Creative Writing", our intent is to create a long-lasting impression in each community, to allow strangers to connect with one another and to offer and experience kindness. Our goal is that these activities will be a cumulatively healing and positive experience for all the participants, ourselves too! Our twitter and Facebook pages will become a community forum to allow participants to continue talking with each other and will perpetuate Five Elemental theory for all visitors.

story:
WHO?

I'm Wendy Kinal, known in some circles as Happy the Sad Clown.  I don't know when I became a clown.  Somewhere in New York City it happened.  I slowly discovered that my favorite form of theater had no fourth wall.  It has become something like a spiritual practice for me.  Raunchy, raucous, silly and spiritual.

WHAT?

I studied with Lume Teatro in 2003, 2005, and 2006.  A good friend called me up while I was out of town working in 2002.  I'll never forget it. He said "Lume is having workshops in February.  In Brazil.  We should go."   I looked at the check I had just gotten out of my mail box for the gig I was doing...and I said yes.  And I'm so glad I did.

Lume is a group of performers who create art and processes of creation.  They are anthropologists of theater, diving deep into kinesthetic and verbal inquiry about the human in performance.  Their workshops have become so popular that there is an application process to join them.  I've been selected to attend O Palhaco e o Sentido Comico do Corpo (The Clown and the Comic Feeling) in February 2014.   It is led by Ricardo Puccetti, who was the first person I met from Lume way back in 2002 in Massachusetts.   He is an amazing clown, all heart and soul and nonsense.

WHY?

I am in a phase in my life where I want to take my art to the next level. This workshop will kickstart that process.  I want to develop my theatrical clown work and continue to be a better artist.  I'm currently creating a clown-theater piece as part of my thesis for my Master's Degree studies in play at Lesley University.

Have I mentioned yet that Lume changed my life?   I can't say that about a lot of things, but this time it's true.   Their approach to art, and the body, and performance is so deep and rich.  After my first visit with them, I had a real a-ha moment about what commitment and skill meant in performance.

Here is a description of the workshop:

http://www.lumeteatro.com.br/curso.php?id_curso=39

HOW?

Your contribution will enable me to get TO Brazil and participate in the workshop. The most expensive component is the flight there, followed by the cost of the workshop.   

Flights to Brazil are costing between $900 US and $1000 US at the time of this writing.  The workshop cost is $720 Brazilian Reais, which is approximately $310 US.  I also plan to rent a room/bed in one of the local neighbor's houses, which will I'm assuming will probably cost between $200 and $300 (once I have the exact information from Lume, I can send an update on the exact amount), based on previous homestays.   Anything left over will be used for transportation (bus and taxi from the airport to get to the location).

If, for some reason something along the line falls through, all funds will be applied towards either the development of my Master's degree clown theater thesis piece post-graduation or the development of a new piece, OR towards a future workshop, OR both.  If Brazil falls into the ocean, or there is some logistical glitch keeping me from going, I will make sure that my clown grows anyways.  No, not just by eating lots of donuts.  You are invited to all future performances!

WHO IS THIS CLOWN ANYWAYS?

I have shared Happy the Sad Clown with the world over the past few years in a number of venues, most well-known being the Solstice Circus, a small circus with live music that perorms on the Solstices and Equinoxes and often some fun pagan date in between.  It's become a popular event, and our performances often sell out.   Along with stand-up comedian, The Sun, we help provide the laughs amongst the sparkles and aerials.    

I've also had the pleasure of a fews visits to Childrens' Hospital with the Clown Care Unit and hope that I can do more of that someday.   I've clowned in an adult rehab facility, for a food expo, and for a gigantic corporate gala. I've taught a couple of clown workshops for Lesley University's Community of Scholars Days as well as a workshop (mostly in Portuguese!) for children living in Salvador, Brazil.  This is in addition to all of the movement and theater teaching that I like to do as well.

I'm in the process of creating a solid demo reel of my clown-meets-aerials-meets-whatever work, but here are a few clips and links of things so you can get the idea (obviously nothing from the medical facilities):

http://www.solsticecircus.com/artist2.html

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TZvWB7gqviA (from 3:19 - although the rest is fun too!)

http://vimeo.com/wendykinal

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Happy-the-Sad-Clown/176234995815828?directed_target_id=0

DON'T WORRY, ME HAPPY

I often find myself a decently fed artist (I'm not quite starving yet), but I live with on low-income too, so even if you are unable to contribute with funds, I do understand, and you can help by spreading the word.  That is HUGE.  I have an Australian friend crowdfunding money for a new album, and it was such a pleasure that, here, all the way across the globe, I could donate a little bit and also help her get the word out.   It all goes a long way.   You can use the Indiegogo tools for ease with that!

::BOWS::

I have such a passion for clowning, and especially for discovering new ways to share the art, and to find new parts of myself that we can all laugh at or cry along with. I love Brazil and I can't wait to go and play.   I want my soul to be fed more and more in 2014, and I, in turn, will try to feed yours as well.

I am grateful for your time, support, and love.  From the bottom of my clown heart.

-Wendy (and Happy)

story:
Making Myth

A New Play by Virginia Grise, directed by Jessi D. Hill

Produced by Megan E. Carter and Lanie Zipoy

Performances: February 16-18, 2014

About the Play:

A conservative intellectual wound a little tight, a graduate student that likes a good fight, a beer drinking, polka-dancing half-breed, and a cross dressing street-smart macha meet in a bar somewhere in South Texas. Between the liquor and the line dancing, a raucous rapid-fire theoretical showdown ensues. The true stories of Chipita and Lucy, two women hanged for murder, take center stage in this gender-bending play that indeed proves Texas really is a whole ‘nother country, ya’ll.

Why We're Doing It:

I love unconventional plays that push me to look at the world differently; plays filled with seemingly irreconcilable contrasts; and plays that defy the page and urgently require actors voices and bodies to ignite understanding. MAKING MYTH is such a play. My co-conspirators, director, Jessi Hill and co-producer Lanie Zipoy, fell in love with this play in the same way I did and, turns out, we all want to make the same kind of theatre. So, introducing Virginia Grise's (aka Vicki) work to NYC just made sense.

Vicki has had a fantastic career in Texas and California, making plays and dance theatre and performance installations; writing books and educating young people. And now, she’s here in New York, looking to stir up some trouble. She’s off to a good start – a member of the WP Lab, she recently won the prestigious Whiting Award (they LOVED Making Myth) and she’s completely hooked me with her plays that are consistently subversive, poetic, and true.

At this point in its trajectory, MAKING MYTH needs to get on its feet in order to be completed. We’re going to do a workshop production (in a bar!): two weeks with 4 actors, a director and sound designer and then 3 performances to see what we have and to share it with you.

What We Need from You:

So, we’re raising some money. The dollars contributed to this campaign will pay the creative team. Our actors, director, designer, and stage manager are not being asked to volunteer their time or work for minimum wage, because they are professional artists, who are vital to the development of new work. And this process is vital for sending MAKING MYTH out to the wider world.

If you love big, daring ideas; if you love theatre in bars; if you love women artists, if you love American mythology, then please consider supporting MAKING MYTH today. Donations small and large are happily accepted. 

And please spread the word!

Sincerely,

Megan

(All donations are tax-deductible and will go through TerraNova Collective, our brilliant umbrella organization)

story:
Who we are...

The Chrysalis Collective is a female-lead, brand-spanking new theatre company dedicated to creating theatre which is immersive, exciting and tangible.
We want to take well loved and well known, classic stories from the literary cannon and offer a new perspective; bringing to life their universal truth by pushing forth contemporary issues of society in an art form that we are passionate about.
Our first production, William Shakespeare's 'Twelfth Night', has been selected as one of eighty-six amateur theatre companies across the UK to take part in the RSC Open Stages 2013-2016. This  production will be set in 1957, with the inclusion of a live rock 'n' roll band and even a little twist...
As an emerging theatre company, we are thrilled to be part of such an exciting and rare opportunity; however, we need your help!
From this campaign we need to raise a total of £1500 to go towards the cost of our performance venue! 

As you can see, we have a lot to find funds for! All the money we raise from the campaign will go towards payment for our venue. If we do not reach the entire goal, your donations will still go towards this area of our funding. Anything extra will go towards the rest!

Other Ways You Can Help


We would be so very grateful if you could be so kind as to spread the word on our campaign and help us make some noise!

Check out the indiegogo share tools if you would like to share us, or perhaps post the link on facebook, maybe even follow us on twitter (@thechrysaliscol) and let people know we exist!

All donations (big or small) and all noise made on our campaign will help make this project a reality! We really appreciate all of your support.

Please, help us achieve greatness and be part of our adventure :)

Thank you for taking the time to read our campaign. 

from everyone at The Chrysalis Collective


Find out more...

http://www.thechrysaliscollective.org.uk
http://www.ideastap.com/People/thechrysaliscollective
https://www.facebook.com/pages/The-Chrysalis-Collective/218975661599477

RSC Open Stages: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j2KiXCvwt7Q

story:
Lila and I met in February 2011 at an event where a scene from 'Cowboys' was performed.  Lila approached me after the show to compliment the scene and asked to read the play; I was struck that she seemed 'right' to play Melanie and when I heard that she sang jazz it seemed like a great fit for us to work together to produce the play.  Only one snag, she was leaving to travel the world teaching yoga for nearly a year.

By the time she returned none of our passion for the project was gone and we set to work trying to find a home for the play; our search lead us to The Cell Theatre.  We planned to rent The Cell but then Kira Simring, the artistic director, fell in love with 'Cowboys' and we fell in love with Kira and she signed on to direct, so now 'Cowboys' is an incubator project, a vote of confidence that gives our project free rehearsal space!

This will be Cowboys's first fully staged production and my first full-length production. I wrote this play in July 2006 and up until a few months ago it was a full-length one act with song.  When Lila, Kira and I began to collaborate I discovered that there was a second act waiting to happen, and that it is an interactive concert: the audience is invited to request songs and vote on the final number.  Also, in subsequent productions it will be up to the artists which songs are performed, or they could choose to write their own music!

Your contribution will go towards covering the costs of using The Cell, paying all artists involved a modest stipend for their efforts, costumes, sets, promotional materials, & event insurance.  

All donations are tax-deductible, because we have a Sponsoring Producer!



Their Mission Statement:
State of Play Productions is a hot, little incubator hatching new work by theater artists.  We embrace challenges and foster communication.  We shake up the traditional order by encouraging actors to produce, working alongside writers and directors from the beginning to create art of unprecedented creativity and bold integrity.  To reach the largest audience possible, we expand across media, presenting our work in radio, film, and other audio/visual formats.
If we can inspire people, even for a moment, to live the life that their most courageous self would lead, to cast their fears aside and touch the hearts of others, then we have completed our mission.

A little more about the production...

Lila Donnolo is a singer, actress, tango dancer, acroyogi & producer who has traveled the world singing, tangoing, & teaching yoga.

Michael Marceline is a playwright and producer, who has independently produced two workshop productions, Cowboys (Straight, Queer, Quixotic, & Otherwise Allegorical) at Smith College in 2006 & Laughing All Along at The Directors Company; he was also an associate producer of State of Play Productions' How To ___ Play Fest in 2011.  He has written three full length plays and seven one acts.

About the play...

Cowboys (Straight, Queer, Quixotic, & Otherwise Allegorical) is an original interactive concert play about soul mates: Melanie Arrojado, a gifted chanteuse, and her gay best friend, Topher Ross, an in-your-face queer performance artist.

Act I

Melanie should be packing–she should already be packed; she's moving tomorrow! Her soon-to-be-ex-boyfriend, Thomas, has a 6AM flight to London that she'd really prefer to be on, but he hasn't asked her along... Topher, her best friend/spiritual brother, will be here any minute; he wants her to move to Brooklyn so bad that he's dragging his boyfriend, Max, all the way to Western MA to help her move. The lease is up; the pressure's on. If only should could decide what step to take next...

Act II

Melanie and Topher reunite, after five years apart, to perform a one-night-only concert together. Of course, they cannot agree on what to perform so they have asked the audience to request songs and vote on the set list...
story_txt:
Lila and I met in February 2011 at an event where a scene from 'Cowboys' was performed.  Lila approached me after the show to compliment the scene and asked to read the play; I was struck that she seemed 'right' to play Melanie and when I heard that she sang jazz it seemed like a great fit for us to work together to produce the play.  Only one snag, she was leaving to travel the world teaching yoga for nearly a year.
By the time she returned none of our passion for the project was gone and we set to work trying to find a home for the play; our search lead us to The Cell Theatre.  We planned to rent The Cell but then Kira Simring, the artistic director, fell in love with 'Cowboys' and we fell in love with Kira and she signed on to direct, so now 'Cowboys' is an incubator project, a vote of confidence that gives our project free rehearsal space!
This will be Cowboys's first fully staged production and my first full-length production. I wrote this play in July 2006 and up until a few months ago it was a full-length one act with song.  When Lila, Kira and I began to collaborate I discovered that there was a second act waiting to happen, and that it is an interactive concert: the audience is invited to request songs and vote on the final number.  Also, in subsequent productions it will be up to the artists which songs are performed, or they could choose to write their own music!
Your contribution will go towards covering the costs of using The Cell, paying all artists involved a modest stipend for their efforts, costumes, sets, promotional materials, & event insurance.  
All donations are tax-deductible, because we have a Sponsoring Producer!

story:
Our Story

BooTown is an independent theatre group in Houston, Texas. We focus on homegrown storytelling based pieces that audiences have never seen before and this Spring we are bringing back the popular Benshi Show from last season. This time around we are interpreting Roadhouse, the cult American Classic starring Patrick Swayze and Sam Elliot.


In a traditional Japanese Benshi show, Benshi performers memorized western movies and then reinterpreted the story for an eastern audience. BooTownâ€™s crew (BooTown founder Emily Hynds, Blake Whitaker and Joe Wozny) will retell the story of two battling bar bouncers through their own satirical commentary backed by the musical stylings of local blues hound Lucas Gorham (Grandfather Child).


â€œHopefully, the audience will go away with a ton of laughs, and the overwhelming urge to high-five their best friend. Or just roundhouse kick someone,â€ the show's director and BooTown Associate Artistic Director Lindsay Burleson says.


In keeping with our mission of producing in non-traditional settings in order to cultivate new audiences, the play will be performed at Rudyardâ€™s British Pub, home of the Grown-up Storytime series.


The production runs March 9-10 at 8p.m. and March 16 at 10:30 p.m. and midnight at Rudyardâ€™s, 2010 Waugh, Houston TX 77006. Tickets are pay-what-you-can and can be purchased at the door.


What We Need & What You Get

One of BooTowns initiatives this year is to pay our actors, designers, videographers, musicians, and of course Benshi-ers, what they deserve. The majority of the $500 we are asking for will go towards paying the actors and musicians who have been working tirelessly to put this show together. If our entire goal isnt reached, the money that we do raise will still go directly to the artists. In order to pay for supplies (we just ordered a slide whistle!) we will use revenue from ticket sales and merchandise sold at the event.


But enough about us, here is what you get for helping us out:


$10 A handmade thank you note signed and kissed by the cast and crew as we channel the ghost of Patrick Swayze. CRAZY FOR SWAYZE. We will also recognize you on our fancy-pants website.

$25 A handmade thank you note signed and kissed by the cast and crew as we channel the ghost of Patrick Swayze. & A Specialty Designed Mijo Chocolate Lollipop. If we have to mail it...you will get a NORMAL lollipop. Think about that and let it inform your decision as to whether or not you come see the show.  (plus the above)

$50 Free admission with a guest to the show  (plus all of the above)

$100 A copy of Roadhouse signed by the Benshi cast. (plus all of the above)

$250 Dinner with the cast at Chez Boo (plus all of the above)

$500 A date with either Lindsay Burleson (the director) or Emily Hynds, Artistic Director of BooTown (your choice!). Lindsay will even clean out her car. (plus all of the above, except the dinner, don't be greedy)

story:
Qui sommes nous ?

 

«  Les membres de Belzébrute (...) ont choisi l'indépendance. Ils se débrouillent avec peu, en dehors des théâtres établis. S'ils travaillent dans un esprit festif et décontracté, ils sont pourtant très sérieux quand vient le temps de polir l'esthétique. »

Philippe Couture le DEVOIR

BELZÉBRUTE :


Belzébrute se définit comme un band de théâtre -- auteurs-concepteurs-interprètes -- qui se plaît à créer des spectacles à GRAND déploiement et petit budget.  À travers ses créations, le band explore avec une énergie lumineuse et une désinvolture contagieuse le théâtre d’objets, la marionnette, le jeu masqué, la poésie de l’image et le théâtre d’ombres.


 

who are we ?

 

“The members of Belzébrute chose independence. They manage with very little money.  They work in a very festive spirit but they are, nevertheless, very serious when comes the time to refining   their work”.

 

Philippe Couture Le DEVOIR

 Belzébrute :

 

Belzébrute defines itself as a Theater Band which likes to create Tiny budget-mega productions… Through its creations Belzébrute explore Object Theater, Puppetry, Shadow Theater, Mask Play and the poetry images with a contagious energy.

 

 

LE PROJET :

 

Notre nouvelle création Manga ! sera jouée au Festival Fringe de Montréal et de Windsor en juin et juillet 2011.

Nous avons besoin d'un gros coup de main pour transporter Manga à Windsor en Ontario. Le spectacle ayant connu un immense succès à Montréal en janvier dernier, nous voulons le faire connaître à un plus grand nombre de spectateurs et le Fringe nous apparaît être la meilleure vitrine !!

 

 

THE PROJECT :

 

Manga! Our latest creation will be performed at the Fringe Festival of Montreal and Windsor (Ontario) in June and July 2011

This is why we need your help ! It is very costly to carry the show to Windsor. Since the show was a great success in Montreal last January we want a largest number of spectators to see it. The Windsor Fringe Festival is the best place to start our quest.

 

 

LE SHOW :

Depuis sept ans, Ritsuko prépare soigneusement sa vengeance et la voici enfin aux portes de sa libération… Voilà une audacieuse histoire épique délicieusement ingénieuse. Un délirant voyage au cœur d'un Japon médiéval déjanté. Vous en perdrez votre japonais!

 

Avec Manga, Belzébrute propose un univers peuplé de samouraïs, de vieux sages et de Shogun. Dans un langage pseudo-japonais, la pièce nous entraîne sur les traces de Ritsuko qui concocte sa propre vendetta.

 

Manga constitue le second volet de la trilogie de la vengeance, amorcée avec « Shavirez le Tsigane des mers».

À mi-chemin entre la bande dessinée et le cinéma d’animation japonais, Manga est une succession ininterrompue de tableaux qui compose une trame narrative mystérieuse, poétique et où l’image prime sur la parole. http://www.belzebrute.com/Revue_de_Presse.html

 

THE SHOW :

For the past seven years, Ritsuko has been concocting her vengeance.  And now here she is, at last, ready to get her revenge against the Shogun.   Belzébrute presents Manga an epic and deliciously clever adventure into an off-the-wall medieval Japan.  You will lose your Japanese!!!

 

Manga is the second part of Belzébrute’s trilogy of vengeance, begun with "Shavirez the Gypsy of the Seas".

Halfway between the comic and Japanese animation film, Manga is an uninterrupted succession of scenes that compose a mysterious and poetic narrative in witch the image prevails on the speech. Once again Belzébrute plunges in a contagious energy that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

http://www.belzebrute.com/Revue_de_Presse.html

 


Une histoire d’amour avec le Fringe :


2006 : Première participation pour Belzébrute. Cri[au]logis, un spectacle qui ne vous laissera pas de glace.

Spectacle sur le sous financement des arts au Québec.

Belzébrute naît.

 

2008 : Prix pour le meilleur texte francophone - Shavirez, le Tsigane des mers

top ten patron’s pick Festival Fringe de Windsor en Ontario.

* Grace à sa participation au Fringe de Montréal et de Windsor, Shavirez tourne encore au travers le Québec et l’Ontario. Vous trouverez nos horaires de tournée sur le site web www.belzebrute.com/Calendrier.html

 

2010 : Nominé meilleure scénographie et meilleur texte anglophone – Shavirez, Gypsy of the sea

           Fringe-spirit ! 1ere compagnie francophone à gagner ce prix en 20 ans – Fringe-Moi ! Web télé du Festival !

 

2011 Avec MANGA, Belzébrute espère avoir la même lancée avec le Festival Fringe de Montréal et de Windsor.

 

 

A love story between Belzébrute and the Fringe

 

2006 : First-time participation of Belzébrute at the Montreal Fringe festival with Cri-au-logis a show about the underfounding in the arts.

Belzébrute is born!

 

2008: Winner of the best French text Award with Savirez le Tsigane des mers  at the Montreal Fringe Festival

          Top 10 Patron’s pick at the Windsor Fringe Festival For Shavirez le Tsigane des mers

 

*Due to its participation at the Fringe (Montreal and Windsor), Belzébrute is still touring with Shavirez le Tsigane des mers in Quebec and Ontario. Consult our tour schedule by visiting our website at  

www.belzebrute.com/Calendrier.html

 

2010:  Nominated for the best scenography and English text with Shavirez Gypsy of the Sea

Winner of the Fringe Spirit Award with Fringe-moi the official web show of the festival!

 

2011: Belzebrute hopes that its participation at the Fringe Festival (Montreal and Windsor) will be as positive for Manga as it was for Shavirez.

 


OBJECTIF 2000$ :

-        ATTEINT : On est heureux

-        SURPASSÉ : En plus d’être heureux on va pouvoir se payer de la bouffe !

-        PAS ATTEINT : Nous sommes dans le rouge, mais rien ne nous arrête, alors nous irons quand même... Au risque d'avoir à tirer le camion par les dents en se relayant à tour de rôle ou encore se mettre à genoux devant notre banquier pour qu'il nous accorde "encore" une marge de crédit, car qui sait nous sommes peut-être les futurs Guy Laliberté de ce monde !!

 

Our Goal 2000$ :

-        If we achieve our goal : We are so happy !!!

-        If we exceed our goal: We will be able to eat !

-        If  not reached: Well… that means we will probably have to tow the mini van by hand between Belleville and Windsor (approximately 500 km)… but I guess that, since nothing can stop Belzébrute, we will still go on… Go Belzébrute, go!!!

 


Nous avons besoin de :

-2000$ : location d’une mini van + coût du gaz continuellement à la hausse… (au dessus de 1800km allez-retour)

-200$ : pour la promotion flyers, affiches, communiqués couleurs

-150$ : hôtel sur la route, c’est long 10h de route…

Là bas nous serons logés, mais pas nourrit, si nous arrivons à dépasser notre objectif, et nos besoins, nous pourrons allouer un budget pour se faire des épiceries.

 

Votre participation nous permet non seulement de nous déplacer mais aussi à faire grandir une compagnie qui est en pleine expansion.

 

our needs :

- $2000 : mini van rental and gas (over 1800km)

- $200: For promotion material (Posters, flyers, color press release…)

- $150: For accommodations (Montreal-Windsor is a long trip…)

 

Your donation also  helps a growing company in its expansion.  

 


Comment vous pouvez nous aider plus :

En partageant le lien vers vos contacts facebook

En venant nous applaudir lors de nos représentations à Montréal ou à Windsor.

En parlant de nous à votre entourage.  

En devenant fan de notre page facebook et en nous suivant sur twitter !!

 

 

You can also help us by :

Sharing this link with your Facebook contacts

Coming to see the show in Montreal or Windsor, Ontario

Talking about Belzébrute to your friends

Becoming a fan on our Facebook page and following us on Twitter.

 

www.belzebrute.com

story:
FOR AUDITION DETAILS:  CLICK HERE!

Hi! I'm Bobby Holder, artistic director of The Actor's Project NYC, a unique theatre company that assists it's actors land representation and get work through industry showcases and plays.  I'm also a writer and playwright.   I wrote a play inspired by a scene called MOTHER from my book OUT OF THE BLUE.  The play is called:           

                         Manhattan Fable-The Actress Who Cried Wolf!  

Manhattan Fable-The Actress Who Cried Wolf! is not only the twisted dark comedy of an actress who is haunted and begins to believe her own lies, but is also a heartbreaking tale of a young couple, Andrew and Carla, who are passionately fighting and loving while living in a cluttered, small apartment in midtown Manhattan. 

The play begins with four characters addressing the audience, preparing them for the frantic story that is about to unfold.  There is conflict, arguments, and dry wit, as each character tries to explain when all the madness began:

         "I'm Andrew, and this all began the day Carla thought she was pregnant."

          "I'm Acantha, and I am part of this story."

         "I'm Carla, and this all happened the day I read Andrew's journal."

         "And I'm Anna.  This all began the day I died."


The Actor's Project NYC first produced Manhattan Fable in 2009 to wonderful feedback from audiences, talent agents and managers.  However funding did not allow us to extend the play to be viewed by a larger audience.  Increasing costs in producing a play have made it difficult for us to keep the original play division alive in our company.

We need your help to pay for publicity, casting, theatre rental, rehearsal space, stipends, and other expenses.  TAPNYC Theatre Company will cover all costs not raised through this campaign.

Help us today and you'll be a supporter, producer and/or a sponsor of a New York play! 

                                     What kind of wolf are you?

*Note:  Any additional funds collected will go toward extending the play or toward a future run of the play.

*Manhattan Fable-The Actress Who Cried Wolf! is part of the campaign to help keep plays alive at TAPNYC! 







                                  See the scene that inspired the play. 

How is the scene different than the play?  In the scene Anna has three daughters while in the play Anna has one son, Andrew, who is a playwright.  In this scene Anna is haunting her daughters.  In the play Anna haunts her son's girlfriend Carla, who is a struggling actress on the verge of insanity.  The play is more of a love story gone wrong which focuses on Carla and Andrew, while the scene focuses on Anna.



 The first performance ever of the scene MOTHER!  In this version the scene is a little more dramatic and darker.

story:
There We'd Be...

 Chasing down a dream! "One Thousand Words" is an original book musical written by Michael Braud and composed by Curran Latas that is heading to the 2015 Chicago Musical Theatre Festival this summer!
"Spanning the 1930's, 1940's and 1990's, "One Thousand Words" follows Warren and Daniel, two young men from the mining town of Winslow, as they try to navigate love and acceptance in times of conflict and intolerance."

We Need YOUR Help!

 This Indiegogo page has been created to help give "One Thousand Words" the Chicago premiere production it deserves!
Our $5,000 goal is in place to help us pay for transport, food, our actors, our orchestra, and any other production specs needed to travel this show from Baton Rouge, LA to Chicago!

The Impact

By supporting "One Thousand Words", you are helping to bring a completely original musical to the Chicago community which is a HUGE step towards progressing this show as it plays along with other impressive original musicals!

In addition, with your help, we hope that "One Thousand Words" will encourage and inspire a community and national-wide discussion on the struggles and issues facing the LGBTQ community, both in the early 20th century and today.

The Challenges

 Putting on an original musical from the ground up is a challenging task alone - producing it miles away in Chicago is another feat in itself! We need all the help we can get to help make the process of traveling our musical to Chicago a worry-free one!

 OTHER WAYS TO HELP
Spread the word! Let all your friends know about this project - where it came from and where it's going - and let's rally a community support towards spreading the positive messages of this show!

story:
The Show

Nicholas Sparks, whose novel "The Notebook" and subsequent film reduced even the most sturdy of men to blubbering tears, is an international sensation. He has written over a dozen novels, several of which have become blockbuster tearjerkers on the big screen. In this (obviously) completely fabricated satirical comedy, we investigate how and why Sparks became the unparalleled master of the "Crymance" genre.

In the play, Nicholas Sparks is visited by the ghost of his ancestor, Reginald Sparks, who tells him he must save the world from a bloodthirsty demon named Rodanthe. The only defense against this demon is the tears of humanity. Nick vows to write "The saddest damn book in the damn world!" to keep the mankind crying and therefore safe from the apocalypse. But Nick soon crumbles beneath the weight of his newfound fame. He must learn to keep the secret of his destiny close to his heart or risk being locked in a mental institution and kept from the woman he loves forever.

The play will premiere at the 2012 New York International Fringe Festival. According to Mayor Bloomberg, FringeNYC has "...been a big part of downtown Manhattan's  burgeoning cultural scene, and it has launched the careers of many a director, designer, and actor - all the while  maintaining a top ticket price of $15. Despite its name, "The Fringe" is at the very center of this city's unrivaled creativity."

Needless to say, we're pretty honored and pumped! However, we're going to need a little help to give this show the production it deserves for its maiden voyage.

Help Nicholas Sparks Save the World! (Or help us help him).

FringeNYC is an incredible organization and it provides each of its productions with a historic downtown theater space, lighting and sound equipment, wonderful volunteer PAs, and personalized publicity. However, there are a few things that FringeNYC does not typically pick up the tab for...

  • Rehearsal Studio Fees
  • Props and Costumes
  • Actors' Equity Stipends
  • Designer Fees
  • Transportation Expenses
We need a little extra help covering these costs to make our show as big and beautiful and crazy as it can be! Every little bit will help put a wig on an actor or a designer on a train. Or a fearsome demon back into Hell where it belongs.

Who We Are

We are Christina Brosman and Elizabeth Kerin. We wrote "And Then She DIES at the End!" and will be directing it as a team for Fringe. We're graduates of the Goldberg Department of Dramatic Writing at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, former roommates, and have collectively read a total of one page of a Nicholas Sparks book as research for this project. Christina read it and then sent it to Liz, if we're splitting hairs. Liz divides her time between New York and LA and Christina is settled in New York. We've been working virtually a lot lately, cultivating a successful long distance relationship of sorts. We're very excited to embark on our first theatre piece together after years of collaborating in other mediums!

Audra Arnaudon is our formidable producer/ACR (Authorized Company Representative for FringeNYC). She majored in Film and Television and minored in Producing at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts. She met Christina while in line for a movie at the Cannes International Film Festival in 2008, and was introduced to Liz later that summer. When not finding ways to support our collective artistic endeavors, she works in Production Management for National Geographic Television, and lives happily in Brooklyn. We couldn't do this without her!

Jill Sapenoff, our stage manager, has worked on a wide range of entertainment productions including projects in video, stage, television, and film. Stage credits include Rebecca the Musical (Broadway, Fall 2012), Voices in Conflict (Public Theatre, Vineyard Theatre), Swimming in the Shallows (Theatre for the New City). TV/Film credits include Putzel (Stouthearted Films), Bert and Arnie's Guide to Friendship (Justified Ends Entertainment), The Newlywed Game (Game Show Network).

UPDATED! We are proud to announce our cast, which includes Alan Starzinski as Nicholas Sparks, Brennan Lee Mulligan as Reginald Sparks, and Sarah Black as Callie. If you're a fan of UCB in NYC, you might have seen the guys tearing it up onstage there recently! We can't wait to work with this incredibly talented cast.

Fringe & The Future (Of humanity?)

FringeNYC has served as a springboard to Broadway and Off-Broadway for many years, introducing the world to shows like "Urinetown" and "Dog Sees God". The festival has also launched the careers of many a well-known writer, such as one of our favorites, The Office's Mindy Kaling. Basically: Kill it at Fringe and it can open doors. Doors you will have helped us walk through!

We would love to take you on the adventure that is building a theatre piece from the ground up. We hope you'll support our show and the tradition of FringeNYC!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you're in the NYC area, we hope you'll swing by the show in August and fill our audience with raucous laughter!
  • Follow our characters on Twitter for a daily dose of demon slaying and spread the word! @SparksySlays for Nick, and @DemonRodanthe for... well, The Demon Rodanthe.
  • Share our trailer, posted above. Don't let Reginald's noble polar bear swim be for nothing!

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Roy Harrington Tracy. I am currently a Masters of Fine Arts (MFA) Candidate in Dance at the College at Brockport. I am heading a funding initiative and represent a group of six dancers who have been invited to premiere a new dance by James Hansen in the Pasadena Dance Festival in California! This festival would be a powerful networking tool for each of us and could lay the groundwork for many more performance opportunities in the future. This opportunity is unbelievably exciting for us and we are committed to representing western NY dance in a positive way!

What We Need

When we found out we were accepted to perform, we all released hesitant cheers of excitement not being sure we could fund the trip. Then, I had a thought. There are seven of us involved in the project. If each one of our friends on Facebook donated just 1 dollar, we would cover travel expenses and food for everyone. I am using this media to reach out to family and friends that are connected to the 7 of us and asking you to help raise the money needed! Again, just $1 would make this trip possible. (but feel free to donate more.  In fact…feel free to donate as much as you can!!!!!!!)

Our goal is to raise $3,000 which, when added to several small grants we are applying for, will completely cover our travel expenses for this exciting adventure as artists.

The Impact

For each of us the professional opportunities we will encounter by participating in this festival can and likely will shape our future careers.

Professionally, it will provide a HUGE networking opportunity which in Dance is essential.  Meeting other choreographers, performers, producers, and dance professionals will enhance our resources to create and produce our own choreography in the future and can also lay the groundwork for future teaching and performing jobs.  Working with dance artists from a different region of the country will strengthen the quality of our own artistic voices by exposing us to new aesthetics and creative forces. In the professional arena of dance performance, these kinds of experiences are crucial to success.

Personally, for most of us, this will be our first professional performance on the west coast which makes it even more exciting.

Our company includes myself and Mathew Frazier Smith, Vaness VanWormer, Devon Monin, Zachary Frazee, and Brett Cox.  Each of us are at different paths of our careers but we are all passionate about our art and eager to share it with a west coast audience in the Pasadena Dance Festival.  The choreographer, James Hansen, has had his work produced in amazing theaters like the Kennedy Center and Jacob’s Pillow. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially to this campaign, please help by sharing through various forms of social media and spreading the word to anyone who might have an interest in supporting the arts and one of the most enjoyable groups I have had the privilege of working with!

story:
tenofus

S.O.S   

Save our Skins!

 

youMove affiliated artists need your help....

To do justice to the amazing works created by our guest choreographers for our upcoming show tenofus, we desperately need monies for dance specific flooring – both the installation and hire for the whole week of the season.

 

tenofus

SIDETRACK THEATRE 21 nov - 24 nov 

A distillation of dialogues between elite Sydney dance makers and affiliated artists of youMove Company.

5 unique solo dance works created by choreographers Narelle Benjamin, Tony Osborne, Anton, Vicki Van Hout and Angela French.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The affiliated artists of youMove Company have been busting out some serious moves in the studio. The funding for this campaign will go directly to the hiring and installation of dance specfic flooring at Sidetrack Theatre for the independently produced season of tenofus.

Please save our skins!

There are great perks for you guys too....

You can’t make the show, wish you were here, interstate, stuck in traffic, a summer cold, Aunt Melba's 90th? For $25 you can still support the show and buy a ticket anyway!

For $50 you will get a ten pack of blank greeting cards with limited edition original dance photography featuring youMove Company...How handy! just in time for the festive season.

Perhaps you’re feeling a little more generous? For $100 be the first to sample youMove’s customised wine label. A bottle of youMove’s finest drop!

WE LOVE YOUR SKIN TOO!
For $200 you will receive an hour massage from a company member, the amazing ten pack of cards and a bottle of youMove’s finest drop.

 

The Impact

Since it's inception in 2009 youMove Company has been creating new contemporary dance works, delivering potent dance education experiences across the state for 100's of young people, building audiences for dance with numerous free outdoor public events; the company has launched several careers of independent dancers, choreographers and even lighting designers, they have employed over 15 professional dance makers, commissioned ten new Australian works, employed over 25 dance artists, mentored over 30 aspiring emerging artists... all of this in only three short years and afforded by the unrelenting passion and commitment of youMove's founder and artistic director Kay Armstrong, who often works to support the growth of the dance sector via youMove's prolific activity on a voluntary basis. 

This is the first time that youMove has asked directly for donations - we hope that our call for help might get answered by anyone who has seen us, been a part of the many programs we have provided, been on the recieving end of any of the amazing opportunities that youMove has initiated...or perhaps you just love giving for a good cause. This production was supported in its creative development stage, but is not receiving any funding or support to present- we are relying on our fabulous supporters - YOU!

story:
Thank you to all who donated and shared this page!

With the $280 That we raised we were able to purchase enough materials to bring our sprung dance floor at 276 Art Studio into fruition! Pictures coming soon! Thank you for supporting the arts and emerging Miami artists.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

Help us Bring a Sprung Floor to our Space!

About Us

My name is Brigette Cormier and I am the co-founder of 276 Art Studio and Love Steady Arts (LSA) Contemporary Dance. 

LSA Contemporary Dance is a project based dance company started by New World School of the arts BFA alumni Juliana Triviño, Sasha Caicedo, and myself. We perform in and around the Wynwood Arts District in Miami, and are based at 276 Art Studio in Wynwood. 276 Art Studio is a multidisciplinary art studio, boutique,  gallery, and performance space supporting emerging and underground contemporary Miami artists of all genres. This is our first official dance project.

Right now we are raising money to build a sprung dance floor in our performance space at 276 Art Studio. Our goal is to raise $600 by February 22nd. Once installed, the sprung floor will allow us to practice and perform much more exciting and experimental dance works with greater range. LSA Contemporary Dance is passionate about exploring new approaches to dance and sharing this beautiful art form with the community. Thank you for watching our video!

 

Sprung Floor Details - we're almost there!

 

Materials needed: 540 sq. feet of floorboards

We've found the supplier and simply need to place the order.

Materials already acquired: foam and glue for the sprung floor foundation

I've purchased the closed cell foam and adhesive already.

 

The Impact

Love Steady Arts contemporary dance is one of the many soon to be performing groups at 276 Art Studio, as 276 Art Studio presents all forms of performance art and supports lots of artists - the acquisition of the sprung floor will ultimately benefit all artists who share the space! Thanks for your time!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Come visit during Wynwood Art Walk! Every second Saturday each month 276 Art Studio is open from 8pm to 1am. 

 

What's inside 276 Art Studio during Art Walk:

  • Visual art on display and for sale. Featured Artists: George Hustus, William Hustus, Herbert Hofer, Christopher Williams, Benjamin Williams Jr., and TwikOne.
  • the Love Steady Arts Boutique. Jewelry on display and for sale by: Love Steady Arts, 77Ss, and Sweet Shot. Original Garments by the Eyesore Bros and Le Rougue Pierre.
  • Dance Performance by Love Steady Arts Contemporary Dance.
  • Live Music, Spoken Word, and all Performance Art by local artists.

 

We're Online

276 Art Studio's Website

Like Us on Facebook

Love Steady Arts Boutique

 

276 Art Studio

276 NW 27th Terrace, Miami FL 33127

Co-founders: Brigette Cormier and George Hustus

email: info@lovesteadyarts.com

Contact Us Here
story_txt:
Thank you to all who donated and shared this page!
With the $280 That we raised we were able to purchase enough materials to bring our sprung dance floor at 276 Art Studio into fruition! Pictures coming soon! Thank you for supporting the arts and emerging Miami artists.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Help us Bring a Sprung Floor to our Space!
About Us
My name is Brigette Cormier and I am the co-founder of 276 Art Studio and Love Steady Arts (LSA) Contemporary Dance. 
LSA Contemporary Dance is a project based dance company started by New World School of the arts BFA alumni Juliana Triviño, Sasha Caicedo, and myself. We perform in and around the Wynwood Arts District in Miami, and are based at 276 Art Studio in Wynwood. 276 Art Studio is a multidisciplinary art studio, boutique,  gallery, and performance space supporting emerging and underground contemporary Miami artists of all genres. This is our first official dance project.
Right now we are raising money to build a sprung dance floor in our performance space at 276 Art Studio. Our goal is to raise $600 by February 22nd. Once installed, the sprung floor will allow us to practice and perform much more exciting and experimental dance works with greater range. LSA Contemporary Dance is passionate about exploring new approaches to dance and sharing this beautiful art form with the community. Thank you for watching our video!
 


Sprung Floor Details - we're almost there!
 
Materials needed: 540 sq. feet of floorboards
We've found the supplier and simply need to place the order.
Materials already acquired: foam and glue for the sprung floor foundation
I've purchased the closed cell foam and adhesive already.
 


The Impact
Love Steady Arts contemporary dance is one of the many soon to be performing groups at 276 Art Studio, as 276 Art Studio presents all forms of performance art and supports lots of artists - the acquisition of the sprung floor will ultimately benefit all artists who share the space! Thanks for your time!
 


Other Ways You Can Help
Come visit during Wynwood Art Walk! Every second Saturday each month 276 Art Studio is open from 8pm to 1am. 
 
What's inside 276 Art Studio during Art Walk:

Visual art on display and for sale. Featured Artists: George Hustus, William Hustus, Herbert Hofer, Christopher Williams, Benjamin Williams Jr., and TwikOne.
the Love Steady Arts Boutique. Jewelry on display and for sale by: Love Steady Arts, 77Ss, and Sweet Shot. Original Garments by the Eyesore Bros and Le Rougue Pierre.
Dance Performance by Love Steady Arts Contemporary Dance.
Live Music, Spoken Word, and all Performance Art by local artists.

 
We're Online
276 Art Studio's Website
Like Us on Facebook
Love Steady Arts Boutique
 
276 Art Studio
276 NW 27th Terrace, Miami FL 33127
Co-founders: Brigette Cormier and George Hustus
email: info@lovesteadyarts.com
Contact Us Here

story:
Short Summary

Since early on I developed a curiosity for reading and writing. Introduced to the world of theater by my high school teachers, it was at this early stage that I accepted the challenge of directing two plays: Hamlet and Macbeth. 

After enrolling in the University of Puerto Rico, Río Piedras Campus, I declared a baccalaureate in Hispanic Studies and a second degree in Drama. At the same time, participated in the Cinematic Workshop offered by the Puerto Rico Film Corporation.

While taking the course Theory & Narrative Practice and Autofiction, both with professor and Puerto Rican writer Mayra Santos-Febres, I wrote the short story “Cenicienta” (Cinderella) and adapted it into a play.

The result? Cinderella: The Tragedy of Mónica Lafemme, slightly cradled in the folkloric tale told by the Brothers Grimm in which a detective investigates the murder of a young prostitute shot at midnight. As a former client of the departed, the detective must tread lightly in order to avoid bringing suspicion upon himself. 

Together with friends and partners I created an independent theatrical group named "Irkelú" whose first production will be the aforementioned Cinderella.

What We Need & What You Get

As an independent group, we have to raise the amount necessary in order to comply with the calculated budget for the production.

The final budget rounded $1,000 of which we have raised $400 with local sponsors and fundraising initiatives. The gross of the money would be allocated to the construction of the sets and publicity. 

If we're not able to reach the goal, any money donated will be used in the aforementioned categories in the best way possible. 

Your help will greatly help foster the emerging theatrical groups and artists back here in Puerto Rico that with much talent, and scarce resources, strive to do what they love most and develop a healthy industry.   

The Impact

As a first formal experience carried out with fellow students and future professionals, in which we're able to apply our newly and everyday growing set of skills and knowledge, the success of this project would prove that there is a career and a life to be made out of theater. 

We would see the results of our hard work and dedication for this project has been in the works for over more than six months. 

And, maybe not the world, but those who contribute and learn of the play will experience hands-on the importance of theater, how it is merely a mean to understanding ourselves in search for a better life.

Other Ways You Can Help

Every and any help on the matter will be greatly appreciated. 


Thank you.
