story:
What I'm Doing

Hi! My name is Maggie Richardson, and I am an actress. I've been singing and dancing my whole life, and when I am on stage I feel at home. I'm a rising senior at Belmont University in musical theatre, and I've been blessed to have the opportunity to perform at Summer Repertory Theatre in Santa Rosa, CA this summer.  I will be playing one of my dream roles, Doralee in 9 to 5, as well as Christine in A Chorus Line and ensemble in La Cages aux Folles.

It is a professional theatre, so they do give a stipend every week, but there are many expenses that the stipend does not cover. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity - ANY amount of money you can give will be received with much appreciation. Thank you so much!

What I Need & Why I Need It

My stipend for the summer pays $1800 - but I estimate my remaining expenses at around $3900, leaving $2100 for me to raise.  Thank the Lord, SRT provides housing for us!  Here's the breakdown of my estimated expenses:

Meals - $1680
Other Household Living - $240
Carpool - $420
Exploring/Experiencing Northern CA - $600
Clothes - $450
Theatrical Expenses - $250
Shuttle from and back to Airport - $78
Return Flight to Nashville - $271

The Impact

I believe that God has given me gifts as a singer, dancer and actress, and it's my responsibility to develop these gifts to honor Him and to bring joy and encouragement to others.   This opportunity is the next step in my training, development and experience to fulfill my purpose.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you maybe can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please help me get the word out and make some noise about my campaign!
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Pray!

story:
*Please excuse the heinous sound quality, there's just no cleaning up point and shoot camera video riddled with loud motorcycle/dump truck traffic noise, fierce winds and constant rooster crowing. We tried.

Skyway Outdoor Cinema is West Hill Community Association's annual volunteer run free summer event. Renting basic AV equipment takes a big chunk out of our budget - and we’d rather spend that money on continuing to make SOC bigger, better and more sustainable.

With your support, we can purchase a compact and portable all-in-one AV cart, which will not only provide a cinematic experience unlike any that has happened in SOC’s 13 year history, but will last us for many more years to come.

When you support SOC, you’re supporting families from West Hill and beyond (Kent, Seatac, Burien, Des Moines and elsewhere) who make the trip to a parking lot behind a 7-Eleven each year because they value the wonderfully friendly neighbors, sense of community, tasty affordable snacks and great entertainment that SOC brings.


We happen to think SOC Fans are kinda the best. SOC Supporters, however, are just plain awesome. When you support SOC’s free family fun, we want everyone to know it.

$5 DONATION

  • Name listed on Bronze Level supporter slide before each movie
  • A big high-five from our hearts


$25 DONATION

  • Individual thank you on SOC Facebook Page
  • Name listed on Silver Level supporter slide before each movie
  • A giant group hug right from our hearts


$50 DONATION

  • Individual thank you on SOC Facebook Page
  • 1 SOC VIP Pack (Free Drink, Popcorn, Candy & Swag - must be pick up AT SOC, any night)
  • Name listed on Gold Level supporter slide before each movie
  • A super secret friendship handshake from our hearts


$100 DONATION

  • Individual thank you on SOC Facebook Page
  • 2 SOC VIP Packs (Free Drink, Popcorn, Candy & Swag - must be pick up AT SOC, any night)
  • Professionally designed preshow advertisement or special message to run multiple times before each movie ($250 value)


$500 DONATION

  • Individual thank you on SOC Facebook Page
  • 4 SOC VIP Packs (Free Drink, Popcorn, Candy & Swag - must be pick up AT SOC, any night)
  • Professionally designed preshow advertisement or special message to run multiple times before each movie ($250 value)
  • Name or logo added to official event poster and/or other primary marketing materials


THANK YOU so much for you support, and we’ll see YOU in August!



Still want to help? We always need more volunteers:

http://goo.gl/UjRR3L

Don’t forget to connect with us on Facebook:

https://www.facebook.com/SkywayOutdoorCinema

And bookmark our website:

www.MyWestHill.org/SOC

story:
Infinite Variety Productions (IVP) is an NYC-based theatre company dedicated to producing plays based on little-known events in women's history. 

 

"A PIECE OF MY HEART" -  WOMEN WHO SERVED IN VIETNAM (WHAT'S THAT, YOU SAY? WOMEN WERE IN VIETNAM? EXACTLY WHY THIS PLAY IS IMPORTANT)

7,484 women (6,250 of whom were nurses) served in Vietnam.
10 to 24% left the profession when they returned.
Up to 48% sought mental health counseling.


Many others chose to fight their personal battles alone.


These statistics are just numbers without the stories that make them real.

"A Piece of My Heart" recounts the journeys of six women who survived the war, only to be left to fight their own battles at home. Based on interviews with female Vietnam veterans, this story shows the courage of women brave enough not only to serve in the Vietnam conflict, but who were also willing to share their stories when they returned.

 

WHERE ELSE HAS IVP PERFORMED THIS PIECE?

After a run at The Tank Theatre in midtown NYC, IVP's production of, "A Piece Of My Heart" by Shirley Lauro, was picked up for a second run by the famous, Living Theatre.

 

We  have been commissioned to perform this play for the third time for the 20th anniversary of The Vietnam Women's Memorial Foundation in Washington DC.

 

The Vietnam Women's Memorial Foundation has asked IVP to perform "A Piece of My Heart" for the 20th anniversary of the unveiling of the Vietnam Women's Memorial in DC. The performance will take place over Memorial Day Weekend. We are thrilled for this opportunity to honor Vietnam's unsung heroes in our nation's capital. The production will be at The Women in Military Service for America Memorial 

http://www.womensmemorial.org/

For more information about the Vietnam Women's Memorial Foundation or the anniversary, go to:

http://www.vietnamwomensmemorial.org/upcoming.php

 

"A PIECE OF MY HEART" STARS ASHLEY ADELMAN, LARISSA DZEGAR, AMBER QUICK, MARIA MAKENNA, ELIZABETH MCNELIS, PETOL WEEKES AND JAKE CULLENS.

SO, WHAT IS THE MONEY BEING USED FOR?

IVP is seeking funds to help pay the amazing actors and designers that make our productions possible. Our host organization IS helping us out as much as they can, but we still need around $5,000 more to be able to pay all those involved and provide room and board for each trip. Funds are also needed for supplies to transport our set to these new spaces.

We are also hoping to have another short run of this piece before we head to DC. Free tickets will be made available to veternas who will not be able to make it to DC in November. We are planning an October show.

story:
Les Lutins et le Farfama, qu’est ce donc ? C’est un conte musical pour enfants débordant d'énergie, de poésie et de féerie. 

Ecoutez plutôt :

«Savez-vous ce qui se passe près de chez vous ? Dans un monde magiquement coloré de musique, que certains ne soupçonnent même pas !? Prenez deux lutins, fous d’amour l’un pour l’autre : Luzel et Libélia, et  un écureuil malicieux nommé Timus. Ajoutez un énorme danger dissimulé dans une toute petite boîte, trouvée devant leur toute petite porte ! Vous voilà parti pour une aventure inoubliable !!

C’est le voyage de Luzel et Libélia, à la recherche d’ingrédients, peu ordinaires, pour combattre ce mal, l’horrible Farfama ! Laissez vous emporter, ce monde vous enchantera !! Entrez dans la Forêt Chanteuse, l’ancêtre de tous les arbres y abrite le Vieux Papi, roi des claquettes, aux multiples secrets !! Osez vous approchez du lac bouillonnant. Saperlipopette ! Vous ne rêvez pas : voici bien un champignon qui sort d’un lac et, qui en dit long dans son fond ! Et Florisse, un drôle de petit lutin farfelu, qui décidément se passionne pour les fleurs et les « SACS à PAPIER » ! Puis vient le moment d’affronter l’horreur, la pire chose, et cette odeur répugnante qui envahit l’espace, le manque d’air, les hurlements des profondeurs torturées….

Heureusement il y a encore la musique ! Mais que se passe-t-il vraiment ? Quel est le contenu de cette  étrange petite boîte ? Vous ne le savez toujours pas ?

Entrez, tendez l’oreille, et regardez… »

Ce conte musical, les enfants l’adorent. Les parents y sont sensibles aussi. Les personnages sont haut en couleur, la musique de qualité, variée tantôt douce et harmonieuse, tantôt jazzy et colorée. Enjoué,  émouvant, drôle, effrayant, il s’est invité dans les familles, les écoles, et même en  cours de chant ! En quelques années Les Lutins et le Farfama a trouvé son public et a rencontré un succès formidable en région toulousaine.

L'origine des Lutins et le Farfama.

Je m’appelle Nadia NELL, et je suis passionnée de musique et des arts en général  depuis ma plus tendre enfance. A la suite de mes études (Premier Prix de piano, classes d’écriture, chant…), ma passion fut entretenue grâce aux rencontres et aux partages avec toute sorte de musiciens, amateurs ou professionnels, et grâce à la rencontre il y a quelques années, d’une histoire pour enfant, écrite par une collègue clarinettiste, l’histoire des Lutins et du Farfama.

L’envie d’écrire des chansons et les idées musicales se sont imposées à moi dès la première lecture. Il fallait que cette musique jaillisse sur le papier;  l’écriture me rapprochait de mon enfance, d’un état que j’exprime comme cela :

 Il me reste quelque chose de l’enfance si loin, si proche. Quelque chose d’évanescent et cependant si présent, à chaque battement de cœur, à toute respiration nouvelle. Un imaginaire qui vacille entre des mondes malfaisants et des mondes héroïques, fait de jeux et de peurs, de danses et de combats. De nombreuses fois, je m’y suis égarée avec délectation. Juste quelques minutes, parfois des heures entières.

J’y ai bougé et sculpté des images ; j’ai coloré cet espace impalpable de mots, de gestes, de sons, de bruits, de musique. Quelque part… Là, dans cet ailleurs, où tout prend vie : de nos espoirs les plus fous à nos peurs les plus terrifiantes, où l’impossible n’existe pas… 

Alors cet imaginaire si présent ne m’a plus laissé le choix. Il me fut dès lors impossible de laisser reposer ce conte musical naissant dans un tiroir. Le chemin fut long : contacts divers et variés avec des compagnies de théâtre, des maisons de disques, des éditeurs… qui sais-je encore ? Les portes sont restées irrémédiablement  fermées.

Qu’à cela ne tienne ! J’ai retroussé mes manches, démultiplié mes énergies et réalisé un CD en 2009 avec une quinzaine de mes amis musiciens, chanteurs, acteurs. Le CD est édité par l’association Geste et Musique. Ce fut une belle aventure pour chacun d’entre nous ! Je les remercie encore aujourd’hui du fond du cœur.

Puis ce fut la réalisation du site internet www.farfama.fr avec Olivier J. pour la diffusion de l’œuvre. Débordante d’idées, je crée des supports pédagogiques et des activités créatives pour les enseignants, les enfants et les familles. De nombreux retours enthousiasmés d’enfants, de parents et de professeurs des écoles, m’encouragent à poursuivre le chemin.

De plus, cet imaginaire me taraude encore et toujours, il est là, je peux presque le toucher, les idées s’amoncèlent. Alors il faut aller jusqu’au bout, faire naître le spectacle, la scène.

A nouveau, je retrousse mes manches, apprends tout ce qui est lié à la gestion d’entreprise culturelle, et je me lance : constitution des dossiers, contacts avec les personnalités du métier, les programmateurs, recherche des acteurs, d’un chorégraphe, d’un régisseur, etc.… Quelques portes s’ouvrent  enfin ; des résidences, des dates de programmation. L’accueil est chaleureux.

Le rêve est presque là.


MON BESOIN DE FINANCEMENT

J’ai besoin de vous. Votre participation, à partir de 10€, permet de réaliser un élément supplémentaire à la création :

-   décor (une réalisation graphique, 3 volumes peints, 2 panneaux amovibles)

-   7 costumes ;

-   accessoires ;

-   une grande marionnette : un écureuil d’1,20m.

Mon besoin total de financement est de 5500€.

L’équipe artistique et technique se compose aujourd’hui de 11 personnes impliquées et motivées par le développement de la création. La costumière, le graphiste et la décoratrice-marionnettiste sont prêts. Les idées reposent  sur le papier et les croquis attendent de prendre vie dans les cartons.

En 2012, la vente des CD a permis de financer un  l'emploi à mi temps de Clémentine L., Chargée de communication et diffusion pendant 3 mois. Aujourd’hui, l’association Geste et Musique ne peut couvrir l’ensemble des frais incompressibles de production. Elle est soutenue par le Crédit Mutuel (500€ en 2012) et le Conseil Régional de la haute Garonne (500€ en 2013).

Parallèlement, je travaille sans relâche à une diffusion nationale pour que ce spectacle voyage et pour lui assurer une vie à long terme. Une captation vidéo est prévue pour la communication.


VOUS POUVEZ EGALEMENT M'AIDER DE DIFFERENTES MANIERES

‐  Réservez vos places pour les premières représentations qui auront lieu à l’Auditorium de Balma (31 Haute-Garonne), le 21 décembre 2013 sur http://www.farfama.fr/

‐ Commandez CD et/ou partitions sur http://www.farfama.fr/ pour vos enfants, petits enfants, amis (anniversaires, Noël), vos élèves,….

‐ Diffusez l’information à tous vos amis, vos contacts, aux enseignants, et tout ceux qui aiment le spectacle vivant, le théâtre, la musique et la danse, et ….  les projets qui naissent de rencontres et de passion !


EN CONTREPARTIE

En contrepartie, je peux vous proposer de recevoir une photo dédicacée par l’ensemble des artistes, un CD du conte, un T shirt, deux places de spectacle pour venir chanter, danser, vous émouvoir et applaudir les artistes, une vidéo à voir et à revoir, ou encore une chanson spécialement écrite pour vous.

C’est le voyage de Luzel
et Libélia, à la recherche d’ingrédients, peu ordinaires, pour combattre ce
mal, l’horrible Farfama ! Laissez vous emporter, ce monde vous enchantera !!
Entrez dans la Forêt Chanteuse, l’ancêtre de tous les arbres y abrite le Vieux
Papi, roi des claquettes, aux multiples secrets !! Osez vous approchez du
lac bouillonnant. Saperlipopette ! Vous ne rêvez pas : voici bien un
champignon qui sort d’un lac et, qui en dit long dans son fond ! Et
Florisse, un drôle de petit lutin farfelu, qui décidément se passionne pour les
fleurs et les « SACS à PAPIER » ! Puis vient le moment
d’affronter l’horreur, la pire chose, et cette odeur répugnante qui envahit
l’espace, le manque d’air, les hurlements des profondeurs torturées….
Heureusement il y a
encore la musique ! Mais que se passe-t-il vraiment ? Quel
est le contenu de cette  étrange petite
boîte ? Vous ne le savez toujours pas ?
Entrez, tendez l’oreille,
et regardez… »
Ce conte
musical, les enfants l’adorent. Les parents y sont sensibles aussi. Les
personnages sont haut en couleur, la musique de qualité, variée tantôt douce et
harmonieuse, tantôt jazzy et colorée. Enjoué,  émouvant, drôle, effrayant, il s’est invité
dans les familles, les écoles, et même en 
cours de chant ! En quelques années Les Lutins et le Farfama a trouvé son public et a rencontré un
succès formidable en région toulousaine.L'origine des Lutins et le Farfama.


Je
m’appelle Nadia NELL, et je suis passionnée de musique et des arts en
général  depuis ma plus tendre enfance. A
la suite de mes études (Premier Prix de piano, classes d’écriture, chant…), ma
passion fut entretenue grâce aux rencontres et aux partages avec toute sorte de
musiciens, amateurs ou professionnels, et grâce à la rencontre il y a quelques
années, d’une histoire pour enfant, écrite par une collègue clarinettiste, l’histoire
des Lutins et du Farfama.
L’envie d’écrire des chansons et les idées musicales se sont imposées à moi dès la première lecture. Il
fallait que cette musique jaillisse sur le papier;  l’écriture me rapprochait de mon enfance,
d’un état que j’exprime comme cela :
 Il me reste quelque chose de l’enfance si loin, si proche. Quelque
chose d’évanescent et cependant si présent, à chaque battement de cœur, à toute
respiration nouvelle. Un imaginaire qui vacille entre des mondes malfaisants et
des mondes héroïques, fait de jeux et de peurs, de danses et de combats. De
nombreuses fois, je m’y suis égarée avec délectation. Juste quelques minutes,
parfois des heures entières. 
J’y ai bougé et sculpté des images ; j’ai coloré cet espace
impalpable de mots, de gestes, de sons, de bruits, de musique. Quelque part…
Là, dans cet ailleurs, où tout prend vie : de nos espoirs les plus fous à
nos peurs les plus terrifiantes, où l’impossible n’existe pas… 
Alors cet imaginaire si présent ne
m’a plus laissé le choix. Il me fut dès lors impossible de laisser reposer ce
conte musical naissant dans un tiroir. Le chemin fut long : contacts
divers et variés avec des compagnies de théâtre, des maisons de disques, des
éditeurs… qui sais-je encore ? Les portes sont restées
irrémédiablement  fermées.
Qu’à cela ne tienne ! J’ai
retroussé mes manches, démultiplié mes
énergies et réalisé un CD en 2009 avec une quinzaine de mes amis musiciens,
chanteurs, acteurs. Le CD est édité par l’association Geste et Musique. Ce fut une belle aventure pour chacun d’entre
nous ! Je les remercie encore aujourd’hui du fond du cœur.
Puis ce fut la réalisation du site
internet www.farfama.fr avec
Olivier J. pour la diffusion de l’œuvre. Débordante d’idées, je crée des
supports pédagogiques et des activités créatives pour les enseignants, les
enfants et les familles. De nombreux
retours enthousiasmés d’enfants, de parents et de professeurs des écoles,
m’encouragent à poursuivre le chemin.
De plus, cet imaginaire me taraude
encore et toujours, il est là, je peux presque le toucher, les idées
s’amoncèlent. Alors il faut aller
jusqu’au bout, faire naître le spectacle, la scène. 
A nouveau, je retrousse mes
manches, apprends tout ce qui est lié à la gestion d’entreprise culturelle, et
je me lance : constitution des dossiers, contacts avec les personnalités
du métier, les programmateurs, recherche des acteurs, d’un chorégraphe, d’un régisseur,
etc.… Quelques portes s’ouvrent 
enfin ; des résidences, des dates de programmation. L’accueil est
chaleureux.
Le rêve est presque là.

MON BESOIN DE
FINANCEMENT

J’ai besoin de
vous. Votre participation, à partir de 10€, permet de réaliser un élément
supplémentaire à la création :
-   décor (une réalisation graphique, 3 volumes peints, 2 panneaux
amovibles)
-   7 costumes ;
-   accessoires ;
-   une grande marionnette : un écureuil
d’1,20m.
Mon besoin total de financement est de 5500€.
L’équipe artistique et technique se compose
aujourd’hui de 11 personnes impliquées et motivées par le développement de la
création. La costumière,
le graphiste et la décoratrice-marionnettiste sont prêts. Les idées
reposent  sur le papier et les croquis
attendent de prendre vie dans les cartons.
En 2012, la vente des CD a permis
de financer un  l'emploi à mi temps de Clémentine L., Chargée de communication et diffusion pendant 3 mois. Aujourd’hui,
l’association Geste et Musique ne
peut couvrir l’ensemble des frais incompressibles de production. Elle est
soutenue par le Crédit Mutuel (500€ en 2012) et le Conseil Régional de la haute
Garonne (500€ en 2013).
Parallèlement, je travaille sans
relâche à une diffusion nationale pour que ce spectacle voyage et pour lui
assurer une vie à long terme. Une captation vidéo est prévue pour la communication.

VOUS POUVEZ EGALEMENT M'AIDER DE DIFFERENTES MANIERES
‐  Réservez vos
places pour les premières
représentations qui auront lieu à l’Auditorium de Balma (31 Haute-Garonne), le 21 décembre 2013 sur http://www.farfama.fr/
‐ Commandez CD et/ou partitions sur http://www.farfama.fr/
pour vos enfants,
petits enfants, amis (anniversaires, Noël), vos élèves,….
‐ Diffusez l’information à tous vos
amis, vos contacts, aux enseignants, et tout ceux qui aiment le spectacle
vivant, le théâtre, la musique et la danse, et ….  les
projets qui naissent de rencontres et de passion !

EN CONTREPARTIE

En
contrepartie, je peux vous proposer de recevoir une photo dédicacée par
l’ensemble des artistes, un CD du conte, un T shirt, deux places de spectacle
pour venir chanter, danser, vous émouvoir et applaudir les artistes, une vidéo
à voir et à revoir, ou encore une chanson spécialement écrite pour vous.

story:
UPDATE

Tickets are on sale now. Seating is very limited in our space, so be sure to reserve your tickets in advance.

http://thirteenthfairy.brownpapertickets.com

We're Baaack!

As you may have noticed, our first fundraising campaign was a rousing success.  Those generous donations allowed us to secure rehearsal and performance space at the historic Jan Hus Playhouse.  As members of the newly formed Jan Hus Arts Collective, we are thrilled to be working on a stage where such legends as Robin Williams, Jerry Seinfeld, and Barbara Streisand (in her New York debut) once performed. 

With our space secured, we were able to assemble an extraordinarily talented group of actors and a production staff we're extremely excited to work with.  This second round of fundraising will be focused on the production itself.  There are still many things to be paid for and with your support we can put the final pieces of the puzzle together! 

If you already donated to our first campaign, we (once again) thank you a thousand times!  We would like to make clear that this campaign is a continuation of that one, and that you should feel absolutely no obligation to contribute again - you've already been incredibly generous! Still want to help? Pass this link on to your friends, put it on Facebook, and help us get the word out... We can't wait to see you at the show!

Once Upon a Time...

Briar Rose & the Thirteenth Fairy tells the classic tale of Sleeping Beauty through the eyes of both the hero and the villain.  Weaving together the narratives of storytelling greats Perrault, Basile, Walt Disney, and The Brothers Grimm, playwright Caroline Angell has re-imagined a very old story for an audience of all ages.  

What happens when you wake up one morning and 100 years have passed you by?  How do you protect the innocence of your children in a world where evil is ever-present?  And what's the best way to keep your Horse's snotty attitude in check?  The universal questions posed by this timeless fairy tale are addressed in a charming, hilarious, and occasionally terrifying manner in this new production, presented by Everyday Inferno.

At an NYC Theatre...

Even if you can't contribute now, we hope you'll come see our show!

May 1, 2, 3, 4, 8, 9, 10 at 8:00 PM; May 5 at 7:00 PM
Neighborhood night (discounted for neighborhood residents): May 6 at 7:30 PM
Jan Hus Playhouse
351 E 74th Street, New York, NY 10021

Reserve tickets at http://thirteenthfairy.brownpapertickets.com/ or by phone (347-291-1805) or email (everydayinferno@gmail.com).

Some very dedicated individuals...

Writer: Caroline Angell
Director: Anais Koivisto
Producer: Katherine Sommer
Stage Manager: Emily Rosenkrantz
Lighting Designer: Carla Linton

Featuring:
Elise Arndt, Kathryn Connors, Lindsay Cook, Augustin J Correro, Leslie Gauthier, Paul Gregg, Peregrine Heard, Jonathan Hendrickson, Hank Lin, Mia Rohrer, Benjamin Drew Thompson

Asked their family and friends for some help...

It costs a lot of money to produce theatre in New York!  Previous donations have allowed us to pay for our theatre space, but there are still many production elements we have not yet covered.  Your contributions will go toward:

  • Materials for set construction, props, and puppetry
  • Compensation for our cast and designers
  • Transportation of materials
  • Insurance to keep our artists and space safe
  • Costs related to listing and publicizing the production
  • Costume elements, fabrics, and construction

It is our goal to keep our production costs (and therefore our ticket prices) as low as we can. Your donations allow us to maintain our high standards for quality while creating theatre that is both accessible and affordable.

And made a very convincing case...

In addition to the perks we offer, and our undying gratitude, here are a couple more reasons to consider making a contribution:
  • For the greater good! By forging a relationship with this historic space, we are working to provide low-cost tickets to an area underserved by theatre.
  • Help us build something special! This is our first fully staged production, but we have plenty of projects planned for the future. Your contribution will not only help us to launch this specific production, but to create a future for our company.
  • Make great theatre! We think this play is going to be pretty wonderful (if we do say so ourselves) - your contribution gives you the right to take some credit for it.
  • Gain our undying gratitude! We know we already said this, but seriously, we can't stress it enough. 

The heroic friends and family saved the day...

You can give us any amount of money you wish. And you can opt out of the associated perk (although you'll still get a "thank you" from us!) by selecting "contribute now" instead of clicking on one of the offered perks.

With their tax deductible donations...

All donations are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law.

They spread the word throughout the kingdom...

Money is fantastic but nothing beats word of mouth. Not everyone who is interested in our project has money to contribute – we completely understand that. Want to help in some other way? Get the word out!

Share the link to this page on Facebook or Twitter (check out the helpful "share" buttons at the top of this page- right under the picture)! Talk us up to your friends at parties! However you choose to do it, we deeply appreciate it.   

And they all lived happily ever after!

story:
Aloha from Houston, Texas! A little bit about us...

We are Halau Ho'ola Ka Mana O Hawai'i, a traditional hula school based in Houston, Texas. The name of the halau (hula school) means, "Resurrect the power of Hawai'i -- the hula."  We welcome all to join our halau because it is our belief that anyone with a passion for Hawaiian culture and hula is welcome to learn with us.

In July, we plan to enter Ho'ike Hawai'i, a hula competition being hosted in Orlando, Florida. We will be joining together 3 hula schools based in Houston, Dallas and Oklahoma so that we may compete as one under the direction of Kumu Hula Keli'i Chang, III. The competition is a two-day event, and you can learn more at http://www.hoikehawaii.com/competition.html.

To learn more about our halau (school) and our Kumu (teacher), visit us online at www.houstonhalau.org.

Fundraising Goal and the Perks for Donors

We would like to enter this competition with 40 students ranging in age from 10 to 65 years, with many of our students being keiki or children.

Our goal as a group is to raise $15,000 in order to be able to take all of our students with us who wish to compete.  This amount will cover our competition registration fees; ground transportation from Houston and Oklahoma to Florida; lodging; costumes; hula implements and meals.  We are making our own costumes and implements, so your funds will help us with purchasing supplies.

Donors will receive perks ranging from being listed on our website (which is gaining a great deal of exposure in the Houston area) to our highest level donors receiving a photo of our group taken at the competition. Of course, we will be grateful for any level of kokua (help) -- and every donation -- regardless of the amount -- will be met with our deepest gratitude.

Also, we are now a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Halau Ho'ola Ka Mana O Hawai'i must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. Please donate online through this campaign or make checks payable to Fractured Atlas and mail to 7601 W. Sam Houston Pkwy S. Unit 650, Houston, TX 77036.

The Impact

Our participation in this competition is one step along our journey to leave a lasting impact on the sharing of Hawaiian culture and values.  In his 30 year career, our Kumu has successfully taught other teachers and participated in hula competitions like the King Kamehameha competition and Merrie Monarch. It is our goal to join the halau on the East Coast in this competition and be a part of the legacy there.  You too can be a part of this legacy when you donate to our Halau!

Other Ways You Can Kokua, or Help

Even if you are not able to contribute with a monetary donation, please know that we welcome your kokua, or help, in any other way:

  • Help us spread the word about our campaign to your family and friends!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to pass on this campaign
  • Contact us if you are able to give time or materials as we prepare for this competition. Every little bit will help!

Mahalo for your support. A hui hou!

story:
Message Me If...

is the premiere of the newly formed Chicago dance company, Kelly Anderson Dance Theatre.  Inspired by several years of unsuccessful relationships and the accumulation of horrible online dating disasters, this 35 year old choreographer decided to take matters into her own hands.  Contemporary dating sucked.  So, she decided to make a dance about it. 

As a recent transplant to Chicago, Kelly has had the great pleasure of experiencing the embrace of the Chicago dance community.  Though Chicago has an already vibrant scene, they welcomed her just the same.  Nine talented dancers from companies ranging from the independent to the established, took a risk and stepped into the studio with a brand new face.  Your support will help secure that taking this risk was the right choice.  Not only will your donations help the vision of Message Me If...come alive,  but it will also compensate incredibly talented artists for all of their hard work and dedication.  This is compensation that is well deserved.


The Show 

Message Me If...is an evening-length dance theater production about a single girl living in the contemporary dating world. Heartbreak karaoke, boozy first date disasters, cat-lady meltdowns, online catastrophes, a reality television tragedy and the infamous “ladies night” all make their way into the imaginary world she creates based on her unsuccessful quest for companionship. By telling the truth and stretching it, the audience will witness her direct the 9 dancer cast in the recreation of her love life misfortune. Episodically staged, they will observe the ins, outs and every angle of her journey as a modern day bachelorette. When will she be loved?

Message Me If...will also feature an original guest artist work by Melinda Jean Myers, to be performed by Kelly Anderson.



We need to raise $6,800


The funding needed to produce this independent work is coming from the pocket of the creator.  With your help, Kelly Anderson Dance Theatre will provide a stipend to the artists for their participation and time investment.  In addition, this is the Chicago premiere of Kelly Anderson Dance Theatre.   Your contribution will help make this production a success. Through Links Hall, Kelly was able to participate in a work exchange for a discounted theater rental and a reduced rehearsal space rate.  She spent three months as a marketing assistant to offer more room for fundraising to go into the pockets of her dancers.  We hope to reach this goal and to, potentially, surpass it.  


The Breakdown:

Compensation to the artists- $2,200

Rehearsal space rental Feb-Nov- $2,200

Lighting Designer- $500

Theater Rental- $400

Documentation- $400

Costuming/Props- $300

Flyer/Postcards- $200

Photography for Flyer/Postcard- $100

Projector rental- $100

Videography in Message Me If...- $400



Other Ways To Help

The greatest support we can receive is to have you seated in our audience.  Even if you are unable to contribute personally to Indiegogo, we hope that you will pass along this link.  Please share this campaign on Facebook or to friends via Email.  Most importantly, help us spread the word about Message Me If...and fill the house!


Message Me If...

November 14th-16th, 7pm

Where:

Links Hall

3111 N. Western Ave.
Chicago, IL 60618

Purchase Tickets:

https://www.ticketfly.com/search/?q=message+me+if

or visit

http://www.kellyandersondancetheatre.com/

https://www.ticketfly.com/search/?q=message+me+if
or visit
http://www.kellyandersondancetheatre.com/

story:
The Forgetting Curve | a world premiere production

In September, a dynamic team of producers, designers, technicians, and actors will bring The Forgetting Curve to life for the first time. This world premiere play is inspired in part by the true-life story of Patient HM, who in his teen years underwent an experimental neurosurgery to treat epilepsy, which instead destroyed his brain's ability to form new memories.

The Forgetting Curve is told through the lens of fictional doctor, Laura Nebbens. While HM hasn't formed a new memory in over 40 years, Dr. Nebbens struggles to reconcile her past. Ahead of receiving a prestigious achievement award in her field, she questions what she sacrificed to leave the legacy of her life's work. Through this Indiegogo campaign, you can help create a memory -- please chip in what you can, and be a part of bringing this fascinating story to Boston. 


This Campaign | nuts & bolts

In order to support our people, we need to provide them with the materials, space, and other physical resources that allow them to do their work. We've triple checked our budgets and know exactly what we need to cover the various nuts & bolts that will bring The Forgetting Curve to fruition. That's why we're raising $14,867 for things like this:

  • $10 buys a roll of spike tape, so our stage manager can make sure everything and everyone is in the right place
  • $25 prints and binds one script, so it's easy for an actor to hold at rehearsal
  • $50 provides dinner for our crew during a grueling, 12 hour load-in
  • $100 buys two tanks of gas, enough to transport the New York based members of our design team round trip for technical rehearsals 
  • $250 lets us print postcards, so our team can promote this work to the world
  • $500 allows one team member to travel in November to Washington, DC, where we have been invited to present the show at the Annual Meeting of the Society for Neuroscience
  • $1000 covers one week's rent and box office fees at our performance venue


The Impact | more reasons to give

Any donation, large or small, will help provide our people with the resources they need to make The Forgetting Curve an engaging experience for our audience. Meanwhile, these fun facts about the project may also inspire you to give:
  • The Forgetting Curve is a brand new play 
  • The script has been commissioned to be presented this November at the Annual Meeting of the Society for Neuroscience in Washington, DC
  • More than half of our creative team is female
  • Our playwright, Vanda, is a member of the LGBTQ community, and has included positive portrayals of LGBTQ characters in the script

    It Takes A Village | other ways to help

    Can't chip in any green backs at the moment? No worries, we get it. You can still help!

    • Please share this campaign on social media
    • Please let us know if you can donate housing or volunteer hours

     

    Our Team | getting to know you

    The Forgetting Curve is being produced by a dynamic team of producers. Here's the roster!

    • Kimberly Loren Eaton & Theatrum Mundi Productions
    • Olivia D'Ambrosio & Bridge Repertory Theater of Boston
    • Alan Swanke
    • Cole Burden
    • Joseph W. Rodriguez & Playhouse Creatures Theatre Company


      Thanks, one and all, for your generous support of The Forgetting Curve.

story:
What?

S/K is a play about a trapped horse. S/K is an ancient brocade technology and a real loom. S/K is a bloody butcher who could not forget his dead horse, a digital female voice and gallows. S/K is made of wood, bamboo, blood, bones, hemp. S/K interrogates our cultural DNA and asks who we really are. Is it true that what we inherit from the past is what suffocates us in the present? Are we the product of this cultural machine, or is this machine the product of us? Are we repeating the same pattern years after years? Should we break this machine, free the horse and end it all?


How?

S/K is a multimedia performance piece written by Tingying Ma featuring:

1 - 9 foot loom created in Chengdu, Sichuan China

2 - Very talented performers


Why do we need you?

In order to bring S/K to life, we want to bring an authentic piece of Chengdu weaving culture to NYC to share with the theater community, a Shujin loom. The centerpiece of our show, our 9 foot tall loom, was created in Chengdu by a weaving and carpentry master who also created a horse puppet for S/K. The cost of shipping a giant loom and horse puppet across the Pacific is substantial for our little show, help us bring this striking set piece to Signature Theatre.  We hope to also use the loom in a future production of S/K in the NY metro area soon!

When? Where?

Performances of S/K will take place at Ford Studio at Pershing Square Signature Theatre Center at 480 W 42nd St.

Friday, May 1st at 2:30pm & 8pm

Saturday, May 2nd at 2:30pm

Tickets at www.columbiastages.org

Who?

If our show doesn't convince you, maybe our amazing team will!

Tingying Ma - Director and Playwright

Ong Keng Sen - Project Mentor

Polina Bogacheva - Co-Producer

Meghan Dixon - Co-Producer

Blake Kile* - Stage Manager


Kiyo Takami* - Performer


Nan Wei & Nova Pan - Video/Graphic Designers

Ye Fu Liu - Sound Designer

Xiao Fu - Set Design

You Xian Jiang - Loom Carpenter


This production is part of New Plays Now, a presentation of Columbia University School of the Arts Playwright Thesis productions. S/K is Tingying Ma's MFA Thesis Production.

*Appear courtesy of Actors' Equity Association

story:
WHY?  Because.....

If I can touch one person, give one person permission to speak up, inspire hope or plant a seed, that is why I love doing this.  I am Laura Grimaldi and this is my story and my experiences with sexual abuse, domestic violence, bad choices and digging myself out from which those trenches engulfed me .  How many times do I have to fall in that hole before I learn to walk around it or better yet, walk on the other side of the street?  As I tell my children, if you can learn from my mistakes even a little bit, then I've done my job well.  I'm just taking that to a bigger scale.  If you can laugh at my mishaps and learn a little something along the way, I will have lived my purpose and executed it in a place I love to be which is on stage. 

A little bit about me, I am a California Native.  I was born and raised in Northern California by my mother who stayed at home and worked odd jobs and my "father" who was never home.  Yes, quotes are there on purpose.  Mystery story number 1.  I have three children and I lived in Virginia for 18 years, 10 of which were under duress.  That's a whole other story.  I am now living in North Hollywood, CA and I'm married to my third husband, in separate residences.  And that's another story.  See what you're gonna miss if you don't come? 

All joking aside, my story touches on very sensitive subjects with a touch of humor and a lot of love.  It's a story in being true and raw and loving the beauties we all are in our own unique way.  Circumstances never matter.  Our world as we perceive it all lies with our state of being in it. 

WHERE?  Hollywood Fringe Festival 2018 Baby!!!

Last year, I performed in an ensemble production in the Hollywood Fringe Festival 2017.  This is where I got the bug.  Hollywood Fringe is just about the biggest theatre festival where the arts infiltrate the Hollywood neighborhood.  Participation is completely open and uncensored where all artists from all over the world can come and speak their truth in the most creative of ways. If you'd like to know more about Hollywood Fringe, here is their link.  www.hollywoodfringe.org.

What We Need 

 

In addition to being creative and vulnerable in sharing our art, this venture is also a completely self supporting effort where all participants self produce and fund their work as well.  

 Which brings me to why I'm asking for your help.  I am asking for 6500.00.  Your contributions will make a difference in supporting the arts as well as helping me with my out of pocket costs for the following:

Registration Fee, Theatre Rental, Insurance, Director, Stage Manager, Technical Director, Marketing and Public Relations.  

Even though this is a one person production, doesn't mean that it doesn't take a village to make it great!!!

The Impact

Anytime another woman shares her story there is an impact.  I hope to entertain, inspire and educate just a little whatever that means to each individual.  Our stories NEED to be told.  The more we share, the more we heal. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate money, you can help by getting the word out about the show!  Share this page as well as Left Turns on facebook!  Also use the hashtag!  #leftturns whenever you post! 

Any and all help and donations are appreciated!

Come on the journey with me!!!  Hopefully I'll see you at the show!

story:
DIRECTOR'S PITCH

 

Carla Fonseca (director and producer of MODJADJI, The Rain Queen) explains why we need your support and talks about her motivation to create MODJADJI.

 

WHAT'S THE STORY?

 

 "The best piece of art I have ever seen. A pure masterpiece" - Karabo Makenna (Art Director, JHB)

MODJADJI is not a linear play at all, there are so many stories being told within the piece.  This is a play that strongly engages with themes of drought, violence, rape, replenishment, politics and power; and how they all interlink. The visually gripping and multimedia infused production traces a journey through social, political and cultural views.The characters in the play shift and interchange at all times. The space transforms. There is not one thing that doesn't shift or move. 

Modjadji deconstructs the mystical rituals, social turmoil, love songs, lullabies and history that all form part of South Africa.

"You have healed me, Thank you for such powerful work." - Warona Seane (Actress, CPT)

 

WHY DOES IT MATTER?

Radical changes in political, social and cultural thinking over the past twenty years have significantly affected concepts of historiography and have caused major re-evaluations of accepted histories and mythologies across the world. This sense of (re)discovery has had a strong impact on concepts of cultural history in post-Apartheid South Africa. It has meant rediscovering lost facts, redefining principles of historiography, mythology, as well as reinterpreting the old, and ultimately seeking to write a new history. The most fundamental issue of course is to uncover the vast treasure-trove of events and artefacts produced before and during the colonial period, but ignored, denied or undervalued by commentators in the past. 

MODJADJI is an avant-garde contemporary production about current affairs, about life in South Africa today and about our mythologies. We believe that a wider spectrum of African stories deserve to be told, especially the ones that help make sense of what the country and the continent are today.

MODJADJI matters because A) The Rain Queen is a real life God in South African culture, she is reincarnated in human form and has provided us with life sustaining rain for hundreds of years, yet her story is not often told; and B) it is a proactive attempt by a new generation of theatre makers to shake and push theatre forward into new directions, new subject matters, and new artistic explorations. We believe that by motivating the audience to fund the play, we are reducing dependency from conventional and often colonial funding channels. We want the success of this play to be funded by those who believe in African vision. 

 

SO, WHO CREATED THIS?

The director, Carla Fonseca, obsessed with telling stories, believes in the power of healing through theatre. Since graduating (BA Theatre & Performance) from the University of Cape Town in 2010, she has focussed her work on South Africa's historical and current societal traumas for nearly a decade.

Carla is vigorous in helping encourage a stronger theatre & performance art culture within Southern Africa. Her work includes a variety of media to achieve her creative objectives. She draws most of her inspiration from personal experiences, street art, lowbrow art, African tradition and global affairs. Her zeal lies within Avant Garde theatre and installation based performance art

In this production, her latest work, she decided to invite a group of brilliant minds together to workshop and develop her idea. It took nearly three years to put together. The ensemble includes Mandla Mbothwe as co-director, Nthato Mokgata (Spoek Mathambo) as sound designer, Iman Isaacs as choreographer and performer, Indalo Stofile, Richard September, and TJ Ngoma as performers and Ryno Keet as lighting designer. Needless to say, the show is a great success onstage because of the unprecedented collaboration which drives it. 

 

WHY DO WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT?

“It takes a village to make a theatre production...” Okay, it doesn’t go exactly like that… But, for independent theatre makers, it's really not that different. Over the past 3 years producer and director, Carla Fonseca has saved all she could, with two small sponsorships along the way, to make MODJADJI come alive. She has lost some money in the process, but she remains committed and dedicated to the vision. The team has workshopped and recreated the script over and over to find creative ways of saving money without compromising the quality and vision they have. 

We have a product, and we want to share it. And sharing it means booking rehearsal venues, booking flights, booking accommodation for cast/crew, feeding tummies, paying artist fee's (at industry standard), hiring theatres, paying for marketing, and making this show come alive again. We have approached sponsors and we hope that they will throw some coins at us, but lets be real, the corporates don't sponsor theatre....so we need your support to achieve the $17 000 we lack in our budget. 

Please join us in this dream and help us make bring the great production to Johannesburg (first) and then the rest of the globe. Believe in us. 

 

WHERE DOES YOUR CONTRIBUTION GO?

See below how we'll use the funds raised during the campaign. This budget will cover 1 month pre-prod, 2 week rehearsal and 1 week run. Seven days a week.

 

HOW ELSE CAN YOU HELP?

Share the campaign as much as you can (don’t forget to include a link to this page)! Talk to your friends, colleagues and family about our production MODJADJI, the campaign and how we hope to contribute to South African theatre and the development of young theatre makers! 

Mention MODJADJI on your social networks, website, blog, vlog, vine or however you express your creativity. Take a megaphone and walk around your neighborhood encouraging every person you see to join us! We are grateful for every bit of support you show us!

 

MEET THE TEAM

Mandla Mbothwe - CO-DIRECTOR

 Mandla Mbotwe a renowned director in   South Africa was the Creative Manager for   Artscape Theatre Centre since 2014, his   theatre is based in Cape Town, South   Africa. Between 2011 and 2013, he was the   Artistic Director of The Steve Biko Centre   Performing Arts based in Eastern Cape.  He was awarded his Honours degree and   distinction in Masters Degree in Theatre   and Performance at the University of Cape   Town where he worked as a lecturer and   researcher in the drama department from   2003 to 2010.  In 2002 he worked with   Magnet Theatre as the Artistic Director   and management team until 2010; now he   serve as a member on the board of trustees.

For the past two decades Mbothwe has been involved in the development of the arts. He has delivered a paper on South African‘s 20 Years of Democracy - Theatre and Performance in Glasgow’ Scotland. He curated ‘I am not the other” for Artscape and British Council South Africa international disability day in 2015 where 13 productions took part during the Infecting the City International Festival. 

Mbothwe conceptualised and curated Artscape Easter Spiritual Arts Festival in 2015, directed a dance musical Kugqityiwe/Intando..its done/the will’.

 

   Nthato Mokgata (Spoek Mathambo) - MUSIC DESIGNER

 Spoek Mathambo (born Nthato   Mokgata) is a South African artist,   producer, film maker, singer-   songwriter  defined by his fusion of a   wide array of musical influences and   his   coining the terms Guzu and   Township Tech to describe two styles   of   music he produces. His unique   vision on electronic music, infuses   futurism with a strong sense of pride in   where he comes from. It is clearly   African music, but like none that has   ever been heard or made before.

 Spoek Mathambo released music on some of the most prominent underground dance music labels such as BBE, Mad Decent, Boys Noize Records, Shitkatapult, Get Physical and Man Recordings. Mathambo topped things off with a grip of visually thrilling videos depicting a fresh-to-death urban gothic vibe which received the Young Director Award at the 2011 Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity. Meanwhile Mathambo was nominated in the Best African Act category at the 2011 Mobo Awards.

Mathambo released his second album Father Creeper on Sub Pop, gaining him a second nomination for Best African Act, at the 2012 MOBO Awards. He was also nominated for Best African Act for the third time at the 2013 MOBO awards.

Spoek, directed a feature length documentary film, Future Sound of Mzansi, about South African electronic music in 2014. Spoek has continued to perform in South Africa, Angola, Ethiopia, UK, USA, China, Canada, New Zealand, Dubai, France, Germany, Portugal, Spain, Italy, Romania, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Finland, Brazil, Argentina and many other countries. 

 

Iman Isaacs - CHOREOGRAPHER/ACTOR

  Upon graduating from the University of Cape Town in   2011 with a BA in theatre and performance acting,   bilingual English and Afrikaans, Iman travelled on behalf   of UCT to New Delhi for 2 months to collaborate with   and   perform alongside graduates from the National   School of Drama. It was a cultural exchange that   explored power dynamics and gender equality through   traditional storytelling and song. Iman is the founder and   co-director of The Poor Artists Theatre collective. A   young theatre company, who create original works that   provoke audiences to enter into a thought process of   evaluation and reflection. These works include Eden, A funny Thing Happened on the way to the Talent Show, The Digital Man and The Bitching Hour. The Bitching Hour was a collaborative process where 8 actresses gathered to interrogate, question and reflect about what it means to be a young woman in South Africa. This was performed in the form of a chorus using the power of the combined voice. In 2012 she played the supporting female role in an international film directed by Jerome Salle acting alongside Forest Whitaker and Orlando Bloom. City of Violence was featured at the closing ceremony of the Cannes Film Festival and premiered in Cape Town in November 2014. She taught movement at City Varsity and worked with children at Muizenberg High School under the Zakheni Arts Therapy Foundation. At Zakheni she worked as the drama practitioner alongside a therapist and they devised workshops to help uplift the lives of children from troubled homes.

 

Indalo Stofile - ACTOR

 Indalo Stofile is an artist born in the Eastern Cape   and grew up in Cape Town. She started getting   involvement in theatre in 2006 as part of   Community group intervention program in   Khayelitsha. She graduated as class medalist   (Best   Actress) from UCT drama school in 2011,   where she studied Theatre and Performance. She   describes herself as an actress, singer, mover, any   way she can break myself down to express. She   has worked with directors in the industry that are driving innovative, contemporary theatre. Indalo has appeared in various productions by Mandla Mbothwe including Bokumnka Bonke,Uvuko,Amazwi which was showcased at Infecting the City festival in 2014. Another production was Madeia under the direction of Brett Bailey which toured Europe in 2013. She appeared in Joanna Evans' King Kong What Whatt at Graham's town Arts Festival in 2014. Indigo is a resident performer of Magnet theatre under the direction of Mark Fleishman and Jennie Reznek. She is currently performing in The Heart of Redness by Zakes Mda running at the Furgard Theatre.

Richard September - ACTOR

 Richard September is Cape Town based performance artist and   freelance actor. His skills include physical theatre, dance and Bunraku   (style) puppetry.  In 2013 he played supporting roles in Athol Fugard’s   Die Laaste Karretjie Graf as well as Magnet Theatre’s  Voices Made   Night at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. He has twice presented work   at   GIPCA’s Biannual Live Art Festival where he performed Category   Syndrome in 2014. In the same year he acted in Rachelle Greef’s   Rondomskrik, for which he has received various awards and   nominations.

 Most recently he has performed in Penny Youngleson’s Nat and the   Kyknet series, Buurtwag. He is set to perform in the debut of two plays in Sep/Oct 2015 including a solo act titled Rooivalk. Richard holds a BA in Theatre and Performance from the University of Cape Town.

 

TJ Ngoma - ACTOR

 Thandisa "TJ" Ngoma is a performer that hails from the   vibrant Eastern Cape. With a strong Xhosa heritage and   a Christian upbringing, TJ has always been exposed to a   variety of beliefs and customs, which have ultimately   influenced his performance style. Trained in theatre, he   obtained a Diploma in Theatre and Performance at the   University of Cape Town in 2011.

 

Since then he has appeared in television shows, films and theatre productions. Not only is this young artist a lover of every type of performance, he also has a budding passion to explore other spheres in his craft such as teaching, writing and directing.

Ryno Keet:

 Ryno Keet, spent his formative years (1996-2004) in   the Zip-Zap Circus School where he trained and   performed locally and internationally in various circus   disciplines. He has worked as a stuntman on various   commercials and films as well as some time spent   working at Cosmesis Advanced Special Effects Studio.   He has worked with Jay Pather on various projects,   festivals and productions over the course of 8 years   including Infecting the City Public Arts Festival   (Technical- Production manager, Co-Curator and Director), Production Manager of the ICA Live Arts Festival, Spier Festival of White Lights (Technical Director) The most recent productions being  What Remains ,written by Nadia Davids, Directed by Jay Pather (NAF 2017 & Afrovibes Festival 2017 in Netherlands), Red Aloes Written and Directed by Themba Stewart and The Rabble, created by Iman Izaacs and Richard September 2017 He is a free-lance lighting designer, lighting and AV technician, Stage & Production-Manager, Set-designer and fabricator by day but always a creative at heart. 

 

YOU MIGHT BE ASKING YOURSELF...

 

  • When do you plan to stage the play in Johannesburg?

We will wait until the crowdfunding campaign finishes to close the final dates, but we aim to run the show in June 2019. 

  • What happens if the campaign doesn’t reach its goal?

We will keep determined to prove that it’s worth chasing the dreams we believe in. We will find a way of raising funds to showcase MODJADJI, even if it means we have to downscale the scale of the production. 

  • What if you get more money than you asked for?

Yaaaasss!!! We love and share your optimism! :) If that happens we'll be looking to invest in setting up a possible run at a theatre festival abroad (currently looking at NYC and UK as options for fringe festivals), which would be an absolute dream come true!!!

 

If you have other questions about this campaign, please send us a message. We promise to answer within 72 hours. If we take longer, the director Carla Fonseca will have to record a video singing a song of your choosing  (believe us, the idea freaks her out!)

 

FROM ALL OF US: 

SIYABONGA! THANK YOU! KANIMAMBO!

FOR SUPPORTING MODJADJI
story_txt: DIRECTOR'S PITCH Carla Fonseca (director and producer of MODJADJI, The Rain Queen) explains why we need your support and talks about her motivation to create MODJADJI. WHAT'S THE STORY?  "The best piece of art I have ever seen. A pure masterpiece" - Karabo Makenna (Art Director, JHB)MODJADJI is not a linear play at all, there are so many stories being told within the piece.  This is a play that strongly engages with themes of drought, violence, rape, replenishment, politics and power; and how they all interlink. The visually gripping and multimedia infused production traces a journey through social, political and cultural views.The characters in the play shift and interchange at all times. The space transforms. There is not one thing that doesn't shift or move. Modjadji deconstructs the mystical rituals, social turmoil, love songs, lullabies and history that all form part of South Africa."You have healed me, Thank you for such powerful work." - Warona Seane (Actress, CPT) WHY DOES IT MATTER?Radical changes in political, social and cultural thinking over the past twenty years have significantly affected concepts of historiography and have caused major re-evaluations of accepted histories and mythologies across the world. This sense of (re)discovery has had a strong impact on concepts of cultural history in post-Apartheid South Africa. It has meant rediscovering lost facts, redefining principles of historiography, mythology, as well as reinterpreting the old, and ultimately seeking to write a new history. The most fundamental issue of course is to uncover the vast treasure-trove of events and artefacts produced before and during the colonial period, but ignored, denied or undervalued by commentators in the past. MODJADJI is an avant-garde contemporary production about current affairs, about life in South Africa today and about our mythologies. We believe that a wider spectrum of African stories deserve to be told, especially the ones that help make sense of what the country and the continent are today.MODJADJI matters because A) The Rain Queen is a real life God in South African culture, she is reincarnated in human form and has provided us with life sustaining rain for hundreds of years, yet her story is not often told; and B) it is a proactive attempt by a new generation of theatre makers to shake and push theatre forward into new directions, new subject matters, and new artistic explorations. We believe that by motivating the audience to fund the play, we are reducing dependency from conventional and often colonial funding channels. We want the success of this play to be funded by those who believe in African vision.  SO, WHO CREATED THIS?The director, Carla Fonseca, obsessed with telling stories, believes in the power of healing through theatre. Since graduating (BA Theatre & Performance) from the University of Cape Town in 2010, she has focussed her work on South Africa's historical and current societal traumas for nearly a decade.Carla is vigorous in helping encourage a stronger theatre & performance art culture within Southern Africa. Her work includes a variety of media to achieve her creative objectives. She draws most of her inspiration from personal experiences, street art, lowbrow art, African tradition and global affairs. Her zeal lies within Avant Garde theatre and installation based performance artIn this production, her latest work, she decided to invite a group of brilliant minds together to workshop and develop her idea. It took nearly three years to put together. The ensemble includes Mandla Mbothwe as co-director, Nthato Mokgata (Spoek Mathambo) as sound designer, Iman Isaacs as choreographer and performer, Indalo Stofile, Richard September, and TJ Ngoma as performers and Ryno Keet as lighting designer. Needless to say, the show is a great success onstage because of the unprecedented collaboration which drives it.  WHY DO WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT?“It takes a village to make a theatre production...” Okay, it doesn’t go exactly like that… But, for independent theatre makers, it's really not that different. Over the past 3 years producer and director, Carla Fonseca has saved all she could, with two small sponsorships along the way, to make MODJADJI come alive. She has lost some money in the process, but she remains committed and dedicated to the vision. The team has workshopped and recreated the script over and over to find creative ways of saving money without compromising the quality and vision they have. We have a product, and we want to share it. And sharing it means booking rehearsal venues, booking flights, booking accommodation for cast/crew, feeding tummies, paying artist fee's (at industry standard), hiring theatres, paying for marketing, and making this show come alive again. We have approached sponsors and we hope that they will throw some coins at us, but lets be real, the corporates don't sponsor theatre....so we need your support to achieve the $17 000 we lack in our budget. Please join us in this dream and help us make bring the great production to Johannesburg (first) and then the rest of the globe. Believe in us.  WHERE DOES YOUR CONTRIBUTION GO?See below how we'll use the funds raised during the campaign. This budget will cover 1 month pre-prod, 2 week rehearsal and 1 week run. Seven days a week. HOW ELSE CAN YOU HELP?Share the campaign as much as you can (don’t forget to include a link to this page)! Talk to your friends, colleagues and family about our production MODJADJI, the campaign and how we hope to contribute to South African theatre and the development of young theatre makers! Mention MODJADJI on your social networks, website, blog, vlog, vine or however you express your creativity. Take a megaphone and walk around your neighborhood encouraging every person you see to join us! We are grateful for every bit of support you show us! MEET THE TEAMMandla Mbothwe - CO-DIRECTOR Mandla Mbotwe a renowned director in   South Africa was the Creative Manager for   Artscape Theatre Centre since 2014, his   theatre is based in Cape Town, South   Africa. Between 2011 and 2013, he was the   Artistic Director of The Steve Biko Centre   Performing Arts based in Eastern Cape.  He was awarded his Honours degree and   distinction in Masters Degree in Theatre   and Performance at the University of Cape   Town where he worked as a lecturer and   researcher in the drama department from   2003 to 2010.  In 2002 he worked with   Magnet Theatre as the Artistic Director   and management team until 2010; now he   serve as a member on the board of trustees.For the past two decades Mbothwe has been involved in the development of the arts. He has delivered a paper on South African‘s 20 Years of Democracy - Theatre and Performance in Glasgow’ Scotland. He curated ‘I am not the other” for Artscape and British Council South Africa international disability day in 2015 where 13 productions took part during the Infecting the City International Festival. Mbothwe conceptualised and curated Artscape Easter Spiritual Arts Festival in 2015, directed a dance musical Kugqityiwe/Intando..its done/the will’.    Nthato Mokgata (Spoek Mathambo) - MUSIC DESIGNER Spoek Mathambo (born Nthato   Mokgata) is a South African artist,   producer, film maker, singer-   songwriter  defined by his fusion of a   wide array of musical influences and   his   coining the terms Guzu and   Township Tech to describe two styles   of   music he produces. His unique   vision on electronic music, infuses   futurism with a strong sense of pride in   where he comes from. It is clearly   African music, but like none that has   ever been heard or made before. Spoek Mathambo released music on some of the most prominent underground dance music labels such as BBE, Mad Decent, Boys Noize Records, Shitkatapult, Get Physical and Man Recordings. Mathambo topped things off with a grip of visually thrilling videos depicting a fresh-to-death urban gothic vibe which received the Young Director Award at the 2011 Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity. Meanwhile Mathambo was nominated in the Best African Act category at the 2011 Mobo Awards.Mathambo released his second album Father Creeper on Sub Pop, gaining him a second nomination for Best African Act, at the 2012 MOBO Awards. He was also nominated for Best African Act for the third time at the 2013 MOBO awards.Spoek, directed a feature length documentary film, Future Sound of Mzansi, about South African electronic music in 2014. Spoek has continued to perform in South Africa, Angola, Ethiopia, UK, USA, China, Canada, New Zealand, Dubai, France, Germany, Portugal, Spain, Italy, Romania, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Finland, Brazil, Argentina and many other countries.  Iman Isaacs - CHOREOGRAPHER/ACTOR  Upon graduating from the University of Cape Town in   2011 with a BA in theatre and performance acting,   bilingual English and Afrikaans, Iman travelled on behalf   of UCT to New Delhi for 2 months to collaborate with   and   perform alongside graduates from the National   School of Drama. It was a cultural exchange that   explored power dynamics and gender equality through   traditional storytelling and song. Iman is the founder and   co-director of The Poor Artists Theatre collective. A   young theatre company, who create original works that   provoke audiences to enter into a thought process of   evaluation and reflection. These works include Eden, A funny Thing Happened on the way to the Talent Show, The Digital Man and The Bitching Hour. The Bitching Hour was a collaborative process where 8 actresses gathered to interrogate, question and reflect about what it means to be a young woman in South Africa. This was performed in the form of a chorus using the power of the combined voice. In 2012 she played the supporting female role in an international film directed by Jerome Salle acting alongside Forest Whitaker and Orlando Bloom. City of Violence was featured at the closing ceremony of the Cannes Film Festival and premiered in Cape Town in November 2014. She taught movement at City Varsity and worked with children at Muizenberg High School under the Zakheni Arts Therapy Foundation. At Zakheni she worked as the drama practitioner alongside a therapist and they devised workshops to help uplift the lives of children from troubled homes. Indalo Stofile - ACTOR Indalo Stofile is an artist born in the Eastern Cape   and grew up in Cape Town. She started getting   involvement in theatre in 2006 as part of   Community group intervention program in   Khayelitsha. She graduated as class medalist   (Best   Actress) from UCT drama school in 2011,   where she studied Theatre and Performance. She   describes herself as an actress, singer, mover, any   way she can break myself down to express. She   has worked with directors in the industry that are driving innovative, contemporary theatre. Indalo has appeared in various productions by Mandla Mbothwe including Bokumnka Bonke,Uvuko,Amazwi which was showcased at Infecting the City festival in 2014. Another production was Madeia under the direction of Brett Bailey which toured Europe in 2013. She appeared in Joanna Evans' King Kong What Whatt at Graham's town Arts Festival in 2014. Indigo is a resident performer of Magnet theatre under the direction of Mark Fleishman and Jennie Reznek. She is currently performing in The Heart of Redness by Zakes Mda running at the Furgard Theatre.Richard September - ACTOR Richard September is Cape Town based performance artist and   freelance actor. His skills include physical theatre, dance and Bunraku   (style) puppetry.  In 2013 he played supporting roles in Athol Fugard’s   Die Laaste Karretjie Graf as well as Magnet Theatre’s  Voices Made   Night at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. He has twice presented work   at   GIPCA’s Biannual Live Art Festival where he performed Category   Syndrome in 2014. In the same year he acted in Rachelle Greef’s   Rondomskrik, for which he has received various awards and   nominations. Most recently he has performed in Penny Youngleson’s Nat and the   Kyknet series, Buurtwag. He is set to perform in the debut of two plays in Sep/Oct 2015 including a solo act titled Rooivalk. Richard holds a BA in Theatre and Performance from the University of Cape Town. TJ Ngoma - ACTOR Thandisa "TJ" Ngoma is a performer that hails from the   vibrant Eastern Cape. With a strong Xhosa heritage and   a Christian upbringing, TJ has always been exposed to a   variety of beliefs and customs, which have ultimately   influenced his performance style. Trained in theatre, he   obtained a Diploma in Theatre and Performance at the   University of Cape Town in 2011. Since then he has appeared in television shows, films and theatre productions. Not only is this young artist a lover of every type of performance, he also has a budding passion to explore other spheres in his craft such as teaching, writing and directing.Ryno Keet: Ryno Keet, spent his formative years (1996-2004) in   the Zip-Zap Circus School where he trained and   performed locally and internationally in various circus   disciplines. He has worked as a stuntman on various   commercials and films as well as some time spent   working at Cosmesis Advanced Special Effects Studio.   He has worked with Jay Pather on various projects,   festivals and productions over the course of 8 years   including Infecting the City Public Arts Festival   (Technical- Production manager, Co-Curator and Director), Production Manager of the ICA Live Arts Festival, Spier Festival of White Lights (Technical Director) The most recent productions being  What Remains ,written by Nadia Davids, Directed by Jay Pather (NAF 2017 & Afrovibes Festival 2017 in Netherlands), Red Aloes Written and Directed by Themba Stewart and The Rabble, created by Iman Izaacs and Richard September 2017 He is a free-lance lighting designer, lighting and AV technician, Stage & Production-Manager, Set-designer and fabricator by day but always a creative at heart.  YOU MIGHT BE ASKING YOURSELF... When do you plan to stage the play in Johannesburg?We will wait until the crowdfunding campaign finishes to close the final dates, but we aim to run the show in June 2019. What happens if the campaign doesn’t reach its goal?We will keep determined to prove that it’s worth chasing the dreams we believe in. We will find a way of raising funds to showcase MODJADJI, even if it means we have to downscale the scale of the production. What if you get more money than you asked for?Yaaaasss!!! We love and share your optimism! :) If that happens we'll be looking to invest in setting up a possible run at a theatre festival abroad (currently looking at NYC and UK as options for fringe festivals), which would be an absolute dream come true!!! If you have other questions about this campaign, please send us a message. We promise to answer within 72 hours. If we take longer, the director Carla Fonseca will have to record a video singing a song of your choosing  (believe us, the idea freaks her out!) FROM ALL OF US: SIYABONGA! THANK YOU! KANIMAMBO!FOR SUPPORTING MODJADJI

story:
Who is LFDC?

LightFighter Dance Company is a contemporary dance company based in Austin, Texas. LFDC seeks to create immersive, emotional and visceral contemporary movement for a broad audience. Esther Bramlett is a multi-disciplinary artist who creates narrative using modern dance, ballet, sculpture, photography, projection, burlesque, cabaret, and other storytelling techniques. Her narratives create platforms to develop communication, share experience and bring alternative perspectives to light through dance and performance.

Where is your money going?

This goal budget will provide LFDC the resources necessary to create and develop two original dance pieces. These pieces will be performed this fall for REVOLVE: A Movement Display in Austin, Texas (https://www.revolveaustin.com/)  and for Waco's {254} Dance-Fest (http://www.outonalimbdance.com/254-dance-fest.html). 

The $1600 fundraising goal will be used for the following:

-pay eight dancers $100 for their time and talent. ($800)

-pay for the set design, creation and color powder ($100)

-create 8 unique costumes ($100)

- 12 hours of studio space for rehearsal ($200)

-pay collaborators for their time and talent ($400)

Collaborators

Ruth Monroe is a sculptor, designer and founder of Lotus Ascension. She will be creating the costumes for the performances.

EZ Maldonado is the lead vocals and bassist for a local Austin band called First Time in Color. He will be creating an original music score for the performances.

Joseph Sanchez is a photographer and axe maker in Austin, Texas. He will be photographing all the performances as well as provided the photos for this Indiegogo.

Kianna Chauntis is a web developer and performance artist who designed our indiegogo video! 

Impact

Developing performance art that highlights alternative voices and marginal experiences will create an inclusive space where individuals can share their experiences. In addition to offering weekly modern technique classes in the community, LightFighter Dance has been commissioned to create for Austin companies such as Ballet East Dance Company and has been selected to perform for the Austin Dance Festival in 2016. 

If the funds we need are not met, LFDC will still perform at these Texas dance festivals but without paying their dancers or developing the full vision for the sculptural installation. 

 

LFDC understands that you may not be able to contribute financially to our company at this time, but we encourage you to share our vision for creating dance through facebook, social media, email or through the indiegogo share tools! Thank you for your help!

story:
Our Story

My name is Taryn Javier and I am a Calgary based contemporary dance artist. This coming fall I will be half of the Artist in Residence program at Dancers' Studio West here in Calgary. I receive seven weeks in the space and three shows produced at the close of the mentorship session.  However, no budget is left for my cast.  I have a cast of five dancers. They are: Jennifer DeWolf, Saxon Fraser, Winnie Ho, John Nguyen, and Tony Tran. These individuals could use their time to work, to train, or to be with friends and family, but instead have chosen to work towards creating a piece of dance work with me and with each other.  In those seven weeks we hope to create dance that will both have impact on each other through the creation and inspire our audience.


The Impact

If this money can be raised; here is the impact it will have. The dancers will be able to have ease within their time budget because instead of trying to organize work plus training plus rehearsal plus school plus teaching etc.....they will not be forced to look for so MANY alternatives to make money. This will give them a stress free environment and allow them to come to work with open minds and bodies. This will allow them  to contribute to society through dance and art, which is what these dancers have spent so much time and money training to do.

What We Need & What You Get

Let us be honest here. We have the space to dance in. We have the place to show you our dance.We just need the money to pay the dancers for their blood, sweat and tears. Literally.  Dance is physical manual labour that also entails asking oneself emotionally based personal questions. A dance process will require self examination and intelligence is required for memory, dance construction and cast connection. Should you be able to donate $10, this will pay 1 dancer for 1 hour of work.  Why not pay a dancer YOU know for 1 hour?? Some of the incentives we can offer you are glimpses into this private world of dance construction through photo postcards and artcards of the process. We will have magnets and even artist cards from the The Grand Theatre, here in Calgary.


Other Ways You Can Help


Once you donate, or even if you can't, why not spread the word? Use the sharing tools and spread word of this fundraising effort by word of facebook, twitter, and email! Let's get the word out there and get these dancers paid!

ANOTHER WAY TO JOIN IN ON THE FUN??? Attend the FUNDRAISER at Local 522 (Calgary, Alberta) on FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 09!! Doors open at 10pm!!

Come join us for a fun night of dancing, mingling, performance and silent auction! We hope to see you there!
$10 ADV and $15 at the door! 

http://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=102627799...

story:
Who We Are & What We're Doing:

Daisy's Madhouse is a non-profit theater in Boise, Idaho. We aim to produce quality theater which diversifies and expands audiences in the Treasure Valley by actively reaching out to younger audiences, cultivating the next generation of theater goers.

"The Last Five Years" is a contemporary song-cycle musical that ingeniously chronicles the five year life of a marriage, from meeting to break-up... or from break-up to meeting, depending on how you look at it.  Written by Jason Robert Brown, this show is an intensely personal look at the relationship between a writer and an actress told from both points of view.

Why We're Doing It & How You Can Help:

We love this show and can't wait to bring it to the stage in June of 2014, but we need your help!  You know that saying, "you need money to make money"?  Well we need money to make art.  Things like performance rights, materials rentals, venues, costumes, set pieces, etc. require funds.  This is your chance to be the village that raises our show!

We have set a fundraising goal of $2,000, which we plan to supplement with other fundraising projects.  This will cover our more immediate needs of performance rights and materials rentals and get us on our way to covering the other costs of the show.  In return, we plan to produce a show that will hopefully touch your hearts as much as it has ours.  And you'll get cool perks for helping!

Other Ways To Help:

Can't donate money?  We would still love your support! Please share this campaign on your social networks!  And, of course, we would love to see all of you at our show in June!!!

Thank you!!!
